description:
My favorite ramen place in SF! 

The first time I went here I got the Orenchi Ramen, which was good but not amazing. I immediately had regrets about my order after trying my friends bowl of Beyond Ramen - it had much more flavor! This is now my favorite place in SF for ramen - I've tried a few other places that just weren't as good as this. Get the Beyond Ramen!
author: Christa S.

description:
We came here for dinner on a weekday - it was quite busy at the restaurant, so there was a 30 minute wait. 

I ordered the orenchi ramen, which has a shio/salt base broth. I tried my mom's beyond ramen (shoyu base), and preferred mine personally because its taste was more pure and not overpowered by the soy sauce.

Overall, I found that the ramen was good but not really outstanding.
author: Megan G.

description:
Review for food quality: 5 stars

Wait time: 6:20pm to 7:10pm seated time on a Sunday night. 

Just came here yesterday after my move back to California and I had to have some Orenchi. Since I moved to SF I decided to give the Valencia location a shot. 

My love for Orenchi's original tonkotsu shio broth has been since the first time I've sipped on their salty buttery goodness.

This location lived up to the Orenchi's legacy. Had their original ramen while my brothers had the tonkotsu shoyu Orenchi Beyond. Both broths was delicious. 5/5

Had the kaarage and it tasted more delicious to me because they left the skin of the chicken on and I liked that the lightly dusted flour wasn't as salty as the original location the chicken was still marinated and flavorful especially w the squeeze of lemon! 4.5/5

Of course also had to have the takoyaki, although not traditionally made like in Japan. The exterior was fried and a little greasier than I would've liked but still tasty w the bonito flakes, I would've appreciated a more chunky octopus inside however still tasty. 3.5/5

If you must have ramen please check them out you won't regret it!
author: Victoria U.

description:
Everything is just perfect! Fired oyster is a must try!
Also fried octopus and their signature ramen!!! Service is also good! YUM!!!
author: Fairy S.

description:
Finally found a ramen place that can rival
Ramen Misoya. I ordered beyond ramen with spicy miso, egg and corn. The soup was garlicky and had fried pieces of garlic floating in it. But you can still see the grated raw garlic floating in the soup. The broth was so good that I literally drank all of it. The noodles were perfectly chewy and thick. I like thick chewy eggy ramen. Very good place.  I highly recommend. I would definitely come back.
author: mei s.

description:
Beautiful interior & delicious ramen - perfect for catching up with friends or going on a date!

+ Seated immediately upon entry
+ Interior is beautifully decorated and dimly lit, love!
+ Orenchi Ramen ($13.5) : Thicker chewy noodles, not an overly oily or heavy broth, melt in your mouth meat (on the thinner side), WHOLE soft boiled egg done to perfection

- Make a reservation if you want to sit at a table
- Check in on yelp for a free topping up to $2 value!!
- Service was attentive but felt like they were rushing us a bit
author: Annie D.

description: I've been on a bit of a ramen kick recently and this place hit the ramen craving!! There's usually a long wait so I'd recommend making a reservation. The broth is very flavorful and the restaurant has a great ambiance. I'd recommend going here if you're in the area and craving ramen.
author: Nesha P.

description: Check in on yelp to receive a free topping!! The free topping can be worth up to $2 so you can get a slice of pork, soft boiled egg, corn, or other toppings. My friends and I had the original Orenchi and the beyond. I personally prefer the original. The beyond has a strong garlic taste. Their noodles are definitely on the harder side which I like. The price is decent, maybe slightly on the higher side. The soft boiled egg is definitely the best part of Orenchi!
author: Jennifer Y.

description:
Orenchi Beyond is aptly named as it has gone so far beyond the original Orenchi I knew and loved that it needs to revisit (and perhaps replicate) its humble beginnings. What happened? I was so excited to try this branch as I had spent countless days frequenting its Santa Clara counterpart - the original parent - Orenchi (as is) Ramen. No extra frills. No need to go Beyond what is already good. 

Anticipation, high hopes and dreams of the rich tonkotsu broth blending against that crunch of the chicken karaage had set the expectation for my first encounter at...Orenchi Beyonddd. As if it is a galaxy far far away in the stretches of George Lucas' mind - on a planet of hot souptopia with thin noodlians and thick noodlens alike living in peace and harmony.  But noooooo enter the salt bomb!! Flee for your life!!!!!

And that sort of describes, in short, my experience at Orenchi Beyond.  I just could not get Beyond all the salt in the ramen. The saltiness overpowered everything... the broth, the vegetables, the noodles.   I really hoped to taste the natural tomato broth but was so distracted - I could not taste anything but salt.  Was it because I got "too cute" and ventured to try something new - the vegan ramen?  I am left wondering.

The one redeeming factor is the friendly service and well decorated atmosphere.  I also like that this restaurant is accommodating for parties of one. 

Orenchi Beyond, please hear my plea to return from far far Beyond - be proud of your original Orenchi ways and the Bay Area ramen heritage you represent.
author: Vivienne K.

description:
This is my go-to ramen spot in a City of hundreds of ramen options. I go about every 2-3 weeks and always leave a happy girl. 

Delicious deep flavorful clean both, nice noodle texture (not over cooked like most places), pork that melts in your mouth and always a perfectly boiled silky egg. 

I usually do the Orenchi ramen which is my favorite and chicken karaage which have the crispiest skin and so moist.  Sometime if I'm lucky, there's an extra piece of crispy skin on top. 

Service is always on point, even on busy nights, as they always have 3-4+ staff on the floor. I love coming here with friends as it's vibrant, fun (design and decor), tall ceilings and good acoustics for conversation.  

Also, this is one of my favorite spots to eat by myself. I love to come after a long day of work or yoga, sit at the bar which faces away from the dining tables, and enjoy a hot bowl of ramen while reading my book or phone.  Even with a full restaurant, it's not too loud. The bar option is very warm and comfortable.
author: April K.

description:
Really 3 stars because I would never come here...if I lived in LA. But I live in SF and this is probably the best ramen to be found in SF. But it really can't compare with ramen in LA which might be the gold standard for American ramen ( never had ramen in NYC tho...)?

The service was good, it's a stylish and cute place, but it's not cheap and the food is good but not amazing.  You'll probably pay between 14 and 17 for your noodles. 

I think the vegan ramen looked like it was the best, but sadly that's not what I got. Definitely I'll get that next time and I'm not even vegan.
author: El B.

description:
VEGAN friendly.  It's not a wide variety, but they offer vegan appetizers and vegan Ramen for anyone interested (:

The location is not the best, I wouldn't spend too much time walking around here, or if you do decide to walk, make sure it's not at night time.  The area surrounding here is homeless central.  

They do offer indoor and outdoor seating, outside there are nice heating lamps installed above you so if it gets chilly they will turn those on to accommodate you in the cold weather.

We ordered appetizers: Karrage Chicken and Vegan Gyoza.  

I give the chicken a 4/5 stars: Very crispy and enjoyable.  We had to ask for a side of spicy mayo, it did not come with it.  This mayo was really spicy but the flavor was really good.  

I give the Vegan Gyoza a 3/5 stars: mainly because it seemed a little squishy and pretty mushy.  I will say I enjoyed the hint of crisp in it though, we didn't ask but believe it to me parts of edamame.  It really gave it some good texture.

The Ramen gets a 4/5 stars: (we got the Orenchi Ramen w/pork broth. itself was delicious.)  The broth is so rich.  The pork chashu was okay, it was tender but very very fatty.  I wish there was a little more meat and less fat.  Definitely not the best cut!   The noodles are so bouncy and yummy.  I really enjoy Orenchi's noodles.  I love the seaweed crisp included, the mushrooms, and bamboo shoots gave it a really good taste.  I added corn as well which I always do to give the ramen a satisfying crunch!  I wish Orenchi had an option to add fried garlic chips... that would really make this ramen a lot more enjoyable.  But this is just me being picky.  All in all the ramen is very enjoyable.  I wouldnt mind eating here again.  

Not the best ramen I've ever had, but it's still very satisfying =)

No issues with service or waiters.  They were prompt and quick and very kind and informative.  

Good first time experience overall!
author: Tori G.

description: So good. Wait time is so much better than the Santa Clara location-no wait at all! Amazing service and the ambiance is great. Will definitely come back again and again!
author: Jenny L.

description:
I ordered the orenchi ramen with spicy miso.

While the broth was a little rich for my taste, mixing in the spicy miso helped cut through that. The noodles were different than what I'm used to, but still chewy and enjoyable. I also really liked that they had garlic paste and pepper on every table! My only real complaint was that there weren't a lot of toppings - plenty of noodles, but everything else was kind of lacking. 

It's by my workplace, so I'll definitely be back! Out of every ramen place I've tried, this comes second just behind Marufuku.
author: Hannah H.

description: Another outpost of the Orenchi empire. There's a nice outdoor seating area and inside has both tables and bar seating. I recommend making a reservation for dinner, especially if you're not going at opening. Service is quick. Not sure why the shoyu ramen and shio ramen have different toppings. But if you want an egg, go with shio. I think the shoyu broth is better because it's not as salty and has more umami. But I really wanted an egg. Check in on Yelp for a free topping!
author: Sherry L.

description: Ordered the shio (salt)-based tonkotsu ramen.  It came with savory thick egg noodles.  Yes, savory noodles just on their own.  They might have cooked them with a touch of salt.  Delicious.  They also blowtorched the pork chashu before they served it to us so the pork had a nice char to it.  Amazing.  Price was $13.50 per bowl; pretty average for quality ramen especially in the city.  Service was quick and wait staff were friendly.  Two thumbs up!
author: Kev H.

description: I thought this place had great vibes. The layout and decor is artful and location is still a bit gritty. I had the Orenchi Ramen which I thought was really good, but when I ran though previous bowls of ramen I've had and I'm not sure this measured up.
author: Leslie T.

description: The service is great and the place is cute. We had a nice experience, but the food was underwhelming. We had "cocktails" which were overly sweet and didn't seem to have any alcohol. The ramen was tasty but nothing special. Overall the experience was just ok.
author: Rachel G.

description: I'm not vegan.  I never order vegan but the reviews and photos for vegan ramen looked so good.  Added some spice, it's off the chain!
author: Hanah L.

description:
Worth the wait, for the most part. :)

The table service is fast, simple, and they seriously turn tables like lightning here when the wait gets out of hand. 
We ended up hanging around for 40 minutes until we got called, with 20 parties ahead of us, signing in on the waitlist at 6:30 on a Sunday. 
They seem to be a bit too lenient with groups who get called and initially don't show, only to come back 15-20 mins after getting called trying to get their spot back. They kept seating them regardless. A bit frustrating as we got called up and intercepted by the no-shows, so our table was given away twice. -_-  

Ordered:
-Hot butter garlic scallops (the garlic sauce is heaven, we were not stoked that the scallops weren't trimmed - gummy and weird. Maybe this is normal but elsewhere I've always seen scallops served trimmed)
-Takoyaki (served PIPING hot. Burned my tongue for these but didn't care. These were delicious and every bit as good you'd imagine they'd taste from watching any anime.)
-Tonkatsu ramen with tamago
-Soy sauce base ramen with tamago and extra nori

The broth was a bit weak for our taste, though both were served hot and full of chewy noodles. Tamago was done perfectly, with creamy yolky centers and soft egg whites. 

-Snow white japanese IPA aka "malt product". A must try for those who enjoy hoppy beers. 


Get here early to avoid the headache of a wait and enjoy!
author: Sam W.

description: Well since my last review I have been here about another 100 times. I try all the latest arrivals on the SF ramen landscape, but nothing hits the spot like Orenchi. It used to be I would have that craving, and the craving was usually for a burrito. Now the perfect comfort food for me is a lovely bowl of noodles at Orenchi. It is pretty much perfect!
author: James T.

description: Located around the corner from my apt so I frequent here often for a quick meal. Usually can find a spot at the bar rather quickly.  Their ramen is good and the mini rice bowls as well. Lots of different ramen options. The flavor of the ramen has changed a bit from a few years ago but maybe that's just me. I remember the broth being more flavorful and intense. Never the less,  good ramen spot if you live nearby.
author: soy k.

description:
I'm used to going to orenchi in Santa Clara so when I discovered orenchi beyond in San Francisco, I was in love! I found the lines here are so much shorter than the ones in Santa Clara and you can get on the waitlist through yelp! 

As if the orenchi ramen wasn't amazing enough, try the orenchi beyond ramen! It just exploded with flavor! Check in on yelp to redeem a free topping worth up to $2!
author: Frances V.

description:
On a cold, rainy night, I was offered a seat next to the door.  Being that it was a cold, rainy night, and I was cold, and a little wet, I asked if I could sit inside where it was warm.  I guess some things are not well understood.

I got the Beyond Ramen.  The broth is flavored with chicken and pork.  It's thin, dotted with fat, and has a hint of charred flavor.

The yellow noodles are thick and straight.  From living in America and not Japan, they remind me of thick, al dente spaghetti noodles.

I enjoyed the sheet of seaweed that had gotten moist on the bottom and remained crispy where is stuck out of the soup.

The chachu pork was tender, with melty ribbons of fat.  Crunchy, fried garlic rounds, and juicy rectangles of bamboo shoots rounded out the textures.

I missed the egg, with it's creamy yellow yolk.  You pay extra for egg.

I had to not finish my soup and leave rather suddenly.  A couple was sat near me, one of them having a strong odor of cheap French parfum, mixed with unwashed vagina.  I was almost choking.
author: Sondra H.

description:
Came here and had a tasty meal with my family. The green beans were *fabulous*. The octopus dumplings(?) were a fun distraction, but we could have just had 2 or 3, instead of 6 or 8. 

My wife's vegan ramen was tasty. I liked it better than the chicken soba noodles I got. I think they would have been better with a soft boiled egg. 

The tastes were different and fun, but we would have preferred more "standard" (whatever that is) ramen options. But we are definitely going back.
author: Benjamin T.

description: Best ramen, best small plates, never much of a wait, fantastic atmosphere.
author: Gina C.

description:
My first experience of Orenchi was at their south bay location, and it wasn't that great (too salty) so I was hesitant to come back to another one, but Orenchi Beyond did not disappoint at all! The staffs were very nice and helpful and the ramens were so flavorful! I ordered the Tan Tan Ramen while my boyfriend got the Beyond Ramen and we also got Perfect Snow Sake to share. It was my first time trying dipping noodle, and it was sooo good! The soup was very rich and not salty at all. It is slightly spicy but not unbearable. I would recommend finishing it up fast though if you do get that because towards the end the food gets a little cold since the noodles and the meat are not soaked in the broth. The Beyond Ramen was also awesome! The garlic taste opens up your palate right away. The Sake was more to the sweeter end but it is stronger than other Sake I've had, let's just say I'm glad we came on a Saturday night :D 

I would for sure come back again and even give the other Orenchi location another try!
author: Rachel G.

description:
Orenchi Beyond, you had me at: "Now Serving Vegan Ramen"
But perhaps your sign(s) should have said: "Now Serving DELICIOUS Vegan Ramen"
Because, well, that's the reality. You serve delicious vegan ramen. Thank you.

I was a little skeptical when I saw this version of vegan ramen, it appeared to be more of a soy-based broth and didn't look creamy (like some of the vegan offerings at other restaurants)...it also had eggplant, which is not an appealing vegetable to me (I'm a picky vegan, yes, picky with my vegetables too). But really, I've been eating so much ramen lately that I honestly don't need to eat fattening, creamy broth all of the time, so this is a good option!

Anyway, I received my eggplant-free ramen and was happy to see the bowl was loaded with some other veggies, such as cauliflower, tomatoes, bell peppers, etc. The noodles used also appear to be rice noodles, which were actually a good idea. The broth was well-flavored and you also have the option of loading your dish up with some garlic (a jar of it is on the table). But if you like spicy (like me) don't order the spicy miso paste. Upon my inquiry they let me know the miso paste has fish in it. There are some spices on the table though...or you can sneak in some sriracha or your preferred vegan hot sauce/peppers (share ideas with me!). I promise I have not done that...yet. But seriously, the broth is good as is without spice.
author: Christina M.

description:
Orenchi Ramen is my favorite bowl of ramen in the city.  I've also visited the Santa Clara location and was pleasantly surprised to find that the San Francisco location is just as good; no, even better because there aren't long lines like there are in Santa Clara. The ramen is perfectly cooked, homemade, nice and chewy.  I usually go for the miso based broth with an extra slow cooked egg. The egg is perfectly done. It's not hard boiled like some places nor is it soft-boiled with undercooked whites. It's cooked in the broth and the yolk is still soft while the white is done. The tonkatsu is sliced paper thin and it's wonderfully fatty and rich, liquifiying at the touch of a spoon.  Also worthy are the shishito peppers and chicken karage, the latter tender, marinated, trimmed of fat but with skin on. 

I can't recommend this place enough.
author: Henry A.

description: Oh boy we walked about 30 minutes to get here from Union Square. I wouldn't recommend anyone doing that though. You see too many bums on the street.  But the exercise brought back my appetite after having breakfast only few hours ago.  So I enjoyed my ramen today. Noodles were little different than other restaurants. Everything was really good but I wasn't blown away. I normally go with Tantanmen because I like the little bit of spicy taste. Staffs were friendly and place looked clean.
author: June F.

description:
I am so disappointed both ethically, morally & legally.

THE MENUE IS FULL OF LIES:Does not state clearly in any way that the items contain FISH EVEN when fish is not listed as an ingredient.

NOWHERE on the menue does it have any warnings or the HONEST list of All ingridents. 

WE GOT SICK ( after stating that we can't eat fish need no fish)

We got NO Apology or HELP in any way!

NEVER AGAIN!  

VALENCIA ST SF!!!!
author: Concerned Community Member C.

description: Ramen is amazing, BUT the service is absolutely terrible! The waitress took over 15 min to get in our first order, and then messed up on all the orders. I informed her and she had the worst attitude problem. It also took like 20 min for us to pay and at one point we had to get up to hand her our cards. We gave her two cards to split the check and she ended up charging the same card twice.... It's so sad to see a good ramen place with terrible service. I'll love to come back for the ramen but also can't take a lunch break for over an hour....
author: Amy C.

description: Pretty good ramen soup (almost a bit too rich) although very few toppings. Portion for both salmon ikura don and wasabi tako was huge.
author: Jessica S.

description:
Holy COW the service here is terrible. We came on a Sunday night just 20 minutes after opening with a party of 9, but we waited over an hour for a table! They called so many parties ahead of us... but shouldn't they prioritize who came first by clearing out space? You can imagine how "hangry" we were.

Once seated, we thought it would get better, but we were faced with more poor service. We had to remind them to get something as simple as water cups three times. Also, after we ordered, the waitress came back saying she forgot almost all of our orders. Girl, weren't you taking notes!? I don't understand. And once we got our food, we still had to remind our waitress for our side of chili oil, that I asked for three times.

Now onto the food--it has potential, but the noodles are heavily lacking. They taste like the ones you buy at the freezer section of an Asian supermarket. The broth was just okay, but the pork slices and especially the egg were on point. Like I said, there's hope here.
author: Sherilyn R.

description:
Delicious garlicy broth and noodles! Plus, a great modern and open design restaurant. It was very busy at 8pm on a Saturday, but my friend and I got seats at their big communal table. 

I got the Beyond Ramen and I couldn't get enough of that garlic broth. Mm mm mm. I only wished I had read the menu closer because I didn't realize it doesn't come with an egg! I always look forward to my ramen eggs. I don't know if I've ever had a ramen without egg actually. 

Solid service. 

Definitely worth checking out.
author: Emma W.

description:
I easily made dinner reservations through Yelp.

Service was very friendly and food came out in good time. I liked the music and they even threw on some Craig David. 

I was hoping to get the tsukemen ramen and when I asked about it, our waitress said they no longer offered it but instead had a vegan ramen that I guess replaced the tsukemen. I ordered the Orenchi ramen which I've had at the Santa Clara location. This time, it fell a bit flat for me. I loved the noodles and the eggcellent boiled egg. While the broth was thin, it just lacked that oomph. 

I also had the takoyaki which had sizable pieces of octopus but again, the ball itself wasn't very flavorful.
author: Maya S.

description:
No waiting, we went early and had ordered, some of us. 
Very friendly, loved the tuna with wasabi. I got a bit lost with the chicken soup - kept looking for the meat, but didn't find any. Well, I am a Ramen newbee, so...
author: Mike T.

description:
The beyond ramen at Orenchi was decent, but nothing to write home about. Broth consistency wasn't quite there and there was not enough pork belly in there. The noodles were quite excellent nonetheless and had a great chewy texture. Whatever pork was in there was tasty but more was needed. 

The apple green tea however was extremely good, and not too sweet.
author: Bharat B.

description:
I've been a member since 2014 but I've never really wrote many reviews.

Honestly, after coming here , it has brought the life force out of my Yelp account. I cannot not (sic) write a review!!!

This is by far the best Ramen I had ever had in my life.

Coming from Los Angeles and seeing all of beautiful San Francisco sights, this was definitely the cherry on top of my whole excursion/day!! 

Family members recommended this place and I cannot thank them enough!!!! Coming from LA and trying many other places before this.. this was DEFINITELY WORTH the wait.

I have to commend the chef for his art, skill, and craft.
author: H. C.

description: Great service & pretty good Ramen. Uniquely made broth for sure. Orenchi broth was a bit saltier than I had hope for. Noodle was supposed to be more firm than Beyond but about the same. The broth for the Beyond was just right.
author: Jennifer H.

description: Overrated ramen $17 for vegan miso. Disappointed in the quality and service. Save your money And go elsewhere.
author: Mackenzie S.

description:
I recently embarked on a completely pointless quest to rank most of the Ramen Places in the Bay Bay Bay.

Ranking explained:  #1 (listed at the top)  is my favorite/ #?  (listed at the bottom) is my least favorite. Check out my latest reviews for my latest up to date Rankings. 

Rod Ramen Rating = (Taste of Broth / Taste of Noodles/Taste of other stuff in soup) on a Scale of 1 to 10 (10/10/10) being the best score possible

* Please note that I don't have a preference for thick or thin noodles or thick or clear broth I just call it like I feel it.
When I look at reviews sometimes just want to know where to go or how a user compares one venue against another to see if we have similar tastes. If you're curious, I have rankings for Boba, Bakeries and Ramen as well (random right?)  Follow my profile to see my most recent reviews.  I hope I can be helpful since so many Yelpers have helped me discover new places. 

# 1 Marufuku Ramen *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 9/8/8 *Rod's Yelp Rating *5 stars 
# 2 Mensho Tokyo *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 8/8/8 *Rod's Yelp Rating *4 stars 
# 3 Orenchi Ramen *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 8/8/7 *Rod's Yelp Rating *4 stars 
# 4 Orenchi Beyond  *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 7/8/7 *Rod's Yelp Rating *4 stars 
# 5 Ramen Parlor *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 7/6/7 *Rod's Yelp Rating *4 stars 
# 6 Ramen Dojo *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 7/6/7 *Rod's Yelp Rating *4 stars 
# 7 Iza Ramen *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 7/6/5 *Rod's Yelp Rating *4 stars 
# 8 Nojo Ramen Tavern *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 6/6/6 *Rod's Yelp Rating *4 stars 
# 9 Yokohama Lekei Ramen *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 6/5/6 *Rod's Yelp Rating *4 stars 
# 10 Ippudo *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 5/6/5 *Rod's Yelp Rating *3 stars 
# 11 Santa Ramen *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 5/5/5 *Rod's Yelp Rating *3 stars 
# 12 Ramen Yamadaya *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 5/5/5 *Rod's Yelp Rating *3 stars 
# 13 Sobo Ramen *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 4/4/5 *Rod's Yelp Rating *3 stars 
# 14 Ramen 101 *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 4/4/5 *Rod's Yelp Rating *3 stars 
# 15 Ramen Shu *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 4/5/4 *Rod's Yelp Rating *3 stars 
# 16 Suzu Noodle House *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 3/3/6 *Rod's Yelp Rating *2 stars 
# 17 Hinodeya Ramen *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 4/4/4 *Rod's Yelp Rating *2 stars 
# 18 Slurp Ramen *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 4/4/4 *Rod's Yelp Rating *2 stars 
# 19 Tadamasa *Rod SF Bay Area Ramen Rating * 3/3/3 *Rod's Yelp Rating *2 stars
author: Rod M.

description:
Best Ramen in SF!!!

Visited this place thursday around 6:15pm and no line so seated right away. Pretty empty on weekdays, best time to go for no wait.

Came here before as well on several occasions, but this was my first visit in a little over a year.

Nice friendly staff.

Lots of seating. Very nice decor. Bar area as well if you want to dine on the counter.

Nice bathrooms in the back! Sink area is outside of the bathroom.

Prices are decent for the quality of food you get. $13 for ramen.

We ordered: Calamari, Kaarege, (2) Beyond Ramen(soy sauce base) = $44(with tax)

Ramen - Moderate serving. One piece of pork that has so much flavor. Broth is rich but kind of fatty for my taste but so good!!! Egg is perfectly cooked. Some veggies in it like bamboo shoot. Noodles were good.

Calamari - Crispy and has very good dipping sauce. Small serving size

Kaarege - Not as crispy for my taste. Flavor was ok but I would not get again. Average chicken

Overall fast service(if not busy) and very tasty and rich ramen. Must try!!!
author: Michele G.

description:
I've always had a fond place in my heart for Orenchi Beyond. I had first experienced them via the South Bay location and they were one of the first nice ramen places in the city. 

I really like the Orenchi ramen and the hubby LOVES the Beyond Ramen (which is rich and strong and not for the faint of heart). However, the I find the Orenchi ramen which is quite rich can be a bit more than I'm looking for.  So, I was glad when they introduced the Shio chicken soba -- it is light and delicate, but delicious. 

There have since been many ramen places in the city and my favorite when judging on ramen alone would probably be Marufuku or Ramen Dojo. But, in terms of overall experience, Orenchi Beyond is my favorite!  They do great appetizers which makes it an amazing overall experience and brings a bit more variety than one big bowl of ramen. 

They do the best tako yaki and chicken karaage is any Japanese restaurant in the Bay. The misomayo chasu gohan is super delicious and now a great alternative when I'm not quite ready for an Orenchi ramen but looking for something more substantial than the tori soba. 

The gyoza was ok, but I'd probably pass next time. Too much sesame flavor and filling was too soft for my liking.
author: Kathryn C.

description:
Got here early with some friends and four kids (ages 7-10) - waited outside - opens at 11:30. Clean and modern looking - open kitchen so the kids could watch how they make the ramen noodles and soup- ordered the Most popular item Beyond Ramen and their signature soup Orenchi Ramen- both were delicious with the right amount of fresh noodles and broth and extras. Order the gyoza and chicken karaage too- will not disappoint! 
Tip: try to get there when it opens - it's a small restaurant and seats get taken fast.
author: Christina J.

description:
Recently, my girlfriend and I decided made it our goal to scour the Bay Area for the best ramen shop. Personally, out of all the places that we have tried, we really dig Orenchi Ramen in Santa Clara. Because of how good their ramen was, we were excited to hear that there was a sibling restaurant in the city by virtually the same name: Orenchi Beyond. According to one of my dear Yelp friends (Christine), "Comparing Orenchi Beyond to the original Orenchi in Santa Clara is like comparing your current boyfriend to the last guy you were in love with" Because of that, we had to try this place and settle the score on whether this city version of Orenchi was better.

Orenchi beyond is located near the corner of Duboce the Valencia. It is extremely close to the 101 AND the 16th & Mission Bart, and so I give this place props for the convenient location. Parking may suck here on high traffic hours, but we were able to pull up on the street nearby (free parking after 6 on weekends!). Luckily, we came at a good time and were seated immediately.

The first amazing thing I noticed about this restaurant was that the atmosphere is as good as I'd want from a hip, ramen shop. For one, there's a giant TV outside for people waiting in line. And, there's a YUGE projector inside for people who want to eat and watch anime. AND, there's no wall between you and the kitchen, so you get a bird's eye view of the magic. Plus, if you like eating in dim lighting, this place is perfect.

On their menu, which was average sized for a ramen shop, we were only interested in their two top ramens: the soy sauce (Shio Beyond) and the salted ramen (Orenchi), which you can find at the Santa Clara location. We both got large (+$2), with an extra side of chasu since it was free with Yelp check-in. 

Ramen came out pretty fast, which was a good bonus since the restaurant was kind of busy. The first impression I got from my large soy sauce bowl was that this was mighty salty. The broth was very flavorful and I thought that the meat was tender enough (though it could've been juicer), but dang, that soup was salty. I made a joke with my girlfriend that my Beyond ramen was probably just as salty as the salted, Orenchi ramen.

In terms of portion size, I thought the large size was mostly just noodles instead of actual ingredients. But I have to say that we were full after engulfing our bowls. To tell you the truth, I personally prefer my experience at Orenchi Ramen in Santa Clara because the soup was less salty and i felt that the quality of the noodles was better. My girlfriend preferred this place only because it was saltier, but to each their own!

Overall, I had an okay experience at Orenchi Beyond. Sure, I think the ramen was filling, but you will need several glasses of water to drown out that saltiness. The price point was decent, compared to how much ramen can cost in the city, but I have definitely had better. The selling point for this place for me was the atmosphere. Because of the ambiance, I am leaning more toward a "Nice-su, can take your parents here and they'll be happy" rating!

Eat well and prosper,
author: Bryan W.

description: The pork here is quite amazing. The broth is decent, noodles are thick and chewy. I would come back.
author: Tina L.

description: I remember going here 2 years ago and finding the broth salty and the noodles soggy. A recent drop-in has updated my views on this establishment, and I'm now ready to upgrade my review to a five. The tonkotsu noodles were thick and toothsome, and while the broth isn't quite Mensho-level, it is more than a cut above the average $15 fare offered at most modern ramen spots in SF. The takoyaki was stellar as well, and as an added benefit, there was no wait on a weekend dinner, which is rare for a good ramen spot.
author: Ken H.

description:
Broth and ramen: thumbs up,
Chashu: naaaaaaahhhhhh, it has no highlight besides a piece of loose meat
Karage: too dry, not juicy
author: Huixin R.

description:
And so the quest for good SF ramen continues.  I came here on a Saturday around noon, and there was absolutely no wait, so that was a welcome change from every other brunch place in the City.  I guess people really like their eggs on a weekend morning, eh?  Well, good, because that means no wait at non-brunchy places like this!

The ramen was really a 2.5.  The broth - which is key to a good bowl of ramen - was just not that flavorful, mostly salty.  It did not have that great depth of flavor and body that other better-developed broths possess.  It was missing the "it" factor.  

At over $13 for a bowl, I wasn't loving the price much either.  

Would I come back here?  Nope. I'll continue my search for a good bowl of ramen in SF.

Unlike LA, which years ago reached "peak" ramen, wherein every place pretty much serves a good bowl of ramen, SF still has a long way to go.
author: Vivian C.

description:
Came in on a rainy day... perfect ramen weather. There was no wait during lunchtime which was very nice. The BF and I ordered the Beyond Ramen and the Orenchi Ramen, both of which were good. Very thick, hearty, fatty tonkatsu based broth; you can even see little fat particles in your soup. I loved the consistency of the noodles; chewy and thick enough to hold the heaviness of the broth. Chashui was soft and tender, but only 1 piece per bowl The other toppings were a bit sparse as well. All in all, very decent ramen (not my favorite in the city), but would come again. 

TL;DR -- Good ramen. Slightly pricey. Terrible location/hard parking
author: Jenny N.

description:
One of my favorite ramen restaurants. The flavor of the tonkatsu is wonderful. Very nice staff. 

However it can be a little noisy and it would be better for customers if they opened earlier, perhaps 5:00.
author: Tom K.

description: My favorite bowl of ramen in SF. To me it's the most authentic to what I eat in Tokyo. Broth is not too rich, egg is cooked perfectly, and the pork is so tender. No random stuff thrown in the bowl (seriously I hate it when I get lettuce, hen eggs and other randomness in my US ramen). Service is always fantastic and they take reservations! One of the few restaurants in SF that I return to and take out of town guests.
author: Robin P.

description: Great taste on the dishes we had last night. The pork belly was melt in your mouth tender. The Orenchi Ramen with meat was dense with flavor, noodles and meat. Add double meat if you want to make it more hearty. Note: they offer both gluten-free and vegan options as well.
author: Frank S.

description:
If you are planning on eating here, it's a good idea to make a reservation, even if it's the day of. My bf made reservations and we were seated right away when we got there. They also offer one free topping when you check in! We ordered the karage for an appetizer. They were good, but resembled chicken wings because the bones were still intact. It's a combination of sweet, savory, and spicy all in one. I liked it a lot. 

I ordered the orenchi ramen and added the extra spicy miso. All around, it's one of the better ramen I've had. My own fault that it was too spicy because I did ask for extra spicy.. lesson learned. Nonetheless, the egg was delicious and the broth was hearty, although the spiciness was overbearing all the other flavors by the end of the meal.
author: Annie H.

description:
Squiggly noodles and tasty broth for the pleasant dining event!  The egg was slightly runny and that is how I preferred it.  I adore how there is a clear see-through glass window to watch how they make the ramen by the chef staff!

Do order their tako wasasbi!  It compliments well with the ramen!  It opens up the palate and has that tako texture that I like a lot!  

Their takoyaki is a good starter.  The pork katsu is made into bite sized sticks instead of the typical slices served.  That's different and great as a dipper to the sauce.  The hamachi carpaccio was surely a delicious appetizer as well. 

Sake was pleasant.

Ayce ramen spot with the great additions of appetizers to choose from on the menu!
author: Tiffany D.

description: Heard about this spot and took a nice little walk there from the Twitter building. I love Tonkatsu broth and this was one of the best I had. And if you check in on yelp, you get a free topping! Great service and friendly faces. I love how you can look into the kitchen and see what they are doing
author: Courtney S.

description:
3.5 / 5 stars

My friend and I decided to give Orenchi Beyond a try after finding the Burma Love line to be too long. The decor at Orenchi Beyond is pretty hipster, with exposed wood and picnic table style seating, definitely not your traditional Japanese ramen restaurant.

I was pretty disappointed though. This SF offshoot of the original Orenchi in South Bay doesn't measure up at all. The chicken karaage was too oily and left a little puddle of oil on the plate. The Orenchi ramen itself had good components -- good noodles, soft boiled egg, meat was decent -- but the broth wasn't super flavorful and dimensional.

All in all, maybe good for a quick ramen stop in the mission but not the best.
author: Tiffany P.

description:
I tried Orenchi in Santa Clara back in its opening phase and the wait was HORRENDOUS. I will never forget the time how I was starving and had to wait 2 hours for food. The longer it took, the higher my expectations. So with it being close to 1:30pm, I was about to rip somebody apart. 

Anyways, this is Orenchi Beyond. I shouldn't compare apples to oranges. I'll give Orenchi Beyond its fair treatment. For a Sunday evening, there was no wait. Although I love the no wait, there's something iffy about it. The number one ramen in SF is the Beyond Ramen. It doesn't come with an egg, so I added the egg. Orenchi is ALL about the egg. 

It comes out pretty fast with the broth piping hot. I love it. The broth is pretty fatty, but lacked umami flavor. The noodles had a weird texture and it was not al dente. I'm unable to grasp what the missing factor was, but it was okay. The saving factor was the egg as I previously mentioned. The egg is flavored well with a runny middle. I probably could eat five of those in one sitting. Not a joke. 

I guess I'll come back here. I mean, there's no wait and it's not terribly bad. It's close to the night life, so why not. 3.5 rounded to 4 because I'm a nice foodie :)
author: Fiona L.

description:
I actually ended up here by accident! How, you ask? Well, we had an event scheduled here...but I wrote it on my oh so carefully maintained calendar wrong! Doh!

Fortunately, there's a silver lining - for both me and them! A chance to review! New flavors, new experiences! And they got a good chunk of my wallet, cause I just can't resist trying a bunch of items when I go someplace new. 

But enough about me, you're here to hear about orenchi. I actually was really surprised to see they're only 3 stars here. Orenchi is one of those places you hear about a lot from friends and "200 bucket list restaurants in SF" lists and etc. I was eager to see the reality. 

Of course there's a line. I waited about 20min on a rainy Tuesday, and I didn't have anyone with me. But so it goes with awesome small places. 

Let's talk food and drink and flavors - the core of a restaurant. This time I went for orenchi ramen (start with the namesake, right?), large, with extra long onions and roasted pork. Then add on their draft sake (sequoia nama), and a peach chu-hi.

And you know? This might be sacrelig, but I think I prefer genki. Their extra noodles and extra richness and lower prices (not to mention less wait time) really go the extra mile. But this was still a fantastic treat. At first I was kinda disappointed, but with each bite the flavor built, until I couldn't stop. Such a great combination of savory and salty without being overwhelming. 

You know what else is cool? The severs - way helpful and nice. Oh and that they take reservations. But ESPECIALLY that they have happy hour! Happy hours at popular places are about as common as buffalo in SF (they exist! But you mostly just hear stories). $3 chu-Hi? And it goes until 730?! Amen to that! A must-repeat next time I'm back. 

All that fun does come at a price. For me, it was $33 before tip...up there, and though it would have been around $12 without booze or extras, it's still more expensive than many places. 

So, is it my favorite ramen place in SF? No, but it is fantastic. We are spoiled here. I definitely won't complain if someone brings me back here - I just won't put it on my OWN list of "must do" SFteraunts.
author: Chris S.

description:
Food:

Karaage - Wasn't the best attempt for me, just ok.  

Orenchi Ramen - Going Going GONE!!!!  What can I say...this was probably hands down the best ramen I've had thus far.  The noodles were pretty aldente and the broth was very hearty and packed with flavor.  Being a person that doesn't drink the broth so much when eating noodles this is one of the rare occasions where the bowl was left empty!

Service:  Sat at the bar and the waitstaff was friendly and attentive.

Ambiance:  It's a cool little spot and from what i hear the wait can get long.  Pretty modern I'd say.

Overall:  When I want ramen...this will be my go to place hands down!  Good job Orenchi!
author: Spencer Q.

description:
I came here with two friends on a rainy Saturday night. We had five groups in front of us when we put our name in. They had a nice waiting area- GREAT heat lamps, benches, and you can order drinks. We probably waited about 20 minutes to be seated.

We sat near the kitchen, sharing a table with two other customers. They served us drinks and water while we waited for our orders. We all ordered the Orenchi Ramen dish. The food was ready in about 10 minutes. 

The pork belly was more pork than belly in my opinion- which I preferred because I like more pork than fat. The egg was perfectly soft boiled and the noodles were the perfect texture-not too soft and not too under done. THE BROTH WAS PERFECT! It wasn't too salty or too bland... just the right amount of flavor. The portion size was also perfect for one person, not an overwhelming bowl of noodles. 

I'm not sure if we were done eating around closing time but the waitress came around when I was finishing my broth to take my bowl.... hello best part! Only thing that was a negative. 

At the end of the dinner, my friend took macadamia cookies from his pocket to share. :)

The ramen was great, the price was very reasonable. I'll definitely be going back to Orenchis!
author: Marcie A.

description:
This is my favorite ramen place in the city. It's one of the few places with ground pork which is my favorite and their broth is delicious and creamy. The staff is always friendly although they do get really busy sometimes and the service can be a little slow.  (They forgot our ice cream order one time so it look like 20 minutes to get it, our ramen didn't even take that long)

I'm giving five stars because it is so worth the wait for the ramen. They take reservations as well through yelp which is hard to find.
author: Rachel P.

description:
Can I just say, I prefer this location WAAAAAY more than the Orenchi Ramen in Santa Clara? Food is great if not practically the same as Santa Clara (some ramen snobs will say otherwise) but the atmosphere and experience at this place are so much better.

First off, they accept reservations - yes a ramen place that accepts reservations. Unlike Orenchi Ramen where you have to fight to get your name on the waiting list and hope it's not a 1 hr wait... Orenchi Beyond accepts Yelp reservations online. Thank god. Some people have a schedule to keep and can't wait absurdly long to get ramen.

Because of reservations, drop-ins might be hard especially if you're a group of 4 or more. HOWEVER... while you wait outside, you can order drinks and appetizers at their outdoor bar. It's a stand up place and there's only a rock to sit at, but it's something. PLUS they have heat lamps outside for waiting. There's even a TV outside... I kept getting distracted by the Hunger Games II movie that was playing at the time.

Also, this space is just much cooler than the Orenchi in Santa Clara. Interesting furniture and they have a projector that seems to play amusing Asian music videos... can't tell if K-Pop or J-Pop, but it's at least entertaining.

Orenchi's strength is the broth - it's very rich and savory. The noodles are OK, but the broth and their perfectly soft boiled egg are what make the ramen shine here. There are plenty of reviews that echo my opinion. Not in the mood for ramen? I can vouch that the appetizers and rice bowls are extremely delicious as well.

- Salmon Ikura Rice Bowl: I'm not sure how this can be a side to ramen... considering their ramen bowls are pretty big and filling here. But the rice bowls are delicious and perfectly portioned for small eaters - loved the flaked salmon and the generous amount of fish roe, and very filling despite the small slide! I'd recommend asking for some Japanese mayo on the side to pour on top of this - great combination!

- Negi-Toro Rice Bowl: Also very good, but I prefer the salmon ikura - the tuna on this was oddly dry in this. Maybe it needed some Japanese mayo to liven it up?

- Tonkatsu Fries: Basically a pork cutlet that's been pre-sliced and fried up individually. The concept was neat and the sauce it came with was delicious... it has this amazing spicy kick.

- Deep Fried Garlic: Indeed it is deep fried... and the garlic flavor is intense! It comes with this miso aoili sauce that compliments it really well.

Orenchi Ramen in Santa Clara is not worth the unreasonable 45 - 2 hr wait. The ramen is good... but it's not the most amazing in the world. And honestly, in the 2 hrs I wait for a table at Orenchi Ramen... I'm better off making the effort to go here. The only real advantage the Santa Clara has is there there is ample parking, but this location is easy to get to with public transporation.
author: Alyanna C.

description:
Since moving to the bay area, I've been trying to find the best Ramen in town.  While none of the ones in SF are close to those in LA or NYC, there is still a good selection. 

Of all the 12 that I've tried in the bay, Orenchi has proven to be the best value and taste for each bowl I get.  Since finding this location, I've taken many friends and incoming visitors of whom all have agreed it's the best Ramen they've had.
author: Craig V.

description: I don't know why this place only has 3.5 stars.  The service and ambiance is great.  They play some DJ vibes which goes great with the wall art, high ceilings, and glass window views to the kitchen.  I've been to the Orenchi in Santa Clara and the wait is ridiculous even if you get there before opening.  This place takes reservations! And it has the same broth and they have a Beyond broth which I decided to give a try.  It wasn't bad, definitely lighter than the original.  For my ramen preferences, I really like the noodles at Orenchi compared to thinner noodles like at Shin Sen Gumi.  With Yelp checkin you can get a free topping too which I opted for the egg. Parking can be tough but I think it's better than other spots in SF.  There's meter street parking but definitely add 10 minutes to your travel time just in case so you don't miss your reservation.
author: Jonathan C.

description: The original ramen here was delicious!! The noodles were the right texture and the soup wasn't too salty (which usually isn't the case at other ramen places I've been). I went on a Wednesday around 7 and there wasn't a line at all. Definitely would come here again!!
author: Amanda F.

description: Horrible customer service they kick us out because we arrive three minutes before opening, food was tasteless. Don't waste your money and time in this place.
author: Jesse R.

description: The tonkatsu ramen is filled with tasty, porky goodness. While I found the broth a bit salty for my liking, all the ingredients tasted fresh and added their own distinct touch to the meal.
author: Tyler W.

description: A great little ramen spot. We had to wait maybe 10 min for a table on a Sunday evening. We sat at the counter. We started with agedashi tofu (prepared lightly fried with broth) and the house salad, which was a generous portion. The dressing was a little salty but very good. We had both the ramens. A nice hearty portion, a little too much fried garlic in the broth in my opinion but very delicious. I had mine with spicy miso which made all the difference. We'll be making this our go to ramen joint in our neighborhood.
author: Ray C.

description: Love this place. I go pretty often, as I live a short walk away. This is a great place to get a nice soothing bowl of ramen. It's pretty casual, the flavors are good, it's usually buzzing with people, and it's relatively fast too. The bowls are big enough for me to save some leftovers (I like to have 2 meals for the price of one!). The only thing I'd say is I was pretty surprised at how small the one slice of meat I had was in ramen, the first time I ordered. Thought it was a mistake. But I came to learn that the meal is super filling and I definitely didn't need to add more meat. So I can't really complain! I'm a fan :)
author: natalie s.

description:
Good ramen but man, I was still hungry after my bowl! 

Checking into Yelp gives you $2 off toppings, dope, good job Orenchi. The place has a decent amount of seating. I'd say a group of 4 is ideal. They take reservations so of course, go ahead and opt to do that if you're coming on the weekend. During the week, it's pretty uncrowded (I walk past this place a lot). 

The broth is good, the noodles are good- so why 3 stars? Whatever meat you decide to order, you definitely feel skimped. The meat was smaller than my closed fist, sadly. We ordered the spicy karrage to start, which was good. We figured we didn't need more appetizers because we would get full off the ramen, but man were we wrong.

Staff is friendly, service is good. I just am disappointed because this is the first time I ever felt hungry still after a bowl of ramen.
author: Arezou A.

description:
It's clean, casual but decent, and has good customer service. Found this place on Yelp. Inspite of the reviews that the ramen is salty, I chose this place for us to eat lunch. It was Monday and there was no wait. Six of us were anticipating to eat good ramen. First we ordered appetizers. Salmon sashimi was really good, the raw salmon was fresh. I liked the chicken karaage, fried pork sticks and I love their fried oysters. I didn't like the takoyaki, a bit salty for me. Now, for the ramen, I had the Orenchi original. It has one small thin slice pork belly, an egg, bamboo shoot strips, pieces of mushrooms, other stuff I donot recall and a lot of ramen noodles which was way too al dente, a bit firm but edible. The soup or the broth, the very reason for this ramen to be delicious and satifying was really salty. It ruined the taste of the soup. I ate only the solid ingredients there in, ate half of the noodles and didn't care for the broth. The only good thing in it was the seasoned soft boiled egg which was perfect.
The two of us who ordered Orenchi original both agreed the soup was salty. Two others ordered Spicy Beyond ramen said theirs was ok. The Seafood Special ramen was ok as well but, I don't think it's worth $18 bucks for the few pieces seafood it has.
For my conclusion, I cannot recommend this place if you're looking for good quality ramen. I will not be coming back to eat here, I do not like salty ramen.
Fyi, they already charge tip on your bill so check the info on your 1st receipt. I paid with credit card and when they brought back the receipt to be sign, this one doesn't show detailed info but I knew that the tip was already been added on the total. So read and check what you're about to pay unless you would like to give more tip.
author: Marlen B.

description:
As a ramen lover, I continue my hunt for the best ramen that SF has to offer. My credibility comes from my ramen experience in LA and Japan. Knowing that, Orenchi falls a little short of what I expected after hearing so many good things but it's still worth the try if you want to discover the best.

I ordered the Tonkotsu / salt broth for my ramen. The soft boil egg is purely perfection and the noodles are a nice al dente. The pork is too thinly sliced to shine and the broth isn't rich enough for me to fall in love. 

Although it's not one of the best I've had, it's still pretty tasty with great service.
author: Nitar L.

description:
I think this place has pretty decent ramen. This is their second store, their original ramen shop in Santa Clara, which I've never trekked to since it's so far! But I'm glad they opened in SF. I'm surprised this place doesn't have a solid 4 stars, as I think this place is a bit better than other ramen shops with 3.5 stars (aka Men Oh, Waraku).

I've been here a few times, and always get their regular special "Orenchi Ramen" which is their original, from their home store in Santa Clara. For $13.50, you get a medium-sized Tonkatsu broth bowl with pork belly, soft-boiled egg, green onion, bamboo shoot, mushroom, sesame, and seaweed. You can check in on yelp and get 1 extra topping for up to $2. I added in the corn, but to be honest they didn't add much in, a bit of a bummer. I love this ramen in particular, because their noodles are cooked just the way I like it - they are on the slightly thicker side, and chewy. This is my preference, and I can't say yours is the same way! But this is the way I love my ramen! The broth was also great - salty and flavorful. 

We also got the spicy negi gohan, and tonkatsu sticks for appetizers. The spicy negi gohan is basically spicy yellowtail fish with mayo and green onions over rice. So simply, but also so amazing! We also loved the tonkatsu sticks. Just think of fishsticks, but instead TONKATSU. Dipping sauce is the great tonkatsu sauce too. Just so delicious! Super fatty pieces too.

They have Hitachino Beer on tap too for $9, which is fun. I've never really seen Hitachino beer on tap, so it was neat to see it. 

Service is always great - they are always very friendly and prompt. Can't go here every week, but it definitely hits the spot when I crave ramen.
author: Jocelyn L.

description:
It was tasty but not amazing ramen. Granted, I had the gluten free version.  Also had the fried garlic appetizer but it was really just ok; I mainly thought it was okay because I like garlic so much. The frying didn't add much flavor.

My main takeaway was that it just didn't seem that Japanese... most of the waiters were white and the experience felt pretty 2020 San Francisco. 

Don't think I'll come back on my own.
author: Tiffany C.

description: Table service is fast. Waiters are very friendly. In my opinion the food is good and you could also choose a larger size bowl -- which is very considerate for ppl with larger appetites.
author: Michael T.

description: Ramen was so-so, parking was bad, area was kinda sketch, and service wasn't bad until the very end. We declined dessert and after we paid the bill, the hostess came over and said, "We really need the table." No one was at the bar, no one was waiting in line, and there were no names on the waitlist. That was the rudest "get out" ever... All because we didn't want your homemade mochi balls. *eye roll*
author: Liana L.

description:
I am pretty down about not having as many ramen choices in Texas as there are in California.  Apparently, I need to coax some more Asians to become transplants. 

Orenchi Beyond was definitely the peak of my SF trip.  I've had ramen before but man, the broth here is tasty as F.  I ordered the original ramen and oh, that soft boiled egg melted my itty bitty heart.  Also who the hell doesn't love a little bit of nori on top with some crunchy bamboo to wrap everything up in a nice little bow. 

We got to Orenchi about 20 minutes before they opened and had no wait.  We were seated immediately.  They had a raffle going on for a $50 gift card which my friends and I regretted not entering into.  If you see a raffle, go for it.

Orenchi is definitely one of those places that leaves me salivating when I reminisce about it.  

I think I should just move to SF, with a very caucasian boyfriend.  Then no one will be able to tell that I'm not a native (sarcasm, LOTS of sarcasm).
author: Su L.

description: I like it! They have seasonal specials, like their own version of fandango noodles. Beyond ramen has no egg but has mizuna veggies (for u veggie lovers). The orenchi ramen has the egg.
author: -Young- T.

description: I got the Beyond ramen with an extra egg (since it doesn't come with one). It's quite tasty and the tonkotsu broth is rich and has a pleasant charred note to it. I do wish there was a little more green though - some thinly sliced scallion or more mitsuba and we're talking 5 stars.
author: Josh L.

description:
I always wanted to try Orenchi in South Bay, but living in Easy Bay, it's a bit difficult to get down there. One day, I was just walking around in the Mission and passed by this place and turns out this place is related to one in South Bay. I was really excited. I ordered the Shio Ramen, which is the one they serve that the South Bay location. The flavor of the broth was very rich. The egg was perfect! The price was pretty average for a bowl of ramen in SF. I would definitely come back if I'm in the area again.

Tip: Check in on Yelp for an extra topping. Get the egg. It's the most expensive topping you can get ;)
author: Jamie N.

description:
Sometimes when I want to go somewhere, but don't have friends to go with me, I just go myself. This was one of those places where I've heard there's an extremely long line and decided to go myself. I went on the earlier side (around 6) and was offered a spot at the bar. Often when I go places myself, I can get seated quickly and get my grub on. 

I ended up ordering the Beyond Ramen - pork belly, green onion, bamboo shoots, dried seaweed, and I added an egg since I do love an egg in my ramen. The egg was a bit overcooked when I got to eating it. I prefer my eggs a bit runny still. Otherwise, everything else was great! I enjoyed it and savored every bite. 

I did notice that quite a people came by so the wait later can get to be about an hour or so (and they have reservations online). 

Protip: show up early or make a reservation for some good ramen.
author: Nina Y.

description: I was finally able to try Orenchi Beyond when they first opened for Saturday lunch.  This place did not disappoint. The ramen noodles were al dente.  The broth was great and didn't leave me feeling heavy.  They also had a great selection of appetizers and I highly recommend the takoyaki.  If you love ramen and live in SF, this is a must try.
author: Andrew S.

description: World class ramen. Broth was complex and true to traditional ramen, noodles were perfectly cooked and portioned, not drowning in toppings, with a soft boiled, soy cured egg. 10/10 would eat everyday.
author: Alexa W.

description: This is my go to spot when I eat ramen! Their broth is the best. I love the chicken karaage, so juicy and crispy. It's really cool and hip and the service is always great! This is my happy place :)
author: Michelle A.

description: Orenchi has some great ramen but nothing that really amazed me...we had their two most popular bowls along with their salad, gyoza and a yellowfin roll..the salad was by far the worst value at $10.50 with simply leaves and an abundance of salty miso dressing. The noodles were however spot on and some of the best I've had in SF; broth gets a B+...tasty but not amazing. Very casual atmosphere and pretty good service overall
author: Steven L.

description:
Spontaneously dropped in for dinner on a random weekday without a wait. Perf cus I hate lining up for food. Service was lovely and friendly, and you can see the chef cooking fresh noodles at the ramen station in the clear glass kitchen, which is always nice. We ordered:

- Orenchi ramen: creamy, savoury broth, ramen al dente & topped with poached egg - can't go wrong, probably one of the better ramens in the city
- Stewed pork & rice: yummy, rich stewed pork on chewy, perfectly-cooked rice, also topped w/ a poached egg

Food came quickly and was on point - rich, filling & satisfying - was pleasantly surprised at how casual and relaxed the ambiance was, considering it's on bougie Valencia. Overall, real solid dinner spot and will totally be back!
author: Anna H.

description:
Good fast ramen place on a cold day. It's not up to par to the best places in SF (eg. ramen underground , Izakaya Sozai, Izakaya rintaro) or some of the best ramen places in New York (eg. Totto Ramen) but a solid place to stop by if you are in the area. 

I had the ramen with soy sauce based pork broth and pork slices. It's solid with good flavors. The salt based version is pretty good but would have preferred a bit more saltier version with more umami. 

I like the high ceiling of this place. Skip the edamame appetizer - not special!
author: Rebecca C.

description: Damn this is good. Wandered in after an event at Public Works and had a great meal. I mean it was spectacular. Highly recommended.
author: Jack D.

description:
This place serves spaghetti instead of Ramen noodles. The ingredients they use are suspect across the board and badly prepared. 

The Dykon salad is just giant chunks of radish tossed in a bowl instead of thin sliced. The meat is all fat and grade D at best. 

Good luck.
author: Brian K.

description:
Another morning hungover. Need ramen.

I walk in and I immediately feel the openness of the space. Very high ceilings and lot's of light coming from windows of the entrance and the ceiling. Modern decor is cool and hip and makes it a little different from a traditional themed Japanese restaurant.  

Orenchi has ample options other than ramen including salads, sushi and other Japanese side dishes. If you're not just looking for ramen, this would be a good spot for you.

I got the Orenchi Beyond ($12): pork-based broth with thick wavy noodles, bamboo shoots, scallion, garlic, a piece of seaweed and a dash of dark soy sauce. The broth is creamy and has some depth but was lacking compared to other ramens I've had. The soy and saltiness was slightly too pronounced over the other elements of the broth. 

Decent ramen but I wasn't a fan of the broth or the thickness of the noodles. I can't speak to the other various things on the menu. Staff was friendly!
author: Kyle R.

description: The ramen broth is so salty my throat hurt after eating  my friend and I ordered the Orenchi Ramen which is shio based. The noodles were too al dente but the eggs were good. Gooey orange yolks were on point. Not sure why this place is so popular but it's pretty mediocre and since I spent hours recovering from that salt overload, I will not be back.
author: Ace C.

description:
Update to the previous review.. now they have a delicious vegan miso ramen.. and .. And.. the noodles they use for this are gluten free! My celiac friends and gluten sensitive buddies would understand how good that is! It is Delicious ! 



Been here almost every week for the past few months we've lived in SF. We've tried multiple ramen places around mission and some parts of the city but this is by far the best.  Husband loves the beyond ramen.. my fav is the orenchi. Great ramen and yes the latest vegan ramen is surprisingly good too! Awesome service everytime. No complaints. Outdoor seating has nice heating if you choose that.
author: Shital R.

description:
Thank you Orenchi Beyond for coming to San Francisco. Thank you for bringing your delicious ramen all the way from South Bay up to the city. Now, if Chick-fil-A would follow suit, I would never need to drive south again.

I actually prefer Orenchi Beyond to the original Orenchi but only because the wait I've become accustomed to in Santa Clara is nonexistent in San Francisco. Hold up. What? Awesome ramen AND no wait? What a perfect combination.

The ramen itself is great. There actually aren't many choices which isn't a bad thing. I've had the Beyond Ramen, Orenchi Ramen, and the Tori Soba.

If you're feeling something "light" I would recommend the buckwheat Tori Soba with its clear broth. It's not as rich and still quite enjoyable.

However, if you're looking for real ramen, I'd go with the Orenchi Ramen. You might be tempted to go with the Beyond Ramen since it's unique to this location, but the main difference is that with the Orenchi Ramen, you get a soft boiled seasoned egg. Fortunately, both bowls include their incredibly tender pork belly.

At the end of the day, the most "wow" bowl of ramen you'll have in San Francisco is probably at Izakaya Sozai in Inner Sunset. However, the wait there can get ridiculous and at the end of that ramen bowl, the flavor gets to be too much and becomes a bit too salty. On the contrary, Orenchi Beyond has little to no wait and the ramen is satisfying to the very last bite.
author: Charles L.

description:
So, this place was on a list of things to try in S.F.  A friend and I were trying to complete the list sometime in this lifetime.  

I have to say I do love ramen and I like trying out new places.  We had the Beyond Ramen.   And it was a bit different that what I'm used to... maybe it was just this dish but I wasn't THAT impressed.  It was good, but I wouldn't rave about it.  

It was a different take, especially with the noodles, they were a bit thicker like chow mien noodles (traditional style).  As I am a fan of more of the thinner egg noodles.  I did enjoy the broth a lot, but when you got down to the bottom, it got really salty so I stopped (which was probably a good thing)

The service was really good and you could actually see them cook the dishes which was really fun to see.  It's kind of hard to see when you walk there, I passed by it when walking there.  For some reason I thought it was a small craft brewery spot.  The venue itself was really cool, as well as the seating, for SF it was an actually large place.  It looked like a garage before it became a restaraunt.

The heat lamps on the outside were a nice touch, cuz you know, its f**king cold in San Francisco.
author: Cliff S.

description: They open exactly at 6pm. The interior is clean, sleak and modern with a bar immediately to the right of the entrance at an open kitchen at the far end. The ramen noodles seem hand-made and have great texture. The soup is rich and delicious. Additional toppings are also available upon request for an additional fee. Not only are the ramen worth a visit, the various items serving as appetizers or izakaya, depending on your definition, is amazing. The fried oysters are moist, salty and flavorful, accompanied by a diced onion mayonnaise medley. The tofu was soft with just the right amount of soy sauce and a crispy outer layer. There is also an ample selection of sake and other alcoholic beverages available.
author: Kimberly H.

description: Drove by this place on a cold rainy day and decided to stop for dinner. We order the beyond remen and a spicy tuna gohan bowl. One of the best remen i've ever had! Staff was very nice and friendly. Great place!
author: Lyneth G.

description:
Solid ramen spot. Bar is open to the outside, so if you're waiting for a reservation life is that much better. The interior space is really well done and they play pretty entertaining K-pop music videos in the background.

Definitely try the ramen and the salmon wasabi appetizers.
author: E F.

description: Delicious meal, I highly recommend this place. I ordered the Beyond Ramen, the broth was salty and luscious, the pork was tender, and the noodles nicely chewy. I also had the chicken karaage, which was crispy and juicy with a nice little side salad. The  space is cool with great music and the service was prompt, professional, and friendly!
author: tania t.

description:
I've been on a ramen kick recently. I've been visiting places like Hinodeya and Mensho. So naturally, I had to try Orenchi. Compared to the other 2 places, Orenchi is ok. It's good, but there are definitely better ramen places in the city. I really like that they take reservations. 

I got the Beyond ramen and an order of the chicken karaage. They were good, but not mind blowing.
author: Carolyn Z.

description: Didn't even get stay!  I had a 6 pm reservation, I was 10 minutes early and instead of allowing me to sit while they clean the patio, they said "We have 10 minutes." I guess hospitality isn't necessary...
author: Ilicia Maxine R.

description:
Orenchi is one of those ramen restaurants you must try, at least in the South Bay. I remember when they just opened this location in SF and its always been in the back of my mind to try it out after going to the Santa Clara location plenty of times. With all the other ramen shops opening in the city, this place doesn't seem as popular as it used to. In any case, it's good to know they accept reservations because their location in Santa Clara doesn't allow it and I've had to wait almost 2 hours once.... :(

My friend and I were the first ones to show up at the restaurant around 6pm. The feeling in here is a little different in that it almost felt like a hipster ramen shop and not like their original location. We got seated immediately and we were deciding on what to order, either the usual Orenchi ramen or the tsukemen which they only can make 15 bowls of every evening. I've always been curious about the tsukemen as I've seen it advertised at the other location but never got there early enough to try, so we both got it. For $17, I felt the portions were pretty big. They gave a lot of noodles and the broth was super flavorful and thick. I sorta found some of the stuff they put as the toppings a little random but otherwise, it was good. I think next time I'll try their bowls of soup noodle instead to really compare if there's a difference!
author: Kathleen S.

description:
For $13 with no additional toppings, I expected the bowl of ramen to blow my socks off. Unfortunately, it was a lackluster experience.

Started off with the Nankotsu Karaage which is battered fried chicken cartilage. Its served with cherry tomatoes, shishito pepper and lemon. The batter was delicious and crispy, very colorful presentation. Who knew chicken cartilage was so tasty!

I ordered the Orenchi Beyond which came in a Tonkotsu pork based soup. Standard toppings included pork belly, soft boiled seasoned egg, green onion, bamboo shoot, mushroom, sesame, and a piece of dried seaweed. Soup was flat in flavor, I had to add a spoonful of garlic paste which they had as a condiment on the table next to the spicy powder. The noodles were smooth on the outside, but doughy on the inside, tasted a bit undercooked.

The highlight was the perfectly cooked soft boiled egg. That was the only thing that impressed me. It was seasoned well, the yolk was golden and runny, the white was smooth and cooked to a flawless consistency. 

The restaurant is bright, clean and inviting. Service was good during lunch, though we came right when they opened at 11:30 am.
author: Janny S.

description:
Loooveeee the decor in this place. I also like the hooks at the table to put your belongings. Owners must have had it well thought out.

We ordered the Orenchi Ramen, Beyond Ramen, Tako Wasabi, and Geso Karaage. It was sooo yummy!

[+] Flavors were on point for all the food.
[+] Great ambiance, servers make you feel welcome and checks on you.
[+] Clear menu
[+] Decor was so cute! Love the windows. Also love how the kitchen is see through so you can see the kitchen staff work their magic. That's how ramen joints should be.
[+] The egg inside the ramen was sooooo good! Cooked perfectly! (Egg porn game strong)

[-] A little on the pricier side.
[-] They do charge you $2.5 per tea per person, but it is Lupicia tea, it was so yummy. Wish we were notified that when we ordered. 
[-] Parking can be difficult, there are two hr parkings and meter parking but it is located on Valencia and it was a little hard to find the restaurant since it is under the freeway with trees blocking. Also, not the greatest neighborhood either.

But I will still come back time after time! It is sooo yummy!!!
author: Tammy F.

description: If you want to avoid the Orenchi Ramen crowd like Santa Clara... this is the best alternative to be. The Beyond Ramen is a must!
author: Ethan P.

description: Excellent ramen spot. Always went to the Santa Clara location but the SF spot has been my go to. Shoyu is fantastic..and that egg...OMG..H.E.A.V.E.N!!!
author: RS Y.

description: I was excited to try this one in my quest for ramen that's as good as Izakaya Sozai but not quite so far out but my high hopes were disappointed. Their tonkatsu broth was too salty for my taste and not quite rich enough. Cured egg was too cold. Noodles were fine and the single piece of chashu was good. Maybe they had an off night? Service was nice otherwise I'd bump it down to 3 stars.
author: Yana Y.

description: Yummy ramen and yummy flavors. Waitress was so cute and little and nice! Had a reservation and everything was pleasant.
author: Helen N.

description: Better than average. Not the best I've had. A unique flavor. The presentation and atmosphere is a bit too precious for me, and so is the price.
author: Anthony B.

description:
Solid ramen place with a nice, modern atmosphere. You get one big slice of meat with the ramen though, and doesn't seem like a generous meat portion.

I added an egg and it was much better.
author: Ke D.

description:
Black Pork Gyoza (mid west, if anything Iowa'n)
- handmade for sure

The Tori Soba passed the "I ordered right" tests.
- going to try the Beyond ramen next time

Give the Mio Sake a shot, no pun intended. The sip redefines sparkling wine, and tunes the mind to the vibe: "I understand why Europeans enjoy their spritz's".

Above all else, the only true bias here is I came early and the place was not busy at all - applied to all my cases of my Yelp reviews. Wisdom has taught me, why compete with the herd when you can beat the herd and reap the culinary benefits before the ensuing madness that will be thrown upon the staff.
author: Edward L.

description:
Unlike so many of the new, interesting restaurants in the city, this place actually takes reservations. Which means now that I have seen how good their food is, I'll definitely be back there. So many other restaurants are good but it's such a turn-off to have to wait in line that I never go more than once.

We tried the orenchi and the beyond ramens, the hamachi appetizer, daikon salad, and chef's special tempura fish. We also had both the draft sake and the specially-make, house-brand sake. Everything was good.

The hamachi is served carpaccio-style as thin slices with a vinaigrette, edible flowers, and a side of wasabi. It is *not* served with soy sauce, which at first I raised an eyebrow to, but once I tried the dish with wasabi only, I could see why. It didn't need soy; that would have hidden the flavors and it was balanced without it.

The daikon salad came with bonito flakes that gave it a nice smokiness, it was really pleasant and refreshing. My wife had the good idea to save some of it to eat alongside the ramen and it made a nice compliment that way.

The battered fish was perhaps the least novel, but it was still tasty, and it came with wasabi salt for dipping.

Some of the other reviews complain of weak ramen broth but that wasn't our experience. It was rich and flavorful. And the tables all have little bowls of garlic puree available if you need some extra oomph. We added a dollop and it was great. The noodles were perfectly chewy and all the fixings were fresh and nicely prepared. I honestly don't know what you could do to improve on something like that.

Of the sakes, we preferred the draft, which was both cheaper and more strongly flavored. The house-special sake was milder, which some people might prefer, but for us the draft was the better choice.
author: Aaron G.

description: The ramen was fine, a bit on the salty side. We also had the tuna avocado and spicy karage (which were chicken wings) and those were also just ok. The price was reasonable by SF standards though.
author: Hong T.

description: This is a really great Ramen house if you are looking for a quick bite. The waiters are very attentive and friendly and the ambience is very Japanese themed as well. Whenever I visit there's always a Japanese anime movie playing in the background which is very fun. The food is good, however not mind blowing. The price is very affordable but you definitely pay for what you get. The meat portions are very small and bowls pretty small as well. If you're in the neighborhood and have a hankering for some soup, give this place a shot. I would not recommend as a super great Ramen house but it definitely satisfies your craving
author: Michelle K.

description: We ate here and we found four blue rubber bands in our dish. Poor quality control. It was too bad because it was one of our favorite places.
