author: Shawn F.

description: Delicious ramen! The broth is complex and savory for both the Orenchi (perfectly balanced) and the Beyond (much bolder and more complex). The seasoned soft boiled egg is the best that I've seen around, they don't hard boil them! It's like a pop of heaven! The karaage was delicious. Made reservations which were super easy through Yelp. Would definitely go here again.
author: Jaime G.

description:
One of my favorite ramen in town (well, I don't usually eat ramen) but this one is a nice catch!!

I ordered the chicken karagee and their "Beyond" ramen, it includes with the tonkotsu based ramen, noodle, pork belly, green onion, bamboo shoots, dried seaweed, dried garlic and mizuna. I added extra egg which costs $15 (if I'm not mistaken)

I feel like their broth is different compared to the one in Santa Clara (also, they actually have the exact ORENCHI ramen like in SC.) Their BEYOND broth is very rich if you like rich soup, you MUST visit this place!
author: Illusio Melani L.

description: Soooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooo freaaaaaaaakig gooooooooddddd!!! :P ordered the Beyond Ramen with spicy miso and it was realllly good. Some places say their levels of spicy is really spicy but it doesn't deliver. Orenchi Beyond had the right amount of spicy for you all people who love that kind of stuff. Super tasty broth, nice consistency of noodles and pork melted in your mouth.
author: Ana G.

description:
My partner and I often walk by in front of Orench Beyond. But until they started vegan ramen recently, we couldn't go eat there because my partner is vegetarian.

We've been twice so far. We are happy about their ramen and service. Plus, we didn't have to wait for dinner for weekend because we were ok to eat at a bar.

I tried Tan Tan Men and Beyond ramen, and I liked them a lot. Takoyaki and Karaage were good too. My partner is happy with vegan ramen.

I can't wait to try other ramen and other dishes!
author: Akiko O.

description:
When Jamie W. and I were coming back to the city from a weekend in Monterey, I stopped by the original Santa Clara location of Orenchi only to see a crowd of twenty-something Asians waiting for tables and busily texting each other in front of the modest strip mall storefront. One look and Jamie refused to wait for a bowl of ramen there, perhaps flashing back to the disastrous Ramen Yokocho Festival where three-hour waits were the norm. We ended up going to the nearly L&L Hawaiian Barbecue and I got indigestion from the worst bowl of saimin ever served to mankind. That lapse only whet my appetite even more when Kuniko Ozawa decided to open a location in San Francisco late last year.

I heard about ridiculous lines when it opened, so I didn't even think about going there until recently when I got off work early and bolted over here. I shouldn't have bothered since they don't open until 6PM where I had nothing to do but sign my name on the sheet and sit on the boulder in front since it was raining. People would walk by and ask me when it was opening. Do I look like I work here or something? OK, maybe I do but still... Anyhow, when the young server did open the front door, she pointed me to the counter which only made sense since it probably took about fifteen minutes for the place to fill up. I perused the menu and noticed they serve only two ramen bowls and two soba bowls. Most of the toppings were extra though I didn't even think strategically about the composition of my order.

However, before having the ramen, I thought an appetizer was in order, so I went with the $7 Ankimo Ponzu since I've been a sucker for monkfish liver ever since I had mounds of it at the just-closed Ino Sushi. There were only four slices in this order, and they were topped with tobiko and nestled on a bed of chopped green onion marinated in ponzu (photo: http://bit.ly/1gFsBXu). It was delicious, of course, but it was also gone in about three minutes flat no matter how hard I tried to look like a sushi connoisseur. My ramen of choice turned out to be the $12 Orenchi Beyond since I figured I should go with the namesake bowl. I passed by the bubbling vats of full-bodied broth through the window when I passed by from the men's room.

I just presumed that was the tonkotsu ambrosia that I heard was the talk of the ramen aficionados (photo: http://bit.ly/1V4WsGt). When it arrived, I have to admit the broth was superb, very thick and flavorful without being obnoxious. It came with the bare minimum ingredients - al dente ramen noodles, one slice of pork belly (which to quote Amy Schumer, is like taking one Advil...why?), a bamboo shoot, fried garlic, a smattering of green onion and mizuna with a decorative square of nori (photo: http://bit.ly/1Lr3K6x). The server suggested I add an egg for $1.20, but what I really wanted was the $5.30 Mega Cha-Shu which would have added six slices of roast pork.

I learned my lesson that a true bowl is closer to $20, but still, it was quite tasty and worth savoring every drop of that broth. It was a good thing I added a $6.50 order of the Nankotsu Karaage which they billed graphically as 'chicken cartilage' (photo: http://bit.ly/1V4Wfmx). Remember that I'm the guy that orders the fried chicken gizzards at Harold's Fried Chicken on the South Side of Chicago. There aren't many of us around that enjoy the chew of good cartilage, and as it turned out, it was a suitable substitute for all the missing pork. Believe it or not, I was tempted to get a $4.20 bowl of Shishito Age as I saw the blistered padron peppers pass by, but I held back for a change. Tasty stuff. Worth the hype? I'll let you know after my next visit.

FOOD - 4 stars...a richly luxuriant tonkotsu broth stands out here and the rest was pretty good, too
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...an open modern space that crowds quickly like a Tokyo subway car
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...emphasis on efficiency doesn't leave much room for a personal touch, come at 6PM sharp if you don't want to wait
TOTAL - 4 stars...nice to know that a half-day trek to Santa Clara won't be necessary anymore
author: Ed U.

description:
Went there on Saturday night with a group of 4. Definitely make a reservation!! There were people that were waiting when we sat down that were still waiting when we left LOL. 

They have two options for ramen: Beyond (Shoyu base) and Orenchi (Shio base). My entire table got the Beyond ramen so I didn't get to try the Orenchi, although based on Yelp reviews the Beyond is better. It was $13 for a normal size bowl which comes with a decent portion of noodles, one slice of meat, one sheet (??) of seaweed, green onions, and bamboo shoots. You have the option to add egg/noodles/other toppings. It's a little pricey for what you get but it's SF so no surprises here. 

The broth is super flavorful without being too oily/heavy/thick, and the noodles are SO GOOD. They're thicker than the usual ramen noodles but they're also chewier which is nice. I didn't get an egg but my friend did and he said it was amazing, so it might be worth the extra $1.50. Our table also got two appetizers to share: Geso Karaage (Squid Tentacle Calamari) and some Avocado/Tuna/Wasabi thing. They were both really good but I liked the karaage better!

Overall would definitely come again but either in an off time (if that exists) or with a reservation.
author: Melissa H.

description: This place is so good! I had the Tori soba which is the salt based soup and it was the broth had the perfect hint of citron. We also had the salmon, takoyaki, and fried chicken as an appetizer which were all also really good. I liked the takoyaki the best since I'm a huge fan of octopus. The tonkatsu based soup of the beyond ramen was also phenomenal. Will definitely be back the next time I'm on the west coast!
author: Rachel E.

description:
I'm a fan of Orenchi in Santa Clara, and now I'm a fan of Orenchi Beyond!  There was no wait for lunch on a weekday.  I really like the decor and ambiance too.  We both got the Beyond Ramen and were satisfied with our choice.  The staff was really nice and we had a great meal. 

YUM.
author: Lyn C.

description:
Orenchi beyond located in the end of the mission district on Valencia where it's less crowded.  
simple menu with a few options of ramen.  Got the Beyond ramen which is a tonkatsu pork stock that is rich and flavorful, topped with pork belly, green onion, bamboo, seaweed and dried garlic.  I did not add the egg, which I shouldve.  Actually, it shouldve came with an egg! No ramen is complete without that egg! 

slurp it, drink it, inhale the porky goodness.  they do take reservations, so if you dont wana wait, call in.
author: Linda T.

description:
Though London is blessed with many ramen restaurants these days, I still think the ones in the USA still just shade it for quality

One of my favourites in the Bay Area is Orenchi and I was excited to find that they had opened a branch in the city, meaning no need to go to South Bay for my fix of Orenchi. Located at the northern end of Valencia in the Mission, it has a funky shopfront and a much smaller menu. However, at lunchtime on a weekday, there was no line at opening time, unlike the restaurant in South Bay, which seemingly always has a line

Having read mixed reports about the new ramen only available at this branch, I played safe with the original version. Now, it's odd because I did like it but it didn't seem as good as at the original location. Not sure why

We also shared a couple of starters, which were again good rather than great

I wanted to love it but Orenchi Beyond needs to get a few lessons from its older sibling
author: Yee Gan O.

description:
After a long hard day (of wine tasting), we were looking for some comfort food. Ramen seemed like the perfect choice. It was later in the evening and we didn't want to stand in a crazy line like at Mensho and decided to try our luck at Orenchi Beyond. We ended up only waiting about 10 minutes to get seated.

He got the Orenchi Ramen (shio base) and I ordered the Beyond Ramen (shoyu base). We both agreed that the Beyond Ramen had better flavor. I ordered a soft-boiled egg for my ramen and I'm still not sure why it's extra for the Beyond but comes standard with Orenchi ramen. Although the egg had the right consistency, it was on the bland side.

It was not the best ramen I've ever had but it did hit the spot on a cold evening.
author: Yi Z.

description: Noodles were al dente, great.  Broth was thick.  Took the orenchi soecial.  Great service.  Strange to sit on wooden stumps.   Lots of choices besides noodles.  Loved the purse hook beneath the table.  Very fast service.  Lots of drinking choices.
author: Helen L.

description:
Ramen was ok. Other options are better worth trying. 

Terrible service. Gratuity is included in the check FYI. Didn't realize this until the next day. When I called them today to correct this, they refused to help and told me to call my credit card company to reverse it. When I suggested they not ask for tip on checks that have tip included, the manager only replied with "it's on our menu"...not cool buddy.
author: Jeff S.

description: Superb ramen, great apps, and surprisingly deep (is pricey) beer selection. This is not the closest ramen to my office, but I shlep here when I want the good stuff. The noodles have just the right textures and are slimy in exactly the way ramen noodles should be. Tonkatsu broth doesn't mess around and is properly fatty and delicious. The spicy miso definitely kicks up the salt content, which is already high, but authentically so. Try the tuna katsu appetizer, I liked it more than I thought I would. Enjoy!
author: Jeremy Y.

description: This is my 4th time going to Orenchi Beyond for the past year az I have been travelling to SF quite a lot.  Everytime was excellent, and I had thr Orenchi Ramen with extra 1 piece of Cha Siu and regular spicy miso. Overall it was a very good ramen,  however,  the cha siu slices are so thin that 2 slices is not equals to 1 slice of other good ramen places in SF. Please keep the quality and be consistent
author: Lawrence L.

description:
Never been to the original Orenchi, but always wanted to!  Apparently Orenchi Beyond can't compare to the O.G. in the South Bay.  We got there before 12:30 on a Friday and there was a little bit of a wait.  Finally got seated about 10-15 minutes later.  There's only two choices for ramen and both are tonkatsu based, we got one of each to be the judge.  

Service was a little bit slow initially due to being so busy.  They accidentally made a large size bowl for me (didn't charge) of my Orenchi ramen.  He got the beyond ramen.  Only difference seemed that in exchange for an extra pork slice (his said belly but looked the same as my Cha su) was that they mixed an egg, his broth was more peppery though.  Both broths were Tonkatsu based.  My egg was overcooked and his that he had to pay extra for was perfectly runny.  Noodles were fine.  Both were very fatty/greasy as well.  So fatty that my stomach hurt pretty soon after throughout the day into the night until I was able to drink tea at home.  

This place is so overhyped.  They spent all of their focus making it look trendy and playing cool music that they forgot about the food.  I've been to mediocre ramen places that served up better ramens.  For $12+ for a bowl of ramen I expect more than just a few ingredients, more than just one piece of pork, and included no egg in one of them, and not a severe tummy ache either!  Orenchi Beyond is definitely subpar.
author: Cat C.

description:
Wings - 2/5
Takoyaki - 4/5 - One of the best takoyaki that I've had in SF.
Karaage - 3/5
Roasted garlic - 3/5
Beyond ramen - 4/5 - Very fatty, almost like a kotteri. Egg was just right. Pork had good flavor, very thin sliced, had to order that largest pork add on to get the right amount.

Overall, "I'm a fan."
author: Mark O.

description: Came here on a hot (90+F) day with my husband and 3-month old baby so there was no wait. The staff was extremely accommodating, making sure we were well taken care of. Ramen and apps were delicious and we loved the desserts as well! Definitely will visit again next time we are in SF!
author: Judith S.

description:
Biggest game changer is they take reservations. Instead of waiting an hour in the cold like their Santa Clara location, you just waltz right in and sit down. 5 stars for that alone!

Orenchi Ramen with a Tonkotsu is the way to go and order an extra egg because you are beautiful and deserve it! Pair it with the Ozeno Yukidoke IPA and you've got everything you need.  Their regular bowls I think are perfectly portioned but if you're a big dude, you should upgrade to a large bowl.
author: James Y.

description: Good, not amazing.  I'll come back with some non-vegetarians so I can get the full concept of this spot.
author: Jason T.

description: I was so excited to learn that orenchi had another location. I've always loved the one in Santa Clara, but the wait was always ridiculously long. My bf and I came here on a Friday night a little after they opened and we didn't have a wait at all. It's a small place, but there were still tables open when we got there. We ordered the orenchi ramen, squid balls, and fried chicken -- there are other names for them, but I can't remember right now. Everything was super tasty. The orenchi ramen was almost the same as in Santa Clara. Only downside was that they weren't able to make our ramens spicy and even with the chilly oil and additional peppers and spices, it lacked a little something. Our waiter did mentioned that the spicy option is coming soon! Yaaay! Overall, everything was still delicious, my soft boiled egg was on point, and I ended up killing everything and leaving very satisfied. The customer service was also really good. I can't wait to come back!
author: Jenn N.

description: I was a visitor and assumed the ramen would be better in SF than back home. In reality this would have been my second least favorite bac home. The noodles were straight up spaghetti and the broth was straight up cup o' soup. My girlfriend had to brush her teeth to get the taste of the vegan ramen (basically old tomato soup with added ingredients) out of her mouth and then had an MSG type reaction. As a result, ramen in general is now off the menu for us for a while. All in all: Extremely unpleasant.
author: Keith B.

description:
Orenchi Beyond is one of my new favorite Ramen spots. Good price, good sake and a fun, relaxing environment. 

Like most ramen spots there is likely going to be a wait. If it's cold out Orenchi has heat lamps set up in the outdoor waiting area for your warmth and comfort. Not only that, but bar access faces the street with an open bar window, so you can easily order your drink while waiting for seating.
author: Alexa H.

description: Love that this place has vegan ramen!! Add some togarashi and garlic purée (both on the table) and you're good to go. Cool tables and wall art, too!
author: D. B.

description:
I've heard amazing things about Orenchi ramen in Santa Clara, so I was excited to try Orenchi Beyond. The decor and storefront look really nice and hipster, with a bar opening towards the front and heated lamps so patrons can have a drink and stay warm during the anticipated wait. 

I was baffled at how much empty space they have inside the bar area (where the waiters are). I haven't seen such a spacious bar area in a restaurant that is supposedly expecting a lot of visitors. Also, the tables are pretty low (if you're not sitting at the bar, that is) and the chairs are upside down buckets! Pretty cute design, but not that functional haha.

I tried the Beyond (shoyu) ramen and a little bit of the shio ramen. The broth for the Beyond ramen is very flavourful and the shio one is less meaty. The ramen itself was pretty decent, but beware that if you don't add extra meat, there is only ONE slice of meat in the bowl, so don't go looking around for more in your bowl. You can add extra meat for some amount of money.

They did have this amazing price for the chashu rice - $3.20 for the chashu rice, and a regular bowl of rice is already $3! Not sure if this is a limited time promotion though.
author: Theresa L.

description:
Very authentic and good foods!
I am not a big fan of ramen usually, so this was the first experience for me to go a ramen restaurant in US. Once I arrived in the front of the restaurant, I was amazed at the nice design of the exterior and interior of the restaurant. Outside of the restaurant, there was a bar counter. Inside was also authentic.

My boyfriend and I shared Karaage and bambamji salad as appetizers. The ramens we took were Beyond ramen and Orenchi ramen. Karaage was very good, the chicken were juicy and crispy. It was the same taste that I had in Japan. The bambamji salad was ok, actually it was not a salad but a shreded chicken breast. Beyond ramen is shoyu(soysauce) based taste, and Orenchi ramen was shio(salt) based taste. Both were very tasty. It depends on the preference but I prefer Orenchi ramen. The reason why I liked their ramen was the there were plenty oftopping ingredientsso that their ramen were pretty gorgeous. I'd be happy to visit again!
author: May T.

description: Decent ramen spot open pretty late at night, but portions are pretty disappointing for meat and noodles.
author: Chelsea W.

description: Delicious, thick broth.  Definitely one of my favorite spots, alongside Iza and Nojo. And I was happily surprised to see my bowl of ramen brought to me not long after ordering.
author: Jonathan C.

description:
Beyond the Great Beyond lies a ramen place
where it is said that their bowl of ramen is so enriched with tonkotsu goodness
that the gods themselves have to wait outside an hour before it opens
in order to guarantee that they will be one of the firsts to be called when the gates open.

Those who fail to do so are fated to suffer
an interminable banishment outside and tortuously observe (probably in seething anger) those fortunate few who are happily slurping away beautifully spun ramen inside.

whatever.

I like ramen but I ain't waiting two hours for the damn thing.
Forget that noise.

Is the ramen good?
Yeah, it's pretty good.  Clean rich broth, wonderfully cooked ramen, and a balance of supporting textures and flavors.

Did I have to wait two hours to get some of said ramen?
Hells no.
(Someone was kind enough to show up an hour before it opened and put his name down so our group would be guaranteed seating when it opened.  Shout out to Mr. Vanevery wherever you may be).

Would I go back?
Maybe.  The food easily merits a return trip but the surrounding trendiness that accompanies the experience makes me want to wait until some of the hype calms down.
author: Dan B.

description:
The 5 of us came here on a Friday night and sat down right away with no wait right before it started getting crowded. we sat at a center communal table. servers are all pretty japanese and also some japanese patrons here. good signs.

I was surprised that they only have 4 kinds of noodle, two of them ramen and the other two soba, on the menu since I thought of the Orenchi Ramen in south bay and did not notice this was Orenchi Beyond. Bummer. Was really looking forward to tsukemen. Four of us ordered the orenchi ramen $13 each. You cannot add noodle to it, but you can make it a large for an extra $1.80. 

Ramen was good. Noodles are thick and round. Al dente which i like. The chashu has been torched which is a nice touch. It doesn't look like much food but it is filling. especically when you see all the bits of pork fat floating around in your soup.

I also tried the ikura don, nankotsu karaage, and edamame. Everything was pretty good.

Pretty expensive though.
author: claudia y.

description:
Updated Review:
There is a new manager who reached out to me and educated me on their veggie/vegan options. Super nice and understanding. I will definitely come back to try again. 

Original Review:
I'm vegetarian, they wouldn't let me substitute pork for a vegetable. They wouldn't let me use their wifi.
author: Martin S.

description:
I have been waiting to try this place since it first opened. All of my friends were telling me this place is bomb and I just couldn't wait to try it for myself! The first time I came here, it was during its grand opening week and the wait was literally 2 hours. For ramen?! No thanks. So I waited to try this place out after the buzz died down. 

My friends and I came here on a Friday night around 6:30 and was so lucky to have gotten seated right away! I must say, the line started to form a few minutes after we were seated. The first thing I noticed was the decor! Such a pretty and hip ramen place! There's art on the walls and the seats are in the shape of wooden logs. So cute, two thumbs up for decoration! 

We ordered Takoyaki as an appetizer and it wasn't bad but Takoyaki isn't something I normally order. The consistency wasn't bad and it's some of the better Takoyaki I've tasted. Now onto the ramen. First off, it's about $13 per bowl. Quite expensive for any ramen in my opinion. They have orenchi and beyond basically one with egg and one with fried garlic. I went with the beyond ramen and overall it was alright. I was expecting so much more since the wait times were always so ridiculous but the broth was quite salty as mentioned in a couple of other reviews and the noodles were just ok. I actually prefer my noodles on the harder side and these didn't disappoint. Overall, I don't think I'd come here if the wait was more than 10 minutes. The ramen to me isn't worth longer than that wait time. Maybe I'll try the Orenchi one next time since I felt my ramen was lacking an egg.
author: Shelly W.

description:
I prefer Orenchi Santa Clara but this is a good second especially if you live in SF. I wouldn't wait in line to eat here. The only place I would wait in line to eat at in SF would be Waraku in japantown. Anyhow we came right when they opened on a Saturday morning. Since this place has been opened for some time I thought it wouldn't be very busy. We were seated immediately and I was even able to bring my stroller in and there was room to park it. 

We ordered....

The karage portion was large but not very flavorful or tasty. I remember the Santa Clara being more tasty. (3/5)

The beyond ramen was very garlicky which I liked but most would probably prefer less. It does become more one note about half way through. The noodles were chewy the way I like them but my husband thought the noodles has too much bite to them. (3/5)

Ikura with egg bowl was delicious! I'd prob come back just to eat that. (4/5)
author: Tiffany L.

description: Ad far as vegetarian/vegan ramen goes, Orenchi Beyond had one of the most flavorful and delicious broths I've ever had. Vegetables in the ramen were fine, though I would have enjoyed it more if they had more tofu or veggie protein options. I would love to come back again!
author: Brittany K.

description: Favorite ramen in SF! Less crowded than Santa Clara and mellower vibe. I always get the salmon ikura gohan, 6 piece karage and the tori soba (for a lighter noodle option).
author: Alex N.

description: Haven't tried the ramen yet, but this Japanese spirit (iichiko)made from barley is very smooth. I had their beyond sour cocktail and it was refreshing. I also love the outdoor bar in the front of the building on Valencia. I'll be back to try the ramen. Thanks
author: Kyle L.

description:
Yeah, it's awesome.  They have two famous ramen bowls, both namesakes, I guess: the "Orenchi" and the "Beyond."  Both are great.  However, if you are going to go back and forth between the two, you will find that the Beyond bowl always tastes magically delicious, while the Orenchi bowl tastes a bit odd if you have it right after a faceful of the Beyond.

Enjoy!
author: Aaron M.

description:
Arrived 5 minutes after opening time and found myself in a middle of a big crowd already. Discouraging to put my name halfway down a page page at the bottom of a list of already waiting customers and went to stand by the open counters sadly ... until they caught my attention through the window and asked if id like to order appetizers and drinks! Didn't even know I could! 

We just started digging into the Chicken karaage and Takoyaki when counter seats opened. Pretty short wait overall. The chicken was so good. There are just a couple ramen options and they both have Tonkotsu broth. I had the Orenchi for the soft boiled egg. It's incredibly flavorful but I don't mind a little extra salt. Those more sensitive to it may find it overwhelming. Extra garlic is available on the tables too. It  was definitely one of the better ramen bowls I've had in SF.
author: Samantha L.

description:
#55 on my Ramen list (click on the Ramen List link above). 

Do you know why it's a long wait?? Because THEY WILL SKIP YOU for their friends, and be shady about it saying they were here first. 

That's right, caught you Orenchi Beyond.  

They will also say it's 20 minute wait but turn out to be 45 minutes wait.  My group of 4 had to get the counter because they gave our table to their friends that clearly came after us.  Rude.  I mean if you want to do that fine, but not on a busy Saturday night.  That's just inconsiderate to the group of people already waiting.  

Anyway, that's why they don't get more than 3 stars.  The ramen itself was pretty good and the egg was soft boiled, however the place itself is very expensive.  I liked the Beyond Ramen more than the Orenchi Ramen since it has fried garlic, so I added an extra egg, $1.50 extra so the ramen is $13.50.  And large sake is like $16. Pricey, esp since it doesn't even get you buzzed. But you're welcome to spend more on alcohol, which they do promote since the bar is also connected outside for those waiting for a table. 

OVERALL: Good hipster ramen joint for SF, but the shady service with the already long wait deterred me from really liking this place.  I'm glad I work in San Mateo where the better ramen is anyway ;)

-Ramen Sheriff
author: Raquel Y.

description:
Couple months new, this outpost sits pretty much underneath the freeway. Parking can be a challenge; I walked.

First ones there on a Wednesday... Sat at long communal table in center of smallish place.

The Orenchi ramen was ordered, large portion. Underwhelming for me. My egg was overcooked and the noodles didn't do it for me. Broth was on the salty side of what was an already salty baseline.

$12 for a not very large bowl of ramen!! At least give it to me perfect!! Or else I'm loathe to be a repeat customer. Luckily, the company saved the night.
author: Jana C.

description:
Meh. 

My friend and I started with the chicken karaage, which was hot and fresh from the fryer. The skin was crispy, the inside was pretty moist, and this was probably my favorite part of the meal. 

...But I judge ramen restaurants by their ramen, and despite the good appetizer, the ramen was very subpar.

I ordered the Orenchi Ramen. I found the broth to be really forgettable, as it was missing that tasty richness that a tonkotsu base should have. The bamboo shoots tasted odd like they came out of an old can, as did the mushrooms. Such a pity, because the ramen noodles themselves were cooked perfectly, as was the soft boiled egg, but the mediocre broth and other fillings kind of killed it.

With so many better options for ramen, I don't think I'll be back.
author: Sara L.

description: Vegetarian perspective here. I got the vegan miso ramen .Pretty good but I'm not a huge fan of miso-tomato base - it's different from other ramen restaurants but usually when I go for veggie ramen I want the standard vegetarian miso base to satisfy my craving and hug my stomach. I also found it a bit overpriced. For example, Izakaya Goku on 16th Street has $13 veggie ramen (regular miso  base) compared to Orenchi Beyonds $16 veggie ramen.
author: Mishika V.

description: Came in looking to satisfy my ramen craving. I have been to the Orenchi in San Jose and I remember really enjoying it. This location was okay, but nothing too amazing or memorable... I ordered the beyond ramen and I liked it. That being said I'd come back because it's convienent but I've had better.
author: Jenny E.

description:
Ramen with a hipster twist. How long did you think the wait was going to be? 

My entire adventure at this venue took 3 hours. Yup, 3 hours. Around 2 hours waiting for a group of 6 and about less than a hour to get our order. Bring fun company and time will fly.

The atmosphere was something to rave on. Beautiful interior design, an awesome wall painting, and the hip-hop music gave this establishment a breath of fresh air and a nice contemporary look and feel.

We had a mix-up with our appetizers, but the issue was quickly addressed by management and our server. 

The Spicy Chicken Wings were good, but it wasn't the best I've had. I wish the temperature was a bit warmer and the flavor a bit stronger. Overall, a decent appetizer I would feel hesitant ordering again. Felt like it was left out for awhile before it was served. As for the Spicy Fries, meh. Forgettable and not worth ordering again.

I ordered a Large Orenchi Ramen ($12.00 + $1.50) and was relatively content with the dish. The noodles were on point and yum. They were chewy. My favorite. The broth had a delicious and flavorful taste too. I had doubts at first, but after a few more spoonfuls, I was satisfied. You could tell it took a long time to make. 

The Chashu though.. was way too thin and definitely needed more work. I wasn't impressed and the flavor needed improvement. And there was barely any in my bowl! Guess the struggle is real for the economy if you have to pay over $13 bucks for a bowl of ramen with only one slice of chashu meat. Maybe I should have shelled over the extra $2 bucks. 

But the egg... let me tell you about the soft-boiled egg! It was mouthwatering delicious! Perfectly cooked and runny. Mhmmm. Perhaps the best part of the meal? I took a bite and soaked it back in the broth.. took it out... and let's just it was orgasmic. Then again, I was waiting over 2 hours for food. I might have just been famished and hungry. 

As far as service goes, this place was hit and miss. Sometimes the other servers were attentive, sometimes they weren't. We were fortunate enough and got a pretty awesome server named Rob. He gave us the rundown of the menu, fixed our orders and was an all-around excellent waiter. If management is reading this, this man definitely deserves a raise. He checked up on us quite frequently and dang, this guy took a pretty rad selfie for our group! 

Overall, this place served up a relatively decent ramen bowl. However, the wait time does not justify the dish and I wouldn't wait again.. especially during peak hours. Until next time, Orenchi Beyond!
author: Chinsin S.

description:
My usual dining companion (boyfriend and I) were getting over a cold, were starving after a day of hard work, and were ecstatic when we saw that Orenchi Beyond was open late (on weekends). We zoomed on over and easily found (free) metered parking on the street. 

Fair warning - the restaurant is a little hard to find since it's tucked about 5-7 feet away from the usual store front and curb, but once you do find it, it's hard to miss. We were greeted "irasshaimase" which means "welcome" in Japanese by all the workers including the chefs. Walking inside feels like you're walking into an art gallery - the ceilings are high, the kitchen has a glass encasing, and even the tables have Japanese themed art work on them. It's dimly lit but not so dark that you feel like you're entering a sketchy club. 

We were given menus and promptly ordered. They only have two types of ramen: 1) Orenchi $13 // Tonkotsu based soup // Toppings: Pork Belly, Soft Boiled Seasoned Egg, Green Onion, Bamboo Shoot, Mushroom, Sesame, Dried Seaweed

2) Beyond $13 // Tonkotsu based soup // Toppings: Pork Belly, Green Onion, Bamboo Shoot, Sesame, Dried Seaweed, Fried Garlic, Mizuna (http://www.orenchi-beyond.com/)

I personally had the beyond ramen and boyfriend ordered the orenchi ramen so we could sample both. My favorite between the two was the beyond ramen. For some reason, the broth seemed more flavorful compared to the orenchi. 

We also ordered the spicy karaage $8 and it wasn't your normal karaage either which is boneless bits of chicken and spice. No, these are actual chicken wings. I'd definitely pass on these - flavor is too strong and it was too sour for my liking.

All in all, a good place to add to your rotation of acceptable ramen places in the city. Definite plus that they are open even later on the weekends for us hard workers that work late into the evening.

Pro Tip: They allow you to modify a few things for your ramen -- how cooked or uncooked your noodles are and how salty your broth is.
author: Kathleene E.

description:
Orenchi Beyond and Orenchi (Santa Clara) are owned by the same company and they claimed to use the same recipe and ingredients .... but the soup tasted different.  Don't get me wrong -- they are both yummy and I like the ramen at both places.  However, if I have to pick one or the other, the one in Santa Clara is my pick.  So why the 5 stars?  The company was pretty awesome that night.  The chef came out to give us a special desert he made for the cute couple of the night -- I guess we took the prize!

And yes, they do have a vegetarian ramen dish -- they just started to offer it last week!
author: David L.

description: Excellent ramen! The Tan-Tan ramen is just the right amount of spice and the noodles are cooked perfectly. Also delicious was the shishito peppers - perfectly cooked and plentiful. The takoyaki is great, and always something we order. We've been to Orenchi down in Santa Clara, which is a much more stressful experience because it's so packed and crowded down there. Here at this SF location, the high ceilings and the fact that we could make a reservation via Yelp was super convenient. We didn't have to wait, unlike the SC location where it's usually a minimum of a 1.5 hour wait. Customer service was very friendly and efficient. Best kept secret for great ramen in the city!
author: C. H.

description: Great vibe, relaxed atmosphere and delicious ramen. The appetizers were good too, my favorites were the fried calamari and fried oysters. I actually like the beyond ramen more than orenchi ramen in but that may be a personal preference..  service was friendly and attentive :)
author: sandy h.

description:
I've been to this ramen spot twice now and have been meaning to leave a review. This is one of those places that is too good to not shout out! 

I was informed prior to going that this place gets busy but lucky me, each time I went I was seated almost right away with a smile! The first things I notice are how clean and well managed this place was. When business would pick up, it was apparent how incredibly efficient and kind the staff is. Everyone is met with exceptional service. 

The menu is short and sweet--limited options guarantee good quality!

Its a funky layout but in a cool kind of way. I like places that are different and have their own feel. 
I love that you can see what's going on in the kitchen and watch the head chef do his thing. 
Along with the great customer service, I appreciate the generous serving sizes. This is definitely place I think of when I crave ramen. If I lived in sf I would definitely go more often. This is a great place to take family and friends who enjoy ramen and sake  I'll definitely be going again.
author: Jillian L.

description: Soooooooooooooo delicious and authentic. We got the soy sauce shoyu ramen and it was one of the best ramen bowls ever in SF! We were also sitting next to a Japanese couple and they said it was the flavor of Japan, no joke
author: Tida M.

description:
A great alternative to the original Orenchi but the Beyond broth is not as good.

PARKING: Street parking.  We got lucky because we found a spot right in front but it's metered in some sections so pay attention to where you are parking.

ATMOSPHERE: It's more "open" than the original and has a bar-tokyo trendy japanese restaurant feel.  They have these cut outs where you can order beer and other drinks while waiting.  The rest of the wall looks like it's cut out but there is glass covering it so you don't freeze while eating inside.  You can also see the kitchen cooking the ramen with huge vats of the broth and noodles. 

The wait isn't that long because it's not super popular yet.  We came on a Friday night and for 4 of us waited about 30 minutes.  We could have gotten seated earlier if we were willing to sit at the bar.  They have a high bar that wraps around the restaurant and then low tables with wooden stumps that hurt your butt after a while.  One great thing is that they have purse hooks for you!

They play loud old school r&b and hip hop with other 70s pop etc.  It isn't super loud but it is ambiant.

FOOD: they have the typical appetizers, regular orenchi ramen and then their beyond ramen as well as soba.

BEYOND RAMEN: Tonkotsu broth (like the original) but infused with soy flavor.  It reminded me more of Halu's broth so not as creamy/porky but still good.  My mom said it was too salty but I thought it was perfect.  Also a good garlic flavor.   The noodles were harder and chewier than regular orenchi but still the same size.  I also feel like the egg wasn't as flavored.  

CHICKEN KARAAGE and CHICKEN WINGS: Chicken wings had a great sweet/salty seasoned sauce and was juicy.  Karaage was a little dry and burnt but still tasty and tasted like the original trench's karaage.

Overall - with less of a wait and if you're in SF it's a great alternative.  They offer the regular orenchi broth still for those that want to eat that instead of the beyond ramen.
author: Brittany T.

description:
First off, this place takes reservations!! What?!@ You say?  
Yes, a ramen place that takes reservations!
and YES, I highly recommend them

Despite how HUGE this place looks, there really isn't a ton of seating, but yes it's more than most ramen places.

IMO, food here is pretty solid!  We ordered the:
*     Orenchi Ramen :: it does not come with a egg!  You must and should order as a side!
*     Spicy Karaage :: good flavor, but difficult to eat (it's sauced up) you will need more napkins to truly enjoy. Your face will thank you for that.

Can't wait to come back and try the Spicy Miso Tsukemen and Karaage (no bones, should be easier to eat)!

Happy eating!
author: Tina F.

description: The ramen was tasty and al dente like I like it. No more Tan Tan ramen though. Nice staff will come again
author: Annie P.

description:
Comparing Orenchi Beyond to ramen in New York or Japan is like comparing your current boyfriend to your first love. You'll always long for the company that you thought was your one true love, but you feel like you have to settle for what is in front of you. Well, "settle" might not be the right word because your current boyfriend is probably freaking awesome too. 

Comparing Orenchi Beyond to the original Orenchi in Santa Clara is like comparing your current boyfriend to the last guy you were in love with. They're both awesome, but you definitely upgraded with the newer model.

Located in the Mission area, David C., Allen C., and I made the trip to Orenchi Beyond quite early (like 5pm early). They open at 6pm, but we wanted to be the first in line! Although there are tons of bars/lounges nearby, Marcus took care of us by supplying us with Sapporo ($18/pitcher). Time does fly by when you're drinking with good company. By 5:30pm, a crowd full of people eagerly waiting to try Orenchi Beyond formed. With 42 seats in the restaurant, you bet everyone wanted to be in the first wave!

- Karaage.. fried chicken ($7.80): they use dark meat (which I prefer) and it was quite delicious!
- Shishito Age.. fried green pepper ($4.20): first time trying this and it was interesting! Some were more sweet, and another kicked me in the mouth.
- Beyond Ramen ($12): add an egg for $1.20. Broth was flavorful, egg was orgasmic, and the noodles were what stole the show!

For a very busy dinner service, I was actually surprised that our servers were on top of their game! Food came at a timely manner, and our servers were polite, helpful, and fun to chat with. 

One of the big pluses of this location (vs the Santa Clara one) is the availability of alcohol. (And I think alcohol plays a big part when you are waiting 1+ hours for food.) If you don't want to drink at the bar, there are plenty of bars around the area. What does the Santa Clara location have? Oh yeah, a crappy grocery store next door. 

Would I wait more than an hour to dine here? Sober Christine says, "hell no". (But it's also because Sober Christine waits for no one!) But throw in two beers, then why not? :) Cheers to the best ramen joint in SF!
author: Christine S.

description: Service was good. I would recommend the Beyond Ramen. I will be back on my next trip to San Francisco!
author: David T.

description:
One small slice of pork in my ramen! Not even as big as what others got. The portion size itself was small, too.

This place deserves two stars, but I enjoyed the monkfish liver. 

$23 +tip  for ramen, monkfish liver, and a non-alcoholic beverage.
author: Angelica C.

description:
Finally there's a place in SF that serves tasty ramen. I came here around noon on Sunday and there was no wait! There isn't much offered here and I think that Orenchi tried to make up for that by having large fonts on the menu. 

I ordered an Orenchi ramen and Takoyaki to share. The Takoyaki (deep fried octopus balls) came with 6 balls in a creamy sauce. The appetizer looked better than it tasted. It was still good, but definitely not the best I've had. 

The orenchi ramen was had a really flavorful broth and came with pork, bamboo shots, mushroom, dried seaweed, green onions, toasted sesame seeds, and a seasoned soft boiled egg. The broth was on the salty end, but being a fan of sodium I didn't mind too much. The noodles were chewy just the way they should be. 

At the end of my meal, I was throughly satisfied. I'm glad to have a to-go ramen shop in SF now.
author: Melanie H.

description:
Came here on a Saturday night with a table of four.

They have a nice outdoor waiting area where you can gather with your dinner party and even order drinks from the bar while you wait. Outdoor heaters keep you warm as you wait.

My table of four waited about 30 mins, not too bad on a busy Saturday night in the city. However, my concern was for the waitresses, who were rather slow and clumsy about seating my party. A table had opened up, been cleaned, and was ready for our fat asses, but the waitress for some reason didn't seat anyone at the table for a solid ten minutes. I'm sure they were very busy, but we could have just seated ourselves.

My table ordered the most popular ramen dish on yelp. It did not disappoint! Broth was flavorful and overall quite satisfying. There was a live DJ playing music which was way too loud for my small party to enjoy a conversation. I was practically yelling just to speak to the person across from me. 

Food is great here, don't get me wrong but my experience here is the reason why I am rating this place so lowly. I felt like our table had been neglected even when we wanted to pay for our meal.
author: Brian L.

description:
I think Orenchi is overhyped and here's why. 

Here at Orenchi Beyond the broth is less oily but there's literally one piece of meat. Regardless of quality, $13 for a bowl of ramen with one piece of meat is quite expensive. 
Since this place seemed to be so popular, I was hoping for a rich bowl of tonkatsu broth. Unfortunately they only serve miso and soy broth. I ordered their soy while my boyfriend tried their miso. His broth was slightly saltier than average and mine...just didn't seem like soy. Isn't soy suppose to be darker? Well it seemed like they gave me miso soup and literally squirted some soy on the side because there was a small black puddle in my bowl.  

This location uses long tables so be prepared to sit next to other customers.

I'd round up to 3.5 stars for customer service if Yelp allowed it.
I sat next to a customer who was vegetarian. She asked the waiter if they could serve a bowl of rice with all the toppings..bamboo shoots, seaweed, etc. The waiter said it was possible, but explained that it would be plain since there's no sauce. Thumbs up for this type of customer service! They could've easily served and charged her for a bowl of dry food.
author: Danae L.

description:
I came here during my lunch break through a recommendation from a friend. The place is a nice little place, you def need to try hard to find it because my freind and I walked passed it twice! We just couldn't notice any restaurant. 

I've heard that this place was one of the top ramen places in SF so I decided to try it and there was really no "WOW ME " factor in it. I ordered the Orenchi Beyond ramen, and I felt that I had better. The soup base was super salty, and the little things that came with it wasn't much.  Everything tasted a bit too salty to my liking, so i didn't have such a great experience.  I also think the price was not worth it, only because again it was wasn't much to eat other than a boiled egg, with two slices of meat and some seaweed on top. 

The service was great, and the place looks nice and clean, I just wasn't amazed by the ramen and the price for it. Again I would recommend to try everything once for your liking but I wouldn't come back.
author: Tiffany K.

description: I'm not a picky ramen eater. I just want good broth and alot of options for toppings. Ordered Orenchi beyond (tonkatsu based broth) and it was so good! The broth was really flavorful. I definitely will be back.
author: Aimee E.

description:
Date & Time:  Sunday October 26, 2014 @ 6pm
Dining Companions:  Mommy & Husband
Scene:  Groups of Young Guys in SuperDry Tee's & Nikes Accompanied by Girls in Crop Black Tops, High-Waisted Shorts & Ankle Boots
Music:  EDM
Decor:  Fun & Whimsical Ramen Bar with Tightly-Packed Tables 
Service:  Young, Hip, Trendy
Imbibe:  Soju & Sake
Devour:  Ankimo, Negi-Toro Rice, Pork Stew Rice, Orenchi Ramen & Orenchi Beyond Ramen
Total:  $52.50
author: Genevieve Y.

description:
I'm ok with this spot. You know why? The wait wasn't 2 hours like their south bay location. I can't do anything over a 15-20 minute wait anymore. I GET HANGRY!!!!!!!

I'm going to have to say 3.75  I ordered a ginger ale while the bf had a beer. Thought my ginger ale tasted funky. He tried it and said it tasted weird as well, but I thought if they're making it in house that could be the reason why. Ehhhh after careful inspection of Yelp photos, I realized they gave me an uemeshi ginger cocktail. NO WONDER! BF paid so I didn't even see the itemized bill this time but I am sure it was a cocktail. And in case you're wondering, that drink was not good. 

On to the food.

Started off with tako wasabi. I love tako wasabi. At Orenchi Beyond it is the standard amount that most restaurants give. Slimy and crunchy raw octopus, yum. I felt it needed a tad more wasabi because it was missing that heat, but BF felt it was the right amount. 

Both of us ordered the Orenchi Ramen. I loved the thick, al dente noodles!! Broth had a great amount of fat, but I felt it needed a little more salt for a tonkotsu broth. The egg was cooked abso-freakin-lutely perfect. Beautiful runny yolk. I wished it was marinated in soy sauce or something though. 

I also ordered an ikura ontama ($6) salmon roe, poached egg and seaweed over rice. Again, a beautifully poached egg. The ikura was not overly salty - do they marinate them in house?? They were tasty! 

The thing that impressed me most was their operations. Service might be a little off ( our order was already taken, but then someone else came to take our order again.. later on the wrong food was given to us. Mehh, opening kinks) as is expected with new places, but I think the Orenchi crew know how to run ship smoothly for the most part. The mister and I were already there are opening, but they staggered the seating. We made it into the first round and opted for the bar. We noticed they only filled about half the restaurant, even though they well could have filled the entire place up with the amount of people waiting outside. Food started coming in a slow wave, and as we ate, we noticed they started filling up the rest of the room as the first parties started paying and leaving. Way to go Orenchi crew. 

I really liked the noodles and thought maybe the broth could've used a little more work, but my stomach didn't agree with me later on. I'll still be back to try other things. Loved the interior as well. That waiting area bar with opened windows is awesome! I'm sure once it gets more cold they'll pop the panels back in. 

P.S. I'll be sure to check that they give me a ginger ale next time and not a damn cocktail..
author: Susy C.

description:
Came here for lunch on a Tuesday with my coworkers around 12:30pm - got seated within 15minutes. The architecture is beautiful and the decor looks like this place is fun at night (with the DJ booth, bar, and old vinyl records!)

We had the Takoyaki and Fried Tofu for starters and liked the flavor of the tofu best. The Takoyaki did not impress me, the octopus were super small, barely ate it, and the flavor was just not there. I had the Orenchi ramen which was super filling and rich in flavor - but it was a little too oily for me. The soft-boiled egg was amazing though and the pork. 

Definitely a place to check-out since it's one of the few ramen spots I don't mind going to in the city. I think the original Orenchi in Santa Clara was better (including their takoyaki). A plus were the cool purse hangers under the tables ;) haha
author: Amanda C.

description:
I never made it down to Orenchi in Santa Clara so I was excited to hear they were opening one in the city.  The bf and I drove by opening night and though there was a decent amount of people, we figured it wouldn't be too much of a wait.  Arriving 5 minutes before opening time, we made it in towards the end of first seating and waited about 20-25 minutes but I'm guessing that's because of the Giants being in game 6 of the World Series.  

The bf likes a variety of food so he likes to over order on the appetizers.  None we ordered were a must order (though my friend went later on and ordered the beef tataki and said it was delicious).  We decided to go with:
*Spicy Karaage ($7.80, 6 pieces) - A bit disappointing.  I expected crispy pieces of chicken tossed in a spicy powder.  However it came as six drumsticks glazed in a slightly sweet sauce and topped with shredded red peppers.  It was not anywhere close to spicy.
*Age Takoyaki ($7.50, 6 pieces) - The fried dumpling contained a small piece of octopus in the middle.  The exterior was nice, crispy and topped with bonito flakes, but the interior was too mushy.  
*Fried Chicken Wings ($7.30, 6 pieces) - The best appetizer, but still not outstanding.  The chicken wings were deep fried and sprinkled with salt and pepper.

There's two types of ramen on the menu that sounded both the same.  Our waitress recommended the Beyond Ramen ($12), their signature ramen that you could only order at this location.  It's a tonkotsu based broth that also has a bit of soy in it.  The soup was delicious on first taste.  It was light with a bit of a garlic taste, but the more I ate, the saltier it got.  I wasn't a big fan of the noodles.  I liked that they were chewy, but the noodles were fat and were similar to chow mein noodles.  The toppings are scarce and came with one thin slice of pork, green onions, a few pieces of bamboo shoots, a piece of seaweed, and fried garlic.  I added an egg and I was glad I did.  Since the bowls of noodles aren't too big (I finished mine with no problem), the runny egg filled me up.

Being that it is a new restaurant, there are a few kinks that need to be worked out with service and timing.  Though our waitress was nice, she was often missing.  We sat at the counter and felt a bit forgotten.  I'm not sure if they have designated areas, but it took awhile waiting for her to come around.  My ramen was served in a timely manner, but the bf didn't get his until about 7-8 minutes after I got mine even though we ordered the same thing.  Both bowls of ramen should have been served at the same time.  

In the battle of San Francisco's over saturated ramen restaurants, Orenchi's broth rates up there.  In the battle of the south bay's battle between Santouka and Orenchi, sorry Orenchi, my stomach belongs to Santouka.

P.S. Hooks under the counters would be a nice touch for patrons to hang their bags

WHAT TO KNOW:
*Beer, sake, and shochu
*In addition to ramen and a number of appetizers, they also offer soba and rice dishes 
*Noodle refills are not available (first time I've seen or heard of that option)
*There's counter seating, a few table seating, and communal table seating
*Glass window, open kitchen concept
*For those 21+, you can order a glass of Sapporo at the outside window while you wait for your table
*Expect it to be a bit loud.  There's music bumping on the speakers and there's probably about 40 something people trying to have their separate conversations.
*Metered street parking.  It's the Mission so it's often difficult to find.  However, we found parking immediately at 5:50pm
author: Nicole S.

description:
I wanted to come here after hearing my friend talk about their location in Santa Clara. It was super busy when i went, which i took as a good sign for its popularity. Had to wait a bit to be seated even though it was just one friend and i, but i didn't mind. There was a rock to sit on and heat lamps to keep you warm. Oh, and you can feel free to grab drinks at the bar while you wait. 

The staff was friendly, but it was quite busy so i expect it was hard for them to be very attentive. Still, the needs were met :) the ramen was good, but i found it to be a bit greasier than other ramen i've had in sf

Overall, and good place and convenient location near valencia bars and such, buuut not really my fave in the city.
author: Bianca C.

description:
BELIEVE THE HYPE!!!
(4.25 stars)

Finally Orenchi Ramen from the Southbay expands to the City. Yes, EXPECT A LINE AND EXPECT TO WAIT. We had arrived 30 minutes earlier with a party of 9, put our name on the list, and was in the first batch of people to load into th restaurant. It's nice they are organized in that fashion. Is it worth it? As Hunter Pence would say "YES! YES! YES!" At a first glance of the ramen "what the hell... only four ramens to choose from?!?!?!"

The tables and chairs are super low. I felt like hunchback of nortre dame sitting on the stills leaning over to eat my soup. There was nowhere to  place our belongings but either on the floor OR on your lap. Please, at the minimum, add hooks under the table. Service was on-point and fairly quick. The servers were very joyful and happy to take our order - we had 3 of them come asking us for our order. After ordering, i'd say 10-15 minutes before we received our ramen.

AGE TAKOYAKI ($6.70) - deep fried octopus dumplings. they prepare it very well here. not overly densed but the perfect kidn of stuffed dumpling with the right amount of octopus meat. the octopus was cooked to perfection as the mean was tender and not chewy. 

KARABUTA SAUSAGE - they gave us huge ordering of this and on the house as they forgot to bring it out to us at the beginning. love karabuta (not karaBUTO) sausages. Although a bit greasy, it was still delicious. The ones they server had a nice spicy to them - making one crave a side of rice. 

ORENCHI RAMEN ($12) - egg, pork, green onion, bamboo shoot, mushroom, sesame, nori seaweed. no need to add extra goods, the basics was PLENTY enough. I must rave about the broth, it was very tasty - one of the best ramen broth's I've had in my life. The soft boiled egg was the best soft-boiled egg ever to ooze and bleed into ramen. That was the most beautiful egg I've ever had to pop. Then the pork... thinly sliced, tender, and juicy... what more can you ask for?! The noodles were typical ramen noodles. Honestly, i'd be happy with everything inside the ramen minus the noodles and still give this place a great rating. I admint, every bite and fishing of left over fragments of bamboo shoots and mushroom were a good sign of really enjoying the place.

Will I be back? I would love too but I am not about to wait in line with the rest of the city.

Until the next review....
author: Jane A.

description:
I've been a fan of Orench at Santa Clara, and I was so dying to try for this place when I heard about their opening towards the end of last year. My chance to try finally came last week while visiting the bay area on business.

I read the reviews before my visit and many said about the line forming up so quickly before opening time..  So I was there at 11:25am, 5 mins before open for lunch time.  I would have been there earlier if I didn't get lost on the way or find a parking spot sooner.  When I showed up, they had about 10-14 people waiting, so I put my name on the list.  As soon as they opened we still had enough space to accommodate everyone waited.

Since I had Orench original several times, I wanted to try their only sold at this Mission location "Orench Beyond".   Ramen came and fairly quickly and i was happy to see so many garlic in the broth.  I added the additional garlic paste, hmmmm.. It was really garlicky and so goooooooood.  Since the broth was tonkotsu base, I was hoping they will serve with thin noodles but the broth was so thick, regular ramen noodle went good with this garlicky broth.  I added soft boiled egg and inside was to my preference.  It was unfortunate inside the egg (yolk) was a bit cold and ruined (but not totally) the hot broth.  They cook eggs ahead of time and keep them in the fridge. To serve with ramen, they really don't want to over heat as that will over cook the egg.  It's just the fine line to make the perfect soft egg is difficult, it would have been perfect if the yolk was warmer.

As the server recommended the takoyaki (and also reviewers said good), I also ordered takoyaki.  I was imagining the takoyaki I had from a street vendor near somewhere in Umeda Osaka, very runny inside with outside texture.  It wasn't the case.  Not sure if they even made them at the restaurant.  I like the way takoyaki is served in Osaka but this restaurant served with special sauce I wasn't expecting.  They were good but not what I expected.  

Service was really good too. They were friendly and attentive.  By the time I was ready to leave the restaurant, they were very busy. I am glad I came at 11:30am.

If you plan to visit here, come early as they do get busy.  I wouldn't mind coming back at night as they are set up as a place to fit in the Mission area...
author: Yuko H.

description:
I had heard about this place but randomly decided to come in and eat here when me and a friend were walking back . It was about 7PM and although the place was pretty full there was not a line so we got seated right away . I loved the ambiance of the place and how it's decorated .
Takoyaki - I don't know what kind of sauce they used for the takoyaki but it was not really to my liking . It tasted a little to mayo-y . Would not order again or recommend .
Spicy Karage - Again the sauce for the chicken was off for me and my friend did not like the sauce at all . The karage also was not really crispy as I've usually had them . Again would not order again or recommend .
Orenchi Ramen - A little salty for my tastes but good nonetheless . The egg was nice and yolky how it should be . The cha siu was yummy and I enjoyed the consistency of the noodles . It tasted good even the day after and suprisingly the noodles did not get super thick the day after . 
Overall I would definitely stick to the ramen and skip the appetizers .
author: Julia K.

description:
When did ramen become a thing?  I mean, seriously, how did one type of noodle make people go crazy waiting hours in line?  This will probably be one of those foodie mysteries that I'll never solve.  

Now that I got that off my chest, let me proceed with my review.  A group of old college friends and I decided to check out Orenchi Beyond.  There's just something comforting about catching up over hot bowls of noodles.  We were lucky enough to be first on the list and got seated right at opening.  This place is like a night club atmosphere with food instead of dancing.   Between the six of us, we shared the hamachi carpaccio, agedashi tofu, fish cake and kaarage as appetizers.  I ordered the signature beyond ramen with an added egg that had the perfect yolk and some kikurage mushrooms.  The broth was pretty rich and amazing!  I loved every bite of the noodles and toppings.  I would have slurped the bowl clean if I wasn't so full from the additional cha-siu rice bowl my hunny and I shared.  What was I thinking? Too much umami!

I don't know if I would wait hours to go here again, but if the timing is right, it worth a try.  Just be prepared for a couple of things.  It is pretty loud - remember I mentioned a club atmosphere?  I wasn't kidding.  There's even a dj booth in the corner of the restaurant.  Most of the seating is communal, with a couple of side tables for small parties.  You can see the kitchen putting the ramen bowls together, which makes you anticipate that warm bowl even more as you see the toppings being added like artwork.  

Enjoy your ramen!  It's a thing.
author: Maria S.

description:
Recently learned about Orenchi Beyond in SF. Didn't know this place existed until a coworker told me about it when I mentioned that I've been waiting to try Orenchi in Santa Clara. This place is opened until 12AM on the weekends! I came here around 10pm and there was absolutely no line at all! I absolutely love the ambience of this place, pretty hipster and relaxed. I don't mind just chilling at the place with a nice bowl of ramen. 

I ordered the Orenchi Ramen, I'm not sure if I was just extremely hungry or it was just that good. The broth was super fragrant, I enjoyed every single bite of it. The noodles were cooked perfectly. Nothing but good things to say about this place.
author: Polly L.

description:
Hard to finally be in the right place at the right time but the food was really good 

Ramen seems like it should be so easy to get right but in SF so far it has been fairly hit or miss !

This spot is a hit out the park !
author: Azikiwee A.

description:
I mistakenly came here BEFORE looking at their health score - 76. Two high risk violations and other moderate and
Low ones as of last month.

Of course the score is not posted.

I'm in public health and normally avoid any place under 80. - it's just not safe!
author: R. P.

description:
Due to my love for ramen my friend recommended me to this place because it is one of her favorite ramen places. Today I finally had the chance to check this place out! We were the first customers into the restaurant and we were greeted by all the workers in Japanese. It was really neat on how friendly all of the workers were. Once seated I was surprise to be sitting on a tree stump! Also on the table there is a hook to put your purse (I love that!). There was also a very beautiful piece of artwork along the wall but I'm not fully sure on what it was (lion? Bear?). Anyways the restaurant was very cute. 

When we sat down we ordered Aged Takoyaki ($7.50) for our appetizer. I'm really starting to get into Takoyaki so I found this very delectable. I liked how the Takoyaki didn't fall to pieces like the ones I had in the past. But then again I am not too familiar with what is good and bad takoyaki.  

For our main course I ordered the Beyond Ramen and my friend ordered the Orenchi Ramen. Mine contained a lot of garlic and had a lot of flavor in the broth. My broth gave my meat a great savory taste whereas my friends did not. My friends tasted like tonkotsu so it was nothing special except for their soft boiled egg which my friend really loved. Unfortunately the Beyond Ramen does not come with a soft boiled egg unless added to the dish but regardless it was delicious and I would say that is their best selling dish. I'm not sure if the noodles were handmade but they also had a unique texture that separated it from the other ramen noodles I've had. (I forgot to ask!) 

But overall the food was average and if the place wasn't so far away from where I live and opened sooner then I would be more willing to  make another trip back.
author: Kaitlyn K.

description: It was so delicious! No wait  was a huge plus. I think the quality is quite close to its original location in Santa Clara but the pork here is not as fatty. The ramen was al dente and the soft-boiled egg was perfect. The original location is still my all-time favorite though (but the wait there is 1hr+). If you like ramen, this is definitely the best ramen place in SF!
author: Norases V.

description: I have to say I was underwhelmed when I came here after going to the original orenchi. I only ate the ramen here because that is what they are suppose to be known for, but it def didn't live up to the same one that is in Santa Clara. I was really disappointed with orenchi beyond and having to wait over an hour for 2.
author: Brandon C.

description: Came here and tried two ramens, the sf special and orenchi special. The sf one was a bit salty and I preferred the orenchi flavored one. I thought the price was very fair and the broth was very reasonable think and flavorful. I'd say this is a better bargain than mensho and you can make a reservation here. It was also more filling than mensho, with mensho tasting a bit better but not worth the other factors like price, substance, and wait
author: Victor D.

description:
One of the better ramen places in the city, better than Katanaya, Ramen Underground, Izakaya Sozai, ...

This place is a bit on the salty side though, but definitely the most legit ramen place in the city.
author: Thomas C.

description:
On the one hand, I was super excited Orenchi had another location in SF. On the other hand, nostalgia goggles might have hit me and I didn't find this one nearly as good.

I had to try their Beyond ramen - a garlic-fied version of their Orenchi ramen. While I do enjoy the addition of garlic to my broth, I found the broth to be more salty and less rich than its Santa Clara counterpart. My additional egg was also a little cold, but everything else was solid and everything I love in Orenchi Ramen.

Also got the karaage, the geso karaage, and the spicy karaage. I liked the bigger pieces of karaage but they were a tad dry. Geso was awesome, and the spicy karaage was a glorified chicken wing. I enjoyed it, but not sure I would get it again haha.

Orenchi Beyond is definitely a solid ramen joint, but the name is misleading. Feels like it took a couple steps back from the lead it had before =(
author: Dave N.

description:
I've been going to Orenchi Ramen in Santa Clara since 2010. I've had it more times than I care to admit. I've lived in SF for a while now and only went to this location today. I was worried that it would have a crazy wait like the one in Santa Clara, but I got there when they opened at 6 on a Wednesday and ONLY FIVE OTHER PPL WERE WAITING. This is unheard of in terms of Orenchi, or just good ramen in the Bay Area in general. 

I ordered the Orenchi ramen to compare to Santa Clara (the tonkatsu with the shio base). I saw on Yelp beforehand that ppl said that the SF one doesn't have as good ramen as the Santa Clara location. I hoped that was wrong, or that it would be a subtle difference, but there are big differences. 

My friend and I agreed that the SF one is wayyyy saltier, much more oily/fatty (it leaves the outside of your mouth all oily), and has an almost sweeter flavor, like they added sweet soy sauce to it. Also, the noodles aren't as chewy and curly (more a textural preference I have), but that probably is because of different noodle suppliers in their respective areas. I mean, the noodles are still great, I'm just being annoyingly picky. The chashu, toppings, and egg are the same though. 

The SF one is a little more expensive, but not that crazy, and totally expected. However, if you factor in the nonexistent wait time (even at 7PM, only like 20 ppl were there and there were many empty seats!), I would go to the SF one instead. After arriving ten minutes before opening at the SC one and being seated 2 hours later, I will always pick the not as good tasting one in SF.
author: Kelly B.

description: Yum! This is way underrated. Some of the best ramen I've had in the city thus far. Great service, great food. Had the traditional ramen and some karaage. Both excellent.
author: Ryan B.

description: I thoroughly enjoyed my Orenchi ramen at lunchtime mid-week!  I loved the broth and everything in it!  I was so hungry and knew what I wanted to order that I did not really pay attention to anything else on the menu.  Service was friendly and quick.  I cannot wait to go back hopefully very, very soon maybe to try other things on the menu or just get that yummy Orenchi ramen again!
author: Maile N.

description:
I was psyched when I heard that a new Orenchi opened up in SF!  I love the Santa Clara Orenchi, and since this one was opened by the same owners... dude why not?!  I had to try.

I had the Beyond Ramen (+ an extra egg, because the egg is not offered in this ramen) and found it super garlicy (which I love) but a little too salty.  After finishing eating, I was barely satisfied!  Super small portions, and not enough for a petite girl with a big appetite like me or even anyone with an average appetite to feel full.  :c  The egg was colder than room temperature and largely contrasted to my lukewarm ramen...which could've also been hotter by the way.  Not a fan of cold egg and barely warm, small-portioned ramen.  :c :c :c  If I'm not going to be full, at least keep my taste buds happy!!!  :c

The total came out to be about $15 including tip, which I found overpriced for what it was.  There are so many other ramen joints that are more justifiably priced, and I just didn't find Orenchi Beyond one of them.  The venue is new/hip and the service was superb, but my tummy was unhappy.  I tried, but unhappy tummy, unhappy Carena.
author: Carena N.

description: Definitely not as good as the original location. The broth is salty and not memorable. $13/bowl w/ add-ons available. Eggs were a smidge overdone. Fried chicken wings were crispy and juicy, though. The pork rice wasn't bad but could've benefited from an egg or veggie. $45 for 2 sans beverages.
author: Julie L.

description:
I've never been to the original location in Santa Clara, but I really enjoyed Orenchi Beyond! Apparently, they cook the soup for 18 hours and I thought that the broth really showed the intensity and richness in flavor! I thought the portions were similar to most ramen places. If you want more noodles, there's an option to make it a large order for a small price. I also got the salmon roe and salmon flakes rice bowl, and the salmon roe was delicious / fresh. Would definitely recommend both the Orenchi Beyond ramen and the salmon roe rice bowl. I would not recommend the takoyaki. The octopus within the takoyaki balls was tasty and fresh, but the outside of the takoyaki consisted of way too much flour. Overall, the ratio of flour to actual octopus was very suboptimal for my taste.

Would definitely come again for my ramen fix! I also recommend smaller parties here, as the restaurant is quite small and seems to be catered mostly to parties of 2-4 unless you manage to snag a large communal type table for yourself.
author: Claudia C.

description:
This place is cool, but it is definitely overhyped. I would not wait 1-2 hours for the ramen. Thankfully, we got there towards the end of the night, so we only waited 10 minutes. 

We ordered the beyond ($12) and orenchi ramen (large $13.50), along with a side of seared/ roasted pork strips ($6 for 4 pcs). The beyond ramen was a little too salty, to the point where I was consistently drinking water. The orenchi ramen was mediocre and a bit bland. They both didn't come with enough meat, so it was a good call to order a side of extra meat. 

Overall, the ramen was only 7/10. However, the staff is extremely friendly and attentive. 
4 stars because of the service, short wait, and quickly served food.
author: Miranda T.

description:
was pretty excited to try this place - i havent been to orenchi in santa clara tho, so i cant compare the two. there arent many ramen options - i chose the orenchi ramen cuz it comes with egg (beyond ramen does not).  broth is tonkotsu based. it was a really rich tonkotsu flavor - you can see the giant vats bubbling down in the kitchen.

also tried the karaage - cuz i was craving fried anything aha. it was crunchy, but kinda lacking in flavor. i prefer it with salt n pepper taste so it tastes like something! so that was disappointing.

anyhoo. if you're craving tonkotsu broth this is pretty good. and the noodles are nicely cooked and held their texture well. but i've learned that i prefer spicy miso ramen, with thinner noodles, so i will probably stick with yamadaya - their chicken is better too. hehe.
author: Christina L.

description: I traveled to SF a few weeks ago, and my friends had recommended this place as a must try If I was in town for a visit. I must say, I am super glad they recommended this place. I got the Orenchi Ramen, and my friend got the Beyond Ramen, they were both delicious. But my favorite was definitely the Orenchi Ramen. The pork belly was tender and basically melted in your mouth. Will definitely come back to this place to try other items on the menu, once I am back in town for a visit. Plus the staff is super friendly, and the customer service is superb!
author: Tiffany C.

description: After trying the location in SJ and this one, I would love to say this is my favorite Orenchi by far. The wait wasn't too long, less than 20 minutes. The outdoor waiting area is great, there's a TV and a heater. Service was awesome, everything came out as ordered. Definitely didn't seem like much of a difference (referring to taste of the ramen) from the other location. Giving 5 stars because of the overall experience I had here.
author: Danny T.

description:
Wait time on Saturday at 7:30PM: 1 hour for a party of 3
Parking: Street Parking

We got seated at 8:30 at the bar area. My friend said that she actually felt like she was in a bar because of the loud club music playing in the background (lol). I felt like it was hard to hold a conversation in here because it was so loud. There is no individual table seating at this location; all communal, probably to fit more people since it is a small restaurant. 

My friend and I ordered the Orenchi Ramen ($12). 
My boyfriend ordered the Beyond Ramen ($12), and added a soft boiled egg ($1.20). 

I would've chosen the Beyond Ramen because of the fried garlic that is in it, but decided on the Orenchi Ramen because it already comes with the soft boiled egg and they have the garlic sauce thing at the table (side note: I love adding garlic to everything). The food came out very promptly. I like the way their kitchen is set up so that they have a glass window/wall that you can see through to see how they make the noodles, etc. The broth was good, and even better when I added the garlic.

However, 3 stars because I think I just really wanted to try it to compare to the Santa Clara location; since the Santa Clara location is so popular. Compared to the other ramen places I like in the city, I think I can get a bowl of ramen that is just as good as this for a more comfortable dining experience and 0 wait time.
author: Michelle C.

description:
Best ramen in SF if you're looking for tonkotsu ramen. I always order the Beyond Ramen with extra takana. Nice tonkotsu and garlic flavor, with thick al dente noodles. 

The negitoro rice bowl is a nice appetizer as well.

Plus sometimes they have open mic karaoke. QED.
author: Glendon M.

description:
I love ramen. 
This spot right across from zeitgeist is the perfect way to wrap up a day of drinking when the fog rolls in in the evening and temperatures drop to sub-zero. 

The architecture and Interior decoration is wonderful. Really innovative window system. The outdoor patio is heated! This is extremely necessary if you're waiting to be seated as there isn't enough waiting room inside, and it makes a great ambiance for standing at the outdoor bar having a beer. 

The food is really great, though I do think I prefer the one in San Jose. I always get the Orenchi Ramen because it has the egg and lacks the garlic. (I have tried the beyond ramen and all I could taste was garlic.) The ramen is  fantastic. no questions there.

The staff is super helpful and friendly. The service is quick even though it's always packed in there. I highly recommend!
author: Shayan S.

description:
Yum! Went to Orenchi as a recommendation from a local friend, and we were not disappointed!  I would give 5 stars if service was better; our servers were not attentive so our meal lasted a really long time (and unfortunately beer-less after we ran out of our first round)... 

LOCATION
