In my opinion, seemed kind of random when we were driving back from Japantown lol.  The place was jammin' but we found street parking no problem.  Yay for free street parking after6 pm!  My bf and I enjoyed ordering beer while waiting, with the heaters beaming down on us outside.  Inside is small, but loud/busy with good vibes.

FOOD
As first timers we opted for the deep fried garlic appetizer, and it was sooo good! My bf and I are huge fans of deep fried or baked garlic because the cloves become so soft and delicious. Bf had the Beyond Ramen, I had the Orenchi Ramen... and we both agreed that we liked the Orenchi better - it just seemed to have more of a garlicky, tonkotsu flavor.  To me, the Beyond tasted more like shoyu based or something.  Both were still very delicious, just if we had to choose a better ramen, we both agree on the Orenchi Ramen... Add a spoonful of the pureed garlic and done!  So good.
author: Joanna Y.

description: First time visit. We found the flavors very authentic, felt like a raman in Tokyo. Great service, fun beers in steel glasses, all around a good, hearty dinner.
author: Richard L.

description:
Short Story:
A really decent place for ramen...but not as good as their original Orenchi restaurant in Santa Clara!

Long Story:
I came here on a Thursday evening around 5:45PM as they opened at 6PM
The long line had not come yet...but to be sure, by the time we left, it was there!
I ordered the Beyond Ramen with extra noodles and spinach.  It came out to be about $16.
Slightly overpriced even for SF for ramen.  I think the Orenchi in Santa Clara ahs better quality food and prices.
I will say they have a sort of hip place for their location and some appetizers and food that cannot be found in Santa Clara.
But in the end, if you want good ramen in SF or in the peninsula, there are far better places.

Verdict:
I may not come back for a while...
author: Michael W.

description:
I was so excited to try Orenchi (since I adore ramen!) and had very high expectations. On Friday night, Jenny and I put our name down around 8:20 pm and went to order a drink at Zeitgeist while we waited since they estimated the wait was at least 30 minutes. We were back at Orenchi around 35 minutes later and our table was ready 5 minutes later, that was painless!

The tables are long, wooden and family-style and the restaurant is chilly especially on a cold night and when the front door is open. Luckily ramen could warm us up. We both ordered the oolong cocktail which came in a very big glass. We ordered the shishito peppers to start which were very good followed by bowls of the Orenchi ramen (Jenny got the large size for about $1.50 more). The soup was very good but not quite as amazing as I expected with all the hype I'd heard. We also ordered the tuna rice which was a big serving and delicious for about $6.

I would come back if I were in the area but won't be rushing back especially since I'd anticipate at least a 30 minute wait again.
author: Meghan P.

description: We got there around 6:30 on a Friday night. I got seated right away so that was nice. I ordered the Orenchi Beyond. I was a little bit disappointed. The broth was good, but the noodles and meat were just okay.
author: Rachael C.

description:
It's hard to come across good ramen in San Francisco. The ramen at Orenchi Beyond falls a little short of the ramen you can find in Los Angeles, New York, or Tokyo, but it's my favorite ramen shop so far in the city. I came here with some of my Japanese friends and we all got the Orenchi ramen. The Orenchi ramen is a tonkotsu based soup topped with chashu (thinly sliced pork belly), seasoned soft-boiled egg, green onions, bamboo shoot, mushroom, sesame, and nori (dried seaweed). 

The highlights were the noodles, soft-boiled egg, and the nori. The noodles were cooked perfectly al dente. I can't stress how important the consistency of the noodles are in ramen and they hit it out of the ball park. The seasoned soft-boiled egg was firm on the outside and deliciously soft and gooey on the inside. The nori was dipped only half-way like it should be, allowing me to enjoy both the soft and crunchy texture of the seaweed.

The downfall was the broth. The tonkotsu broth had a nice milky color and it was rich and unctuous. However, there wasn't enough flavor or saltiness. A lot of tonkotsu broths use shoyu dare and I couldn't taste it in this one. Shoyu dare is crucial for bringing out the umami and saltiness and without it (or not enough of it), I felt like I was just marrying my noodles in pure fat.

Overall, Orenchi's ramen is good. It definitely beats many of the other ramen shops you will find in San Francisco. Another plus to this place is the decor and design of the space. It's trendy without losing its authenticity. The service here was excellent as well.
author: Hana K.

description:
I'm a huge ramen person, so I'm glad to have had the opportunity to taste one of NorCal's well-known ramens.  I was lucky enough to go there when it was just about to open for dinner time so the line wasn't too bad.  

I LOVE their pork broth--the fatty, thick, flavorful, MSG gets to me ALL THE TIME! I can tell that they simmered the pork for quite a while.  I love how the noodles were thick and chewy; the noodles remind me of the ones from Tsujita (one of my favorite famous ramen places in LA). I loved everything in the ramen, including the bamboo shoots (and I usually hate it!).  The Orenchi ramen also included a perfectly cooked soft-boiled egg :).  A suggestion is for them to have spicy Orenchi ramen!!! That sounds SO DELICIOUS, but for now I will just ask them for the chili oil and spices. 

They don't have a parking lot so it's hard to find parking around there, but that's very typical since it's located in SF.  For ramen, the price is pretty expensive :/.  Back in LA, I can get ramen for around 10 dollars, but the Orenchi ramen already costs 12-13 dollars!!! Also, I didn't really like  how the music was SOOO loud that I couldn't hear what my friends had to say during dinner; while the music brings in a young, hip mood, I don't think you have to put it on blast--people are still trying to have dates and "catch up" time here so you don't need to! 

Overall, when I do go back to Norcal I would definitely want to come back again! :D
author: Iris C.

description:
I have never had ramen before and this place really surprised me. The waiting staff is very friendly and willing to explain their menu to someone who has no clue - like me.
The interior is very pretty, they have an open kitchen and funny videos on the wall.
I'd love to come back but unfortunately I'm only visiting.
author: Sarah H.

description:
Hands down my go-to ramen joint in the area! The tonkotsu ramen is pretty good and consistent. If you want something with some kick, try the Beyond Ramen which is intensely garlic-y, and not for the faint of heart. Those familiar with the Orenchi in Santa Clara will find themselves at home here.. but closer and less of a wait!

Breakdown of ramen: Broth is a medium tonkotsu. Good flavor and not heavy. Noodles are standard size and typically more on the al dente side. The chashu is pretty delicious, but cut a bit thin. Egg is on the more well done side, but still slightly gelatinous.

Insiders tip is to try the Chashu gohan. Its pretty delicious and a good value if you want something small.
author: James S.

description: I've been here a few times for lunch.  It's a really cool spot.  There isn't a lot of seating, but the atmosphere is very open (and loud).  The food here is a really good value!  I wish they had ramen in a vegetarian broth (every ramen comes in a chicken or pork broth), but the other appetizers and small bowls are still great comfort food.  My favorite item here is the rice bowl with salmon roe and a poached egg.  The hot apple green tea is also good, although I don't like that it is served in a plastic carafe.  I imagine reservations would be necessary for dinner here, but seating is pretty easy to get during lunchtime.  I'll be back!
author: Virgo A.

description:
FOOD:
I liked the BEYOND ramen. The noodles are a good middle between the usual "thin" and "thick" choices of ramen noodles. Luckily I got to also try some of the ORENCHI ramen, and there was very little difference. The only difference I can tell was the soup base which was very very slight. If I had to guess, I would guess that the BEYOND is more miso and soy base and the Orenchi is way more salty. Both are good! There are different toppings for each bowl also. Both are good and taste very similar. I also liked the takoyaki as an appetizer. It was regular takoyaki but the batter is a little more thicker with flour. Also the sauce they add on is unusual but still good. Usually, there is takoyaki sauce on the takoyaki but this place had some kind of sauce that was like thousand island and mayo? Not sure, but still yummy! Also, if you like UMESHU, definitely get the umeshu ginger ale-definitely getting that again!!! What I didn't like is the portion size and the fact that they don't do kaedama. No refills for noodles. Usually, other places will give more noodles for $12 / bowl and kaedama is usually only $1 or even for students.

TIPS:
Don't go here if you plan on talking to someone. You can barely hear each other over the music since the ceilings are so high. And come here on a weekday-the wait is very very short. About 5min to 10min, or none! :)

HIGHLIGHTS:
Get the BEYOND, TAKOYAKI APPETIZER & UMESHU GINGER ALE!

Would I recommend this? Yes!
author: Kelley Y.

description:
I came here a few months ago to get my ramen fix.  I was excited to see another Orenchi open, even thought this one is far from my east bay home as well.  I would not call this restaurant conveniently located.  However, it was easy for us to find parking nearby.  

Overall they do serve a good bowl of ramen.  However, the original location is better.  If you are in the city and you want ramen, this is not a bad choice at all.
author: Tracy L.

description:
The talk of town for ramen, sister restaurant to the famous orenchi in San Mateo, this place opened in mission not too long ago.. No reservations and the line can get crazy.. Get there put your name on the list and you can order some appys from the window but dress warm..
The place is very chic and modern but still japanese twist which U.S. Nice but it gets very loud so don't expect any great conversation over dinner.
Tried both orenchi original and the beyond.. They were ok.. But not worth the wait... Just stick with ramen as the ikura don was really bad.. Although the wings looked alright..
Value 3.5/5
Atmosphere 3.5/5
Service 3/5
Quality 3.5/5
13.5/20
author: Nina S.

description: I love this place. Come during lunch time for a shorter or non-existent line. I've tried all of the 4 noodles offered here. For a richer dish, go w/ the Orenchi or the Beyond ramen bowls. The broth is a bit thicker, also more salty and oily. The Beyond comes with an egg. The tori soba was not that salty even though it's a salt-based soup. The leek was shredded so thinly that it had the effect of green onion. Great even for a hot day. The chu-ka soba was okay. I love that all 4 have bamboo shoots. The age takoyaki nicely fried and a good size. I also like the rice bowls, which are a pretty good deal. Sometimes, they have a ramen + rice bowl combo special. The cha su gohan was simple, but delicious. I also like the restaurant structure itself, nice open area in the front. Interesting stools and artwork on the tables and walls.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
my family and I stopped by here on a whim over the weekend, and couldn't identify the restaurant very well because the only Orenchi sign is about as big as a standard 8.5 x 11 piece of paper, with the words Orenchi in size 14 font. The venue is pretty large, and there is a pretty big boulder/rock seat in the front though, so it's a pretty hard place to miss.

the environment here is pretty hipster - dark lighting, communal tables (with hooks on the underside for your purses!), and barrels as seats. the communal seating was not too close for comfort at all. however, the noise level is pretty high, so save the good talk for after dinner. it's pretty much impossible to have an intimate conversation because it's so loud!

we ordered the chicken karaage, the orenchi ramen, and the beyond ramen (special only to this location). the orenchi ramen is a creamier broth and comes with an egg, whereas the beyond ramen is lighter and has no egg. and i must mention the egg again, because that onsen egg (half cooked and perfectly runny yolk) definitely made my night. both were pretty solid bowls of ramen, with enough noodles and toppings to successfully satisfy and fill my tummy. each bowl was $12, and you can pay an extra $1.50 for a "larger" version with more broth and noodles. the karaage was okay, nothing super special or exciting.

orenchi beyond was overall a fun and enjoyable experience, but i only wish the decibel level was a little lower!
author: Caitlin C.

description:
Kinda horrible.
The noodle texture didn't have enough bite for my taste. The broth for the Beyond ramen was nothing special.
The negi toro wasn't toro at all but seemed like low grade tuna.
The mentaiko rice bowl was really fishy and had a bad aftertaste.
Definitely not impressed and do not feel like I have to try Orenchi in Santa Clara anymore.
author: Heejin L.

description:
Ramen is so good! I like here more than Mensho.
Mensho is horrible!!
Mensho use Too much MSG!! OMG!!! MSG!!!
Orenchi ramen felt more authentic Japanese ramen. I can strong recommend here.
author: Yummy H.

description:
I never had Orenchi from Santa Clara, so I figured this location would be just as good from what other reviewers said. I came here with my boyfriend and was a little surprised how tiny the place was. We probably waited about 10 minutes until seated. The menu is limited to only four types of ramen. My boyfriend and I both ordered the Orenchi Ramen ($13) with a coke and water. Our ramen came out pretty fast but they forgot to give us our drinks, so we had to remind the staff for them.

Overall, the food was okay. It was nothing special to me. I wouldn't go out of my way to come here. I actually have had better ramen at other places lol. The music is too loud; to the point where I can't even have a conversation without having to yell across the table... I didn't enjoy my time here. I give this place a 2.5 stars.
author: Gelato T.

description:
Came here because of the name since I've been to the SJ Orenchi multiple times. Don't know if the SJ location and this SF location are siblings. Anyone know?

$13/bowl which is alright but is pushing it.  

I'd come back if I was absolutely craving ramen and was in the area. Otherwise I'd make the drive into San Mateo for Ramen Parlor. It's worth the drive.
author: Joshua F.

description:
I'm not sure what all the fuss is about -- the ramen at this place tastes identical to the one at the original restaurant down in Santa Clara. 

Very creamy, porky tonkotsu broth. I was impressed by the quality of the noodles here -- it was done just right, and though I think the "thicker" noodles stray from the traditional hakata tonkotsu style, it had the right amount of chewiness to make it great.
author: Kazu O.

description:
Oishii! 
Ramen: wonderfully cooked, great texture. perfect ratio of noodles to broth/toppings.
Broth: very flavorful but not overly salty. (I had the Orenchi Ramen)
Toppings: great mix of pork belly, perfectly poached egg (a bit runny on the inside--just the way I like it!), seaweed, mushrooms
Appetizers: highly recommend the shishito peppers--lightly fried, succulent, great for sharing.
Service: friendly, on-point
Decor/Atmosphere: minimal, hipster, approp. Not a big place: would not come with group over 4 ppl. Great to dine alone or with a partner at bar seating.
Price: seems reasonable for SF; $12 for medium-sized bowl of goodness.
author: Ray H.

description:
I was super excited to find some great ramen in the Mission-ish area, but I was pretty disappointed. The karage was great, but the ramen itself was pretty poor. The flavor of the broth was very burnt (I have no problem with black garlic oil, but this wasn't that) and fishy, which was bizarre. It was so bad that I couldn't finish it  and wound up getting a slice of pizza afterwards.

The good: we were able to get a seat within about five minutes of arriving on a Friday night at 9. 
The bad: I really didn't like the ramen. I wouldn't get it again.
author: Amanda B.

description: The Orenchi Beyond ramen is overpriced. Definitely has some garlic flavor with a number of garlic chips, but the broth is heavier and visibly fattier than the lighter milky white broth I remember from a while back in the south bay joint. My $12 bowl of ramen came with the dinkiest piece of pork; I think I had one bite's worth. I thought it was just a scrap that fell off a proper slice of belly, but after fishing around a bit, didn't see any more meat. :( The menma also has a strong aroma and flavor to them, which I am not a fan of. You will leave feeling reasonably full if you drink enough of the broth due to the grease, and yet still shortchanged if you order this bowl. I won't bother with the Beyond ramen again at least, but would give them another shot later to try some of their other stuff. They do have plenty of seating during weekday lunches at least.
author: Linus W.

description:
I have a confession to make... the last time I had ramen was back when I was a teenager at summer camp. I know, crazy right?! 

I was in the Mission last week with a friend and he suggested having dinner at Orenchi Beyond. The restaurant has a cool vibe; it's a good fit for the neighborhood. We both ordered a glass of the house sake while the waitress explained the different types of ramen. I decided on the Tori Soba, while my friend had the Orenchi Ramen. The food was very good. We ended up staying pretty late and noticed that we were the only ones left in the restaurant. After realizing this, we quickly gathered our things to leave. The staff was very friendly and did not rush us as we made out way out the door. I would recommend Orenchi to any ramen-lovers in the Mission!
author: Rachel S.

description:
Yes we braved Valencia street all while waiting about an hour and a half for our table but I have to say, it was well worth it.

The crowd is young with an energetic vibe. Everyone is either too excited about their future ramen meal or already tipsy from the drinks served while you wait. Architecturally speaking, this place is a hidden gem literally hidden behind a garage door and next to a Religious center and sketchy pizza place that we all know must be a front for something else.

The drinks are plentiful, the scene is perfection, the food is spectacular. A recent Ramen article came out yesterday featuring the top 10 Ramen eateries in the US and I was surprised Orenchi wasn't on the list. But it soon will be. Check it out for yourself and make sure you feed your ramen craving.
author: Kevin J.

description: Both Orenchi Beyond and its sister restaurant in Santa Clara called Orenchi are great!!  Whenever I'm craving delicious healthy ramen, I choose this. One of the best Ramen places ever! If you ever decide to get Ramen. This must be a go to! Stop reading my review and enjoy the delicious food!
author: Angel V.

description:
I have been wanting to try Orenchi ever since we went to Santa Clara and waited in line for 2 hours and decided to leave. I was so excited to hear there was one in SF. Of course, we didn't go when they first opened because we didn't want to be disappointed by the long wait. 

Surprisingly, the wait was not long at all on a Friday evening.. around 15 minutes. We checked out the menu and noticed they have a window where you can buy sake, beer and apps while waiting. However, I was first in line at the window and no one even came to the window! After 5 minutes, someone said they were gonna "be right there". Another 5 minutes passed and our table was ready. 

We started with the Hamachi Carpaccio. It was sooo fishy.. and salty.. and warm. I think they seared it on the outside. Should have read the other reviews on this appetizer. Be warned!

Alternatively, the ramen was REALLY good. We had the Beyond Ramen and Orenchi Ramen on the menu. One was soy sauce based and the other one was salt based Tonkotsu (pork) broth. We added 2 eggs and corn and it was very tasty. We washed it down with their imported beer.

The ambiance is laid back and our server was attentive.. VERY attentive. Their decor is fun and our server had green hair!

I will be back if I am in the area but I don't think I will go out of my way to come back. It is a tad pricey for ramen. Next time, I will try their sake in a can!
author: Vanessa Y.

description:
First, let me say, I'm not a ramen kind of girl. 

I'll eat it but do not go out of my way for it. Even when in Japan I wasn't in awe of it. But I really love the broth in the Beyond Ramen. It's not as heavy as the Orenchi Ramen. Not sure what the difference is but it's lighter, more complex, and much easier for me to slurp down than the standard tonkatsu broth I'm used to. 

The hamachi carpaccio tasted a bit "fishy". The chicken karaage was good but was surprised to see it was served on the bone and covered in a glaze. The house sake is served in individual glasses, which is again, odd to me. 

Love the modern, open design. There's a window so that you can watch the ramen magic happening. Service is great. They didn't make us feel guilty when me and my friend stayed from open to close. Literally.

Tip: Get there early. A line starts forming before opening.
author: Kristine W.

description:
Big names like Orenchi have a lot to live up to, and although I haven't tried the one in Santa Clara, I didn't find the ramen here to be that special. 

I had the Beyond Ramen, and I thought the noodles were pretty good. They were slightly thick with a firm bite and chewy texture. The tonkotsu broth had a nice creamy mouth feel, but it tasted a little off balance. The broth had too much of an earthy flavor. I'm thinking it could be too much kombu or shiitake. The toppings weren't memorable either besides the well cooked egg. I barely even noticed the thinly sliced piece of chashu. I dunno. I think for the price range, it should've been more thoughtfully crafted.
author: Nei N.

description:
Yum yum. All your South Bay Orenchi goodness but with more manageable lines and in the lovely city of SF. Also a better location--since you're actually in Mission, there's actually stuff to go do/more to eat around the area rather as compared to the strip mall that Orenchi South Bay is located in.

My friend and i strategically showed up at 5:40 on a Saturday night. I was definitely pretty nervous about showing up that late.. but we were lucky enough to be on the earlier half of the first wave of people who went in. I'm definitely much happier waiting twenty minutes which I think is totally reasonable. Parking can be tough here, especially on a weekday night, so you want to definitely a) use the buddy system, drop someone in your group off to write your name down b) leave enough time to find parking because if your entire party isn't there when you're called, tough luck, you're skipped over

I went for the classic Orenchi goods--karage and their classic Orenchi ramen. I know this place is famous for Orenchi Beyond ramen, but I really just wanted my good ole Orenchi ramen. It's the exact same goodness that you experience from South Bay. The karaage is seriously some of the best karaage that I've ever had--super meaty, great flavor, and awesome portion sizes as an appetizer. Orenchi ramen is perfect broth and delicious al dente noodles. I will say the usual caveats for Orenchi--the soup is very oily and difficult to completely finish. You'll love the first sip, but my guess is that you'll probably end up not finishing the whole thing because it'll be way too oily. The egg is considered one of the best soft boiled eggs in the area but having had quite a bit of ramen in the last few months, I actually think the Orenchi egg pales. I think the egg is perfectly cooked and it's amazing how they maintain the yolk while the exterior is solid. BUT, this egg is not an ajitama--aka it's not marinated in something ... or if it is you definitely don't taste whatever it's marinated in. It's a good egg, but just not as flavorful as the soup.

But okay at the end of the day despite my qualms... I have yet to find a better place than Orenchi. It's hip and maybe some might say it's overhyped.. but yo let's be real. you can be a hater and hate the lines, but you're not going to find ramen that's any better in SF. That's why you're standing in line. Plus they have a bar so it's not even that bad. They make waiting trendy. That's good marketing.

tldr; still my favorite ramen place in the Bay Area.. glad to see that they have this new hip trendy place in Mission!
author: Jasmine X.

description:
Was kind of reluctant to try Orenchi Beyond since I was not at all impressed with their mother store in San Jose.

The only reason I came here was because the boyfriend hasn't tried this place and its only a 2 minutes walk from his house. 

Arrived approx 5 mins before they opened and they already generated a waitlist (Sunday Night), but luckily we still made it into the first round of customers. 

I got the Beyond Ramen that is exclusive to this location and to my surprise it was much better than their Orenchi Ramen at the other location (I thought that one was bland as "*** and could not for the life of me understand the hype what so ever. Like, it legitimately totally sucked and made me questioned what everyone else was thinking) 
It's more flavorful than the Orenchi Ramen by folds but its still not the best ramen. 

That same night, I saw others that also went to Orenchi Beyond but their wait was not as pleasant - Waited for 45 mins to eat for 10 mins.

Overall, Orenchi Beyond is not bad if I want a quick bite around the time they open. But they are definitely not worth the wait of more than 30 mins.  

Dont forget that parking is not friendly in the area.
author: Harriet W.

description:
YUM.  Hands down, best ramen in the city.

As always, come prepared for crowds.  But on the plus - you can enjoy a beer at their bar while waiting, or chance it and head over to Zeitgeist while making one chosen friend the "spot checker".

If you come before opening, better make sure it's at least an hour.  Then you can actually go to Zeitgeist, and rest assured no names will be called til opening.

Or, go on the later side - we only waited 20 minutes once.

Out of the 5+ times I've already gone (it helps when the bf lives 2 blocks away) - average wait time was an hour.

But you get REALLY good ramen, with a tasty broth, al dente thick noodles, an egg (if you get the Orenchi ramen, my favorite), and pork.  It's pretty good value.

AND a great selection of appetizers - wasabi ocotopus, chicken karaage, etc.
author: Adele Z.

description:
Okay so we're from Idaho and love San Francisco. That being said we've never had authentic Ramen before. We love everything that involves noodles. While we were walking to another restaurant after just getting into town we stumbled upon Orenchi Beyond. My head spun and my brother asked a random diner how he rated it! From then we were sold. 

The Beyond ramen was amazing! Everything you could ask in a bowl of noodles. If all ramen is like this then we're fans, but we would probably be fans anyways. I definitely recommend Orenchi Beyond to anyone wanting a great bowl of Ramen. Oh, and their spicy fries with wasabi fry sauce was out of this world!!
author: Eric J.

description:
As a self proclaimed ramen veteran, I can safely vouch for the quality at orenchi beyond!  The first time I came I ordered the "Beyond".  Very disappointed.  Don't order that.  Stick with the "Orenchi Ramen".  It's a bit low on meat, but its broth, noodles, and portion are spot on.  If you're willing to shell out $12 for a great bowl of ramen, this one's worth it. In SF, I'd consider it among the best options (in the same conversation as peninsula greats - Santa Ramen, Orenchi, Santouka)

Also the spicy karaage is a bit odd.  More like chicken wings with some sauce poured over it.  Stick w the regular karaage!
author: Warren C.

description: They welcome you in Japanese when you enter, which surprisingly not a lot of ramen places I've been to in SF do that. It was spacious and there were a lot of seats. I was expecting there to be a long line for dinner considering their Santa Clara location is really popular. Surprisingly there were only a handful of diners at the time I entered. I ordered the Beyond ramen with a soft boiled egg. The ramen noodle was rather short. Considering that Orenchi is extremely popular, I was surprised that their ramen did not taste extraordinary.
author: James S.

description:
I'm a fan of fatty Tonkotsu broth and noodles with bite, I'm an even bigger fan of not driving to the South Bay to get my name on the wait list an hour+ before open.

Get: Cha Su Gohan (pork + rice bowl).

Bonus: The seats are low and the table high for optimal ramen slurping.
author: James G.

description:
There is a lot of hype around Orenchi and so my family and I dined here to see what the fuss is about.
We got there about 30 mins before opening to secure a prompt seating.
First off, the service was not great. They spilled 3 waters while trying to serve our table and it made a huge mess. The waiter was not really apologetic and my dad's pants got wet from the spill. Nothing was done to rectify the situation and they (in true Asian style) tried to "throw it under the rug."
On to the food! The karaage was decent but nothing to write home about. I ordered the "Beyond" Ramen and was beyond underwhelmed. Meat serving was measly and broth was too salty. The noodles had a great bite but that's about it. I left feeling pretty unsatisfied.

Overall, pretty disappointed and won't be back. My mission for a great bowl of ramen in SF continues.
author: Angela D.

description:
The ramen was good, I don't think it compared as well to Orenchi in South Bay. The construction of the bowl wasn't as tantalizing, but the broth and noodles were good. The Beyond ramen had an interesting flavor to it, a little reminiscent of soba sauce. The ramen portions seemed smaller, or maybe I was just really hungry?

I liked the karaage more than the karaage in Santa Clara, but all the other appetizers were a miss for me. Over-flavored and rich, especially the braised pork belly.

Big bonus is that the wait was super short. :P Went there on a Friday night and got seated within a minute.
author: Kathy Z.

description:
I came here for dinner when everyone was preoccupied with the world series and less interested in ramen, so thankfully there was only a 15 minute wait for a table.  This is seemingly unheard of nowadays- I went back last Wednesday and was quoted a two hour wait as a conservative estimate.  

So the ramen here is good.  Really good...and I'm surprised that some other yelpers don't  agree..  Believe me, I've eaten at nearly every single ramen joint in SF proper, and none of these places even come close in comparison.  It's all about the broth, of course, and they've got then intense porky flavor down and all of the depth of flavor we've come to expect in a good bowl of ramen, complete with plenty of fat globules in the broth.  

Haven't tried any of their small plates or izakaya type appetizers yet, but maybe someday if I ever have the patience to wait for a table...
author: Joanne G.

description:
Late Saturday night dinner in none other than my favorite city, San Francisco! And you can never go wrong with Japanese, in my opinion, especially ramen. :)

The service was good and waiter was attentive in the small, urban establishment. I'd says about half or just over that amount of the restaurant was full of patrons. 

I sampled my friend's appetizers of fries, which were quite tasty with the right amount of crispness out of the fryer. The wasabi dipping sauce, which I stupidly mistook for a ranch, was very potent and definitely will open up your sinuses with a generous fry dip. Tebasaki Owariage chicken wings were finger-licking good! The sweet sauce on the crispy exterior was just right.

For my main dish I chose the Chu-Ka Soba. The broth was too salty for me though and left me chugging water at the end. There was a generous amount of noodles but skimped a little on the menma (bamboo shoots). 

As a lover of ramen, especially the tender and fatty tonkotsu though, I would come back and just be sure to hydrate throughout my meal.
author: Malika H.

description:
Orenchi Beyond is the hip little sister to its peninsula location. There's street art on the walls, polished wooden tables + chairs, a dimly lit dining area, and an open kitchen (with glass walls surrounding it) that showcase cauldrons of delicious ramen broth. There's even a cool DJ turntable setup with a Daft Punk vinyl!  

I have to say, the ramen overall tastes better here than at it's Santa Clara location. There's better tenacity and slightly better body with fuller flavor in their tonkatsu broth. The service is parallel to what you would receive in Clara' - tentative, yet not pushy, with a genuine smile.  

The appetizers here are a mixed bag. Some are great, such as the hamachi carpaccio and fried white fish on a stick. While others such as the karaage and beef carpaccio miss their marks. The karaage was oddly on the bone and didn't have much flavor. They tasted like a basic chicken wing. The beef carpaccio, although tasty, was cold which killed it's palatable appeal. 

Would I dine at OB again?  Absolutely!  My friend and I enjoyed our experience so much that we literally drank sake and ate from open to close on a Thursday night. Crazy, I know, but this place is awesome with excellent service!  Keep up the great job guys n' gals!
author: Josh S.

description:
It's... Alright. Typical ramen place. Love how there was no line or much of a wait. The waiters are friendly... One even told us about his day (weird?)

I ordered the orenchi ramen and it was... Well... Your typical ramen made with a creamy broth, half boiled egg, piece of pork, bamboo shoots, etc.

I always compare my ramen to Santouka, my favorite ramen place and this place did not come close. It's decent but I probably would not get out of my way to eat here again.

We also ordered the fried chicken.
author: Carin S.

description:
If you love Japanese Ramen, or any kind of ramen, I totally recommend going here. The broth is so rich and full of amazing mouth watering textures. If you're reading this review, you better just turn of yelp and head over to Orenchi Beyond right now! The spicy miso Tsukemen is one of my favorite dishes. Just the perfect amount of broth and base that creates a wonderful mouth-gasm! I totally recommend the appetizers, especially the hamachi Carpacio. I've never tried a dish so sweet and delicious and mouth watering before in my life. The sister restaurant in Santa Clara is equally the same when it comes to service and food! If there's one word that can describe Orenchi Beyond, it'd be amazing. The staff is incredible with the service. Kind, generous, respectful, you name it! This place is definitely a must go and a check on your bucket list. Come to Orenchi beyond if you really want fine delicious ramen or come for the delicious appetizers! Now stop readying this Review and have yourself the best Ramen you could ever try! 


P.S.  the wait may be 15 to 20 minutes (but we all know that if any Ramen spot has a wait, it's definitely worth it!
author: Raymond T.

description: Tried the Santa Clara location, wasn't a fan and decided to give the Mission location another try and sadly, still not a fan of their ramen. Soup is too oily/fatty for me. Karaage is decent and enjoyed the ikura soft egg donburi. Long waits as well though you can pass the time at the second hand furniture shop next door -- huge place to wander around, like going to a flea market.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
I really wanted to like this more, given all the hype from the South Bay location, but after eating here twice, I'm still convinced that Ramen Dojo in San Mateo is the best ramen in the Bay Area. (I have yet to go to Orenchi in the South Bay).

I came here shortly after it opened, and thought it was some of the best ramen in SF - the noodles were fresh and chewy, the broth was flavorful and rich and you can add in extra goodies: extra noodles, pork, etc. The ramen is reasonably & appropriately priced at $12. I got the Beyond Ramen the first time and the Orenchi Ramen the second time, but thought the Beyond Ramen was overpowered by the garlic. The person I was with ordered the normal Orenchi Ramen and it was better.

The second time I went, I ordered the Orenchi Ramen but it was too salty I couldn't finish it. I'm not sure if it was a fluke or not, but I was not sober, and it was too salty.

The appetizers are nice for sharing but nothing amazing - the Age Takoyaki (deep fried octopus dumpling) were good (but what deep fried thing doesn't taste good?) but a bit on the heavy side with too much sauce. The eggplant was good, and the other appetizers I've tried were not memorable and I can't remember.

On a Saturday night around 8 pm, be prepared to wait for about an hour for a group larger than 4. This is a popular place, so be patient, or go to Japantown to find cheaper ramen, and probably more restaurants. 

The ambiance is nice, wooden and hipster but it's like almost eating in a club because it's so loud and the music is loud as well. Probably not recommended for a date with someone you've just met, as you'll be yelling across the table to each other.

All in all, a decent choice for ramen if you're in the area. I may try it one more time to verify how salty the broth really is (another friend recently confirmed he found it too salty). I'll probably stick to ramen places in Japantown or make the trek to Ramen Dojo, unless I'm in the area and this is convenient. I'd also stick to the ramen instead of all the other small dishes.
author: Christina L.

description: This was our 2nd try to dine here. The first time we arrived at 5:30pm on a weekday, and we were put on the second wave on the wait list and knew the wait will be over an hour so we left. Now the second time we went, it was during the big rain storm and we got there half an hour before they opened and we were number 2 on the list! So highly recommend going there half an hour early and put your name on the list or come during a major storm. So we were seated right at 6pm, and exactly 10 mins later our 2 bowls of ramen arrived. Very quick but unfortunately they forgot to give us nori in both of our bowls. The table next to us got theirs. They were probably rushing. We definitely felt rushed. They get really busy. The ramen is really good here but I wouldn't wait over an hour for it.
author: Vinkin Ken T.

description:
We went for the soft opening today - their grand opening according to their site is 10/28. Just across the street from Zeitgeist on Valencia.

Delicious ramen, by far my favorite in SF now. My friend got the Orenchi Ramen and I got the Beyond Ramen and we shared the Nankotsu Karaage and Takoyaki. I had a sip of my friend's Orenchi Ramen - the broth was simple, light and delicious. Beyond's broth was a bit more complex, but also delicious (also love garlic and mizuna :D) The egg was cooked to perfection and the noodles were cooked perfectly. The umeshu ginger cocktail was also delicious; highly recommend it.

On top of delicious food, service was stellar (staff was attentive, and service was quick for a full house!) 
My other Japanese friends have also recommended the Tori Soba. I'll have to come back and try that!
author: Food E.

description:
Went to the soft opening on 10/25. Usually soft openings are for practice but the service was awesome and it felt like they've been doing this for years.

Food was so good. Not much else to say about it. If you're craving for ramen and you're in SF, there's probably not going to be a better place than Orenchi Beyond.

The atmosphere was really cool and laid back. It's a little loud with the music playing (they have a DJ booth) and the alcohol flowing but you can still have a good conversation with the people across your table without having to yell at them. It's definitely a fun place to eat.

I thought the price of the food and drinks were normal. Yes, they do have some pretty expensive drinks but you pay to play I guess. The price of the ramen is well worth it. Best ramen in SF hands down.
author: Steven T.

description:
Orenchi has changed my perception of ramen forever. Easily the best I've had. If you're a fan of garlic, this ramen will tickle your fancy and then some. Their main ramens are the Orenchi and the Beyond, with a shoyu and shio base (not quite sure what shio is) respectively. Each with their own great flavor but with the garlic kick aforementioned. Another notable dish would be the fried chicken wings. Fried to a wonderful crisp with that sweet, Asian type glaze. I've also had the salmon flakes and roe rice bowl. Kinda weird because I'm not a huge fan or salmon roe, especially the larger eggs, but still pretty good. 

Overall, the food and vibes of this place are wonderful!
author: Gabriel G.

description:
Well Maruyama-san you have done it again. As the 'Ramen Wars' continue Orenchi Beyond has hit San Francisco by storm.  I am a huge fan of Orenchi and now Orenchi Beyond . 
Simply the best!
author: Mike F.

description:
I was roaming the streets of the mission one night and was hit wit a ramen craving. I'd passed this place earlier in the day, and made a mental note that I needed to try it. As a solo diner, ramen places are usually a good bet because you can squeeze yourself into that nook at the bar where no duo or posse could possibly take root.

I put my name on the list and waited outside with some other parties who sipped sake and imported beer they were served from the walk up bar window. After a short wait (others had a much longer wait), I was called to take a seat at the bar.

They had a full DJ dual deck setup in the northwest corner of the kitchen, and it was blasting some hip techno crappola. I'm glad I didn't need to do much talking. The room is pretty acoustically untreated. (Who would care besides an audio engineer?) The room had interesting art though.

There I ordered a house hot sake, the Karaage, and a bowl of the ramen (the regular one, not the beyond). The Karaage was great for any fried chicken lover. It was not salty and was very moist. The sake did the job.

For the main event, the ramen was good, but not the most spectacular ramen I'd ever had. It definitely had a very umami funk to it, probably owed to the fermented bamboo shoots or something. The pork was good, the broth rich, the noodles firm. I felt like the noodles were the best executed, slightly softer than al dente. At Ken Ken, the noodles are pretty much vermicelli (which I don't like {but their broth is good}), and at my #1 all-time, go-to, don't-give-a-flying-crap-how-long-you-need-to-wait favorite ramen place, Ramen Dojo (San Mateo), they are slightly softer. The egg in the ramen was soft-boiled, but cold. Obviously they were prepared much earlier in the day but weren't heated enough to be warm in the broth. Other places don't let this happen, and the egg is usually one of the highlights of the meal. This time it was not.

Overall, I would go here again if I were in the city, in the area, there was no wait and I was suddenly stricken by a hunger for ramen...but if I were setting a day aside special to go get ramen, I would likely not go here.
author: Michael M.

description:
Brand new Orenchi Ramen location. Not so crowded as in Santa Clara. Very friendly and lovely staff. 
We came here at 6pm on Sunday and there was no line:) 
P.S. Beyond ramen was awesome!
author: Vladimir K.

description:
I had big expectations of this place just because everyone said the Orenchi in Santa Clara was amazing, and I was sadly disappointed. For $12, I got the Orenchi Ramen. The piece of pork that showed up was kind of pathetic, and the soft boiled egg was perfectly cooked but under seasoned. The broth itself wasn't bad but I felt like it didn't stack up to the broth at Izakaya Sozai, and the ramen noodles themselves were a little too chewy for my taste. 

Overall, Orenchi is alright if you're in the area and need a quick fix (I was late, but my friends got seated immediately at 7:40pm on a Sunday). If you're looking for good ramen, stick to Japantown/Sunset/Richmond!
author: Grace C.

description:
I am absolutely obsessed with ramen, good ramen and Orenchi Beyond makes it onto my top favorite ramen spots! I love the atmosphere (especially the bar/waiting area), the servers were rad and the ramen was great!

I got the Orenchi Ramen which was really good. The noodles were great, the soft boiled egg was to die for, but the broth was not as thick or porky and pork belly was tough, yet still overall yummy!
author: Aaron G.

description:
The ramen here is ok. Not great or horrible. The selection wasn't huge compared to other places. There's only four choices for a whopping price of $13- two of them are tonkatsu base and the other two was chicken broth base. I got the regular Orenchi ramen which is tonkatsu base with shio and my bf got a large beyond ramen which is tonkatsu base with shiyo. The orenchi ramen soup tasted creamier and the beyond ramen soup was a bit more savory. I thought my bowl of ramen was kind of sad. After my meal, I regretted not getting a large which is $2 extra because I was still kinda hungry. I felt content while my bf didn't leave still feeling hungry. You only get one thinly sliced piece of char-sui. It was so thin it fell apart in my soup and I had to go digging for it. So for the value of the meal, I don't think it's worth it because there's plenty of other places that are cheaper and taste just as great. However, the only thing that was spectacular was the egg! It was really orange and the yolk was still liquidy. It was bursting with flavor unlike other places where it lacks flavor. 

If you're coming during a busy time, I recommend sitting at the bar so you get seated quicker. 
Also, good luck finding parking!
author: Anne H.

description:
I have been to a handful of ramen places.  Orenchi in Santa Clara is definitely one of my top three picks.  Naturally, I had high expectations for the food and service at this location too.  

The GF and I came here at 6:00 pm prime time.  The wait was said to be 1 hour and 30 minutes.  It was closer to almost two hours though.  We walked around a for awhile, and ended up coming back with thirty minutes still to go.  So, we decided to people watch.  Just to provide some visual insight of this establishment, someone has accidentally placed an odd shaped rock in front of the restaurant.  . People sit on this rock, but I doubt it is very comfortable.  A bench would have been more practical.  A few feet in front of the rock are little openings where one is able to order drinks from the bar while waiting for seats.  I have speculated that this is quite popular amongst these hipsters.  The actual restaurant is "open", for lack of a better word.  What I mean by this is that air is able to pass freely between the dining area to the outside and vice versa, with the exception of a few pieces of glass.  I appreciate this at a ramen place because I can imagine it gets quite hot, and if there is glass everywhere, lots of steam would be produced, fogging up all the windows.   

After our names were called, we were led into the very first spots located at the bar area.  Although, they did not ask if we wanted to sit here (as we usually rather sit at tables), we did not question it because the wait would have probably been another thirty minutes.  All the workers greeted us as we took our seats.   After we sat down, we noticed how uncomfortable sitting at the tables looked.  If I remember correctly, the chairs are tree stumps, and they are very low.  This might have been my mind playing tricks.  After all, I was sitting on a very high chair at the bar.  

We decided to order as soon as we sat down.  We decided on the chicken karaage, spicy fries, and two Orenchi Ramens, one with an extra egg, and the other with extra noodles. We wanted to try the corn tempura but they did not have any! :(

The appetizers naturally came out first.  The fries came out fast.  Basically, this dish is comprised of shortly cut seasoned fries with a spicy dipping sauce placed on the side.  The fries are good, while the sauce is just okay.  It was definitely worth trying, but a bit overpriced.  The karaage came about five to ten minutes later.  I was taken aback because I have always known karaage to consist of no bones.  I asked the waitress if this was our dish, and she explained that it was.  The wings tasted really good.  They were tangy and crispy, kind of reminding me of San Tung wings.  

The noodles took quite a while to come out which is very surprising.  I would think they have a giant pot cooking the endless supply of broth, and ten pounds of noodles being cooked every minute.  Regardless, we were both very happy when it came out.  We dug right in and it was definitely worth the wait.  My favorite part of the ramen hands down is the egg.  It amazes me how the soft boiled egg is perfectly cooked.  When I cut into the egg and the yolk just oozes out a rich creamy liquid.  

Orenchi is a must try.  I would say it is worth the wait.  The bill came out to $50 which isn't too bad.  I will be back!
author: Victor L.

description:
Lines for this place form quick!

You should get here at least 30 min before they open as they start a sign up sheet around then. 

I came here about an hour early...too early lol. So I went across the street to Zeitgeist for a beer then came back.

Luckily, I was within the first 10 groups to sign up so I managed to get one of the first seating right when they opened. Also if you have a smaller group, you'll have a better chance to be seated earlier/on time.

We ordered as soon as we were seated. The menu is not that extensive, also if you have been to other ramen joints, you know the drill! Orenchi beyond, offers 2 types of ramen - Orenchi or Beyond. The Beyond ramen is only available at this location so obviously my friend and I ordered this. There's a slew of toppings and add ins you can do. Being overwhelmed, we went for the safe choice of adding a soft boiled egg to our ramens. We also started with the age takoyaki as I'm a fan of takoyaki and will always order this if its available. 

The takoyaki was a great starter! Lots of yummy aioli and bonito flakes. The Beyond ramen was really good as well! The egg was perfectly cooked! Also I like my ramen to be hella flavorful so I used a lot of the minced garlic and spicy flakes condiments to punch up the flavor in my ramen. Soooo goood. I love how they have minced garlic and the spicy flakes on each table for your use. I really enjoyed the beyond ramen as all the flavors of the toppings, the noodles and the broth just complemented each other perfectly. After eating all my noodles, I was still drinking spoonfuls of the delish broth!

I would highly recommend this place to any ramen eater! :)
author: Christine W.

description:
This place is a great addition to the Mission - good food, modern / industrial atmosphere.  It's hard to get into, though, so plan ahead!

We stopped by around 5:15pm on a Saturday, 45 minutes before it opened, to put our names down on the list.  We strolled around and came back at 6:00 (opening time) and found a huge crowd and long line. The only reason we got in without waiting in line was because we had put our names down early.

My husband and I both had the Orenchi ramen, which had a rich, flavorful broth.  The spicy chicken karaage was also good.  I enjoyed my plum wine and ginger ale cocktail (I forget what it's called).

We enjoyed our partial view into the glass walled kitchen where the food is prepared.

The service was decent (though our appetizer took quite a while to arrive, and came after we for our ramen).
author: Barnali D.

description:
5 stars if you ever get better noodles!

PROS:
- Great music
- Cool wall art
- Modern ambiance and decor
- Beyond ramen
- One of the best ramen shops in SF
- Location at the top of the Mission near Zeitgeist
- Usually no wait

CONS:
- Okay service
- Okay value
author: Lisa H.

description:
Okay! So the famous Orenchi Ramen from South Bay finally landed in the city!

I was super excited about it. I love Orenchi Ramen in Santa Clara - their broth is really unbeatable (in US only, of course) but the huge crowd + crazy long line always make me hesitate going there.

Went on a Saturday evening - yup, no except in this location. I think Orenchi Beyond SF has opened for a month now? Just to tell you some facts:

- It opens at 6pm on Saturday; I arrived at 5:50pm and I was #33 on the list
- Got sit-in at 8:05pm (party of 1)

Good thing is, the store design of Orenchi Beyond is kind of unique. Next to the entrance there's a mini-bar where they sell beer/sake/appetizer etc. So if you go with a group of friends, or even by yourself, grabbing a beer or two will definitely help kill some time. You may think "oh, can I just order a bowl of ramen there and stand+eat?" Nope, someone tried and got rejected. It will be really cool if they serve this style though, just like those street ramen carts in Japan.

Looking at the menu, "Orenchi Ramen" is certainly there; but there's also a "Beyond Ramen" and this is only served in this location. Whoa, let's go for that.

[Beyond Ramen]: A 

- Soup: Once the bowl came I took a sip of the soup: my first feeling was that it's 70% similar to "Orenchi Ramen"'s broth with the additional flavor of garlic and a type of vege, which I suspect it's kale. The taste of this vege might be a bit too strong for first-time-beyond-ramen'er but after a while I felt totally fine. In fact, the aftertaste of Beyond soup was better than Orenchi's soup, in a way that it felt less fatty but still left a layer of thin soup film on your tongue. The extra garlic that I added to the soup must have contributed to some of that feeling.

- Noodle: It might be me but I felt the noodle was slightly thinner than Orenchi South Bay's. It's still very chewy though, and maintained the "hard-boiled" texture.

- Pork: the menu said "pork belly" is included but it's more like slices of pork belly (aka cha-shu style) rather than chunk style. It was soft and completely absorbed concentration from the soup.

- Egg: **NOTE** Egg is not included in Beyond Ramen by default; it can be added as a topping and of course I did: it's soft-boiled and the quality was comparable to South Bay's.

Well, so why not a 5-star? Honestly, I don't mind the wait because the food is just too good, but I don't feel I was treated equally just because I was party of 1.... I was so excited to see my name on the list being the next one to be called; but instead, the server skipped my name and jumped to the name after me, which was party of two - and not only once but twice! So I had to go in and talked with the server; she pretended nothing happened and said "oh, you are party of one? [walked in and looked around] sorry we don't have a seat now" YES I KNOW because 4 people were just sit-in (at the bar table). So I decided to stand inside the restaurant to wait just to remind her that I'm there; and finally, after another 10-15 mins, I was offered a seat at the bar table -_- She maintained a nice attitude the whole time so I wasn't mad; but still, I'm a customer too, if it's because of certain policy that bigger size party should be sit in first - tell me and I would be fine with it. Skipping me was just kind of rude.... 

Anyway, I guess I will come back, probably trying the real Orenchi Ramen to see if there's any difference comparing with South Bay's; and next time I will be sure to grab at least one more person with me.
author: Simon C.

description:
I highly recommend that everyone arrive about 40-45min before it opens to put your name down. This guarantees you a spot for sure, avoiding the hour long waits.

Orenchi Beyond is definitely very modern, with their very own DJ table in the corner as well as barrel seats. An outdoor bar is also available so customers can have a drink while waiting.

-Orenchi Ramen ($12): al dente ramen noodles cooked to perfection, served with bamboo shoots, kikurage mushrooms, a soft boiled egg, one slice of pork belly, and seaweed. They use a very delicious chicken and pork broth, cooked for at least 18 hours.  I usually prefer tonkotsu Kotteri or tonkotsu, but their soup still went very well with the noodles. Overall, the ramen noodles stood out to me the most. Honestly one of the best. The pork slice was extremely delicious and melted in my mouth, but it was paper thin ): the soft boiled egg was cooked perfectly, but lacked flavor.

-Beyond Ramen ($12): basically the Orenchi Ramen but with fried garlic, veggies, but no egg. The broth and everything was the same 

They also have a wide selections of appetizers so that was a definite plus!

Overall, I think the ramen is on point. However, I don't think that it is worth $12 for the amount that they give :l I recommend that guys get the larger portion for $1.50 more to get full. 

I would come again though, because the ramen noodles were really delicious.
author: Jackie T.

description: We've been coming here every few weeks for two years, with a toddler in tow, and this place keeps getting better and better! I love the introduction of the vegan ramen, and the to-go option. All the soups have been delicious and the side dishes offer nice variety and flavor. The staff has been incredibly friendly to the toddler and very helpful, which makes for extra special experience.
author: Olga Z.

description:
First impression/thoughts : (just got off the plane, really hungry, about 8:30)  3 groups of 4-5, 3 groups of 2-3 ahead of my party of 2. its a warm night out, kind of out of character for the season. Love the open bar area thats made for people who are waiting to get seated. A gripload of people, but expected a long wait so I'm at peace with it, despite my empty tummy. 

2 beers on tap. Sapporo and Stone Warrior. Warrior beer is chocolatey (like a stout) but not like a stout in its texture(?)(not familiar with descriptive beer terms) high carbonation level, light. Served in hipster tin cups. 5$ for sapporo, $6.80 for stone.

30 min later: 1 group of 4 ahead of me. Being (uncharacteristically) patient tonight. Or maybe just really wanted to bust out my "pen"manship. Omg getting seated now. Ty yelp gods. 

Seated at bar, friendly staff.  I ordered orenchi ramen, bf orders orenchi ramen large (aka extra noodles). Comes out in less than 10 min. Minced/mashed garlic and redpepper on the side for preference. 

30 min later. Empty bowl. Great hearty broth.  Chewy noodles. I like mine not so chewy but i was so hungry i devoured it. 

Would i come back? Eh..idk if i would actively seek it out (i am a spice fiend and orenchi didnt have a spicy broth option) but id be down to join if a friend(s) wanted to come here.
author: Jane C.

description:
Pretty darned good! Word of this location spread fast, and seems like it's been super crowded ever since. Came on a Friday night around 8pm and the place was packed. The wait was around 40 minutes, but since it was a rainy night we decided to stay put.  There's a bar that faces the outside, so it's easy enough to get a drink while you wait. There is also plenty of space outside to sit or stand around for the long haul. We did notice that around 9pm there was really no wait, to keep that in mind for next time.

When we finally sat, we had:
Takoyaki - $7.50 for 6 pieces - octopus balls!! these were really good, tasted pretty fresh and was a great appetizer, although a bit filling... but then again, my stomach was full of beer from drinking already!
Beyond Ramen - only offered at Beyond. This is a slightly sweeter broth, and does not come with an egg
Orenchi Ramen - this is the original Orenchi that everyone knows and loves. The noodles are just right, the broth is flavorful, and there's a really soft boiled egg, made just right. I definitely preferred the original broth over the beyond broth, but my friend thought the opposite. 

Service was prompt and friendly, restrooms are clean, and the ramen ranks up there for SF. I would put it in my top 2 in the city, especially since it's conveniently located in the mission. Will be back!
author: Lily C.

description:
Really hip and beautiful modern decor, in the middle of a really weird block with auto repair and the like.   They even had an assortment of records in the back with a DJ.  We had no wait, but it's only because they just opened for lunch this weekend and no one knew about it yet.   

We ordered the Orenchi Ramen.  The broth was good, as were the chewy noodles.  The pork, mushrooms, bamboo, and egg were all very good.   The difference between the Beyond and Orenchi is apparently that the former is a soy-based pork broth and more intense on the garlic, while the Orenchi is salt-based, with softer noodles and an egg.  Either way, we were pleased with the Orenchi, except that we were also super thirsty afterwards. 

We also ordered the ankamo monk liver, which was very good, and the salmon roe gohan, which has salmon roe, an egg and rice. This was surprisingly not warm, and lacked a bit of flavor.  

Overall, it was a good meal but it would be hard to get excited about an hour long wait, which is what it sounds like dinner requires.
author: Vivian W.

description:
Ordered the orenchi ramen and the beyond ramen here. The orenchi is a little richer and saltier while the beyond is lighter and has a strong garlic flavor. I liked both soup bases. The noodles are exactly the same. The Orenchi ramen comes with an egg while the beyond ramen does not. If you order the beyond, I highly recommend adding an egg. Orenchi is known for their amazing soft-boiled egg and for good reason! 

The ambience of this restaurant is very hipster so it fits perfectly in the mission. It's definitely not like it's sister restaurant down in san jose. I haven't been there in a while so i can't really compare the ramen :( I thought Orenchi beyond was pretty good. I'm glad so many good ramen joints are opening up in SF. 

I came here on a friday night with my BF and didn't have to wait at all! I would recommend coming here in smaller groups (2). They're not great for groups.

Oh, also, their large pot of hot tea is quite expensive. ($9! while ramens are $12) I didn't know the tea would be so expensive. I just ordered it thinking it would be free or priced more reasonably. I'd probably skip the tea next time.
author: Annie Z.

description: Orenchi Beyond is the sister restaurant of Orenchi in Santa Clara, and I was excited to learn that it's less than a mile away from my house! The broth of this ramen is amazing.  It's rich in flavor, but not too heavy. It came with pork belly, a poached egg, and seaweed.   While the small was good for me, I would say it's definitely worth it to pay extra for the bigger portion.  The decor was modern and hip, but there wasn't a ton of seating.  However, we got there 15 minutes before they opened, so we didn't really have to wait long at all.
author: Jenny C.

description: I had draft sake and tsukemen ramen (crab-based sauce) and both were delicious! The portion was large and there was a good spread of veggies on top of the ramen. I enjoyed the fun ambience and trendy decor, and the place was clean and neat. Definitely worth going alone or with friends for yummy and quality comfort food. Right off the 101, too!
author: J C.

description:
I came here for ramen with friends on a Sunday night, and was pleased that the wait was not going to be hours long (like other dining options in the city). I ordered the large version of the Orenchi Ramen, and I thought the noodles and everything inside of my bowl was absolutely delicious! I remember enjoying every bite of it! The only thing that I wish would be that there be a spicy option for the broth (not a huge necessity, but that would have made things all the more flavorful). We also ordered the spicy chicken karage, and that was a great choice as well! The chicken wings came out nicely sauced and seasoned, but were also crispy and had a nice texture to it. 

Service was pretty attentive as well, which is always a plus! I didn't need to stop them constantly for water because they conveniently leave a jug on the table. I think the only downside from my dining experience would be that the tables here are communal. You share a table with strangers sitting next to you, so there is not a lot of room for privacy here. Those water jugs are also shared on the table. While nice for the atmosphere, the chairs that we sat on I thought were also not the most comfortable. They had no backing, so it wasn't the most comfy dining experience...but thankfully the food was great! Definitely would not mind coming back to eat here again!
author: Daniel H.

description:
They're open for lunch! Maybe I like it more just because they're fast, close to my work, and solid, but that should account for a lot. Although, I might be bumping them up a star just because of those things. There are really just 2 types of ramen that are offered here and 2 types of soba with very little variation.

Service is really fast, the broth is a bit oily for the ramen, but rich and good. The garlic flavor really comes out in the beyond ramen, don't let people take a whiff of you without warning them.

They have a few rice/gohan small bowls too, but we didn't love any of them we tried so far. Overall, if you just want a bowl of nice chewy hot noodles, go on and get it. Not too much meat in the bowls either, but the bowls are pretty full of toppings.
author: Annie S.

description:
Very disappointed in this new joint. This ramen place wasn't opened too long ago and is already experiencing issues.. Got there around 6:30pm to only find out that their noodle machine broke and is closed for the night.. Not sure what the employees are eating inside if the noodle machine is broken...

Oh by the way.. Very difficult to find parking.
author: Samson L.

description:
So much hype, was expecting more. 

It's definitely the trendiest ramen spot around here, but the ramen just isn't what I had hoped for. I'm a huge fan of Santa ramen in San Mateo and love the noodles at katanaya but not the broth as much. Here, the bamboo in the ramen made the bowl smell fishy to me which was rather off putting and I think the tonkatsu ramen broth surprised me at how super fatty it was you could see the fat particles and it still wasn't as tasty as Santa ramens pork broth. 

We were lucky and barely had to wait since it was 8:30pm by the time we arrived. Had we waited for an hour or more than the 5 mins or so we did this would have been a 2 star review, simply not worth the wait.
author: Melody T.

description:
The ramen itself is average. But it's definitely NOT worth that 1 hr and 45 min wait!!

We got there around 6:30pm and for a party of 2, there were 11 parties before us. It DOES NOT take almost 2 hours to turn over 11 parties. They have a pretty decent seating size too. The original Orenchi's in Santa Clara takes about 20 mins to turnover 11 tables. While we were waiting, I noticed some empty tables and it took some time for a server to bring in the next party, which plays some part in the delay of turning over tables. Also, many tables would linger after they finished eating. The workers can definitely learn something from the original location in efficiency.

The place itself is very hipster with an open waiting area/bar area and loud, I mean LOUD music. They let you order appetizers and drinks while you wait, which is a nice concept, except the bar area is so small that only a few people can actually have appetizers. And it's overcrowded so getting to the bar and getting some service for drinks can be very difficult. After spending 15 mins standing behind some people at the bar window I got frustrated and moved inside to try to catch a servers attention for a glass of water while I waited. After asking for water, it took another 10 mins for them to actually get me one. So ridiculous. I honestly think they could benefit from serving some COMPLIMENTARY HOT tea for their guests while they wait out in the cold for 1+ hrs.

Our wait was estimated to be 45 mins. After an hour, we asked how much longer and we were told another 15 or so minutes. But after 1.5hrs of waiting I was ready to give up and go home, but how could you give up after being in the game for so long? I just couldn't. I was so grateful once we were seated. I had already went through 3 glasses of water, 3 trips to the bathroom, and a slice of pizza from next door because we were starving and freezing cold outside waiting.

We weren't given menus immediately and after about 10 mins we finally got to order. But I mean, after waiting in line for almost 2 hrs, we knew what we already wanted so why give us the menus and give us 10 mins to order. I mean, I was already frustrated from the wait, the cold, the rain, and starvation. 

Food came out relatively quick thankfully. I ordered the Orenchi Ramen and the BF ordered the Beyond Ramen. The Beyond Ramen was definitely more seasoned and had more flavors and at the same time saltier. But I still liked my Orenchi Ramen better and it comes with an egg. The egg was soft boiled perfectly, but barely even warm. The noodles were a perfect al dente. The ramen was on the pricier end too, $12 per bowl. And overall, it was just OK, definitely NOT THE BEST.

I do give the restaurant cred for a very innovative and hipster layout. The outside bar is a great concept and they make good use of the limited space they do have. They definitely do try fit as many people as they can. Some tables are separate and some tables are communal. It felt like I was dining with the group next to us. We shared condiments, a jug of water, and I could hear their entire conversation without even trying. And trying to have a conversation ourselves on top of the music and neighboring conversations was very difficult.  The ambiance is definitely geared towards a younger crowd.

However, I still prefer Orenchi's down in Santa Clara. They're efficient with better tasting ramen, and they give more of a traditional Japanese restaurant feel with Japanese greetings and phrases. Parking is also way better. The mission can be a pain to find parking in. Plus I've only ever had to wait 30 mins at most there.

1.75 hr wait for a 20 min dining experience that was below par. Meh, Me Thinks Not. I definitely won't be coming back for a while, hopefully the hype dies down and the wait isn't so ridiculous then maybe, just MAYBE I'll consider returning.

I hear there's even a line an hour before they even open! You've got to be SH!TT!N ME!
author: Stephanie L.

description:
5 stars for ramen, 1 star for service.

Ramen: beyond delicious, the egg is perfectly cooked and seasoned, the broth is perfectly creamy and rich. I like to order the Orenchi ramen, occasionally will order the Beyond (but always get the egg because this one has no egg by default).

Service: I come here at least once a month and service is always the same: consistently bad. Granted, they are super nice and friendly, just terrible at their jobs. Yet, I return again and again because I don't feel like driving down the Peninsula for ramen. You will sometimes have a hard time finding the sign-in sheet, they like to move it around. They will forget to bring you water once you sit down. You will HAVE to ask for check, and flagging them down will be a theatrical trial. Sometimes you will have to ask for the check twice, to the same waitstaff, because they got too distracted. 

IMPORTANT TIP: gratuity is included in the check for all orders!!!! This is not announced or written on the menu, so you might accidentally give an additional tip for the terrible service.

Come for the ramen, you have been warned about the service.
author: Christy L.

description:
A decent Japanese restaurant with a lack of parking spaces. This place is right across from zeitgeist. It was said that Orenchi in Santa Clara is the best ramen restaurant in the Bay Area. 

Overall a okay place, not sure if the wait is worth it but it sure beats driving to San Mateo for ramen dojo. The egg was good but cold. I vaguely remember the egg that I had in Orenchi, Santa Clara was warm, not cold.

Get the large size, it's worth it. Watch out for the chicken, the table next to us got a piece of  raw chicken, the meat was red. And watch out for your wallet, not going to be a cheap dinner.
author: Michael Q.

description:
Not the best ramen I've ever had. That honor goes to Ichiran. But this was pretty good compared to what I've had in CA. The broth and noodles were alright. The pork was very tender. One thing they absolutely blew out of the park was the egg. I haven't seen a yolk like theirs since I was in Japan. Admire the vivid orange color and the intense yolk-y flavor. I asked where they buy them and they were very hush-hush. I'd want to keep it a secret, too.

I hate to sound old but the music was up too loud. I went for the food, not to dance.
author: David S.

description:
Decided to try it out tonight because we were home early and have never had the patience to wait at dinner time. We arrived 10 minutes before opening and there was already groups of people with their names on the seating list. Once they opened at 6pm, we were immediately seated. FYI-- This is probably the best time to come without a crazy wait. 

We ordered the Beyond Ramen (this Tonkatsu based soup is only available at this location), the Orenchi Ramen and the chicken karaage. We ordered additional pork and egg for both our bowls of ramen and added on the roasted garlic that was available at the table. Overall, the food was ok. Not sure if it was over hyped, but I have had better. We also ordered tea which was really awkward because one pot of water only served one cup of tea. 

In terms of ambiance, the decor was cool and the music was on point (90s and 2000s hits!). The waitress on the other hand was confused and screwed up our order. She probably needed a little more training.

I would probably not come back again because of the wait time and sub-par service. I'd rather take the 5 minute walk to Izakaya Roku where I can enjoy the ramen (and other options) and better service there.
author: Jess D.

description:
This place is a sort of place you go to because you're really craving ramen and you don't really care if it's the BEST... You just want some solid tasting soup and you're in between limbo of Hayes Valley and the Mission and don't really want to walk far from where you are and you just really need a ramen fix.

I don't dislike it and it's not terrible at all, but nothing really stood out to me. It's good quality and the soft boil egg shows its legitimacy. A solid B grade spot. Would I go back here? Probably not considering all the much tastier spots in SF to explore.
author: Janelle S.

description:
BEYOND excited at not having to drive over an hour to Santa Clara to get my ramen fix so when Orenchi beyond finally opened in (near) the Mission, I grabbed a girlfriend and beelined here for dinner. 

Surprisingly, I actually slightly prefer the beyond ramen here more than the original. It's deliciously creamy and filled with umami flavor. The pork was tender albeit a bit thin, the soft boiled egg was perfectly cooked, and the noodles were very chewy/QQ (al dente). I think it's one of the best ramen places in the city but that's not saying much for SF :P
author: Xinxin W.

description:
LONG WAIT, BUT TOTALLY WORTH IT! 

This is my second time here now, I've tried their Beyond Ramen which I believe is unique to this location, but I've also had their Orenchi Ramen before. In my opinion, I thoroughly enjoy the Beyond Ramen more, to the last sip of the soup. It has a thick, fragrant broth that is filled with hints of garlic and it was absolutely flavorful and delicious. I only wish that it already included an egg in it. Definitely splurge on the extra double chaasu and egg, it's so worth it! 

Ambience was very lively and hip, loud music and energetic vibe. Just make sure you are prepared to wait a while for some delicious ramen!
author: Stephanie C.

description: The savory and saltiness of the garlic broth does a good job of balancing the arugula (Beyond ramen).
author: Roxane P.

description:
I'd been biking by at night wondering what was drawing those milling crowds on the sidewalk. No signage and since I was never tempted to stop I just wondered. Finally I figured out it was Orenchi Beyond.

But no fear! If you can make during weekday lunch there are hardly any lines or wait. I showed up 15 minutes early expecting it be a madhouse like the Santa Clara location but there was only one other person waiting. In fact, up to 12:30pm you could just walk in and grab a seat. 

I got the Beyond Ramen. You only get two ramen choices: Orenchi Ramen or Beyond Ramen. The Beyond is special to that location. The toppings are pretty hard to tell apart. The Beyond doesn't have an egg - $1.20 extra. I would say the toppings aren't anything special - good but not distinguished. Also, it's just for variety and you won't get like a huge mound of meat - which is okay with me since ramen is really about the noodles. And man oh man, these noodles are really good. Thicker but not like really thick. Tasty and chewy. These are probably my favorite noodles after Ramen Shop in Oakland. Broth was good but a little too salty and fatty to finish the bowl.

Dang, I'm coming back at lunch for more of these noodles!

Decor is really nice. Like all other hipster restaurants along the Valencia corridor. A far cry from the sterile Santa Clara location.
author: Jean K.

description: So good! No wait on Saturday morning. I came at 11:30 ish and just walked in. Tried Orenchi Ramen and my hubby got the other classic one, the soup is fatty but good and not salty, it taste even better if you add the garlic. Chashu only one piece, the portion is just alright, not large American style, that's actually good. The egg is insane!
author: Vivian F.

description:
Excellent place. Great Ramen, finally have a go to place in the city vs being limited to Ramen Dojo in d
San  Mateo. Had the Beyond Ramen and Beyond hot chili oil for spice, awesome. Great place to eat in, contemporary, relaxed, well kept, and pleasant Service
author: Richard C.

description:
Unfortunately this Orenchi does not compare to the one in Santa Clara. Came here on a Saturday night around 8PM with two of my girls expecting it to be super packed, but to our surprised it was not! So we were seated right away.

I ordered the Orenchi Ramen and I didn't think there was anything too special to it. In fact, the noodles seemed to be small, "broken" noodles that did not remind me of what ramen noodles should be like. the broth was also super fatty.. and left my lips and mouth feeling suuuper oily and I usually.. wipe after almost every bite/avoid getting my mouth dirty while eating.
