My two girls ordered the Soba ramen.. which I thought tasted pretty good/fresh and it had a hint of lemon flavor to it! 

Idk if I would really come back to this place seeing that there are sooo many other ramen spots to choose from. 

A huge plus though.. our waitress and waiter were suuuper friendly and they even asked if we had any song requests to play! My girl requested Drunk in Love and they immediately added it to their queue and played it before our meal was over. Super big plus to the good vibes this restaurant brings though.
author: Krystal O.

description: Rich tasty shio broth, and I love the spicy miso (add-on to any ramen order). Ramen noodles were perfect. Clean and modern setting, good service and it was easy to make a reservation on yelp and avoid the wait.
author: Melissa T.

description: Best ramen I've had outside of Japan. I loved the pork broth. I was surprised how flavorful it was.
author: Josh C.

description:
3.5 STARS

I still haven't been to Orenchi Ramen in Santa Clara but I've already been to this spot a couple times now. Overall, this place is decent.

First off, the design and ambiance of this place is awesome. It's simple and hipster. It's the main reason why I would come back. The bar is in the very front of the restaurant so you can get drinks and snacks while you wait a table. And though it's mainly communal seating, you'll still feel comfortable eating.

I always get the ankimo appetizer here but it could be a hit or miss. The first and last time I had it, it was just okay. But the second time, it was amazing. My main complaint is that they put too much onions on the dish. 

I'm always skeptical on getting takoyaki at restaurants because they all taste the same to me. But Orenchi's takoyaki is the best I've ever had. It's perfectly crispy on the outside, soft on the inside, and it's not completely drenched with the sauce.

I've tried both the Beyond and Orenchi Ramen. The noodles in the ramen are really good. They are perfectly soft and taste fresh. In terms of broth, I think that the Orenchi ramen is better because the Beyond is a little overwhelmed with garlic. Both broths are pretty good but it can get pretty salty. I didn't like that the ramen only came with one super thin piece of cha-shu and a cold soft boiled egg.

I think this place is a little pricey for some ramen. I like a good amount of meat but that would make my bowl of ramen cost $16. This place serves good food but I will only come back if someone wants to try it.
author: Derek T.

description:
I really like how this place is set up. They set up a bar service outside of the place as you are waiting to be seated. Pretty sure you can order appetizers as well as beer as you wait. Oh and they have heaters outside on top so you don't have to wait in the cold. So far both times I've came here to eat the wait has been about an hour :/  

I got the beyond ramen bowl which is a tonkotsu soup based with Pork Belly, Green Onion, Bamboo Shoot, Sesame, Dried Seaweed, Fried Garlic, Mizuna. The pork belly wasn't actually pork belly though. It was more like a slice of pork. Usually they give two slices but I think I only got one. Sigh no worries though. 

The servers are super friendly and the t-shirts the workers wear are pretty clean. Wish I asked them if I can have one haha.
author: Randy G.

description: Decently priced ramen. They have a really creamy soup base that is quite rich. The pork is also cooked perfectly. Friendly and polite service that you would expect from a Japanese restaurant.
author: Chris H.

description: I really love the beyond ramen, but what is great is not just the ramen!The Karaage, takoyaki, garlic beans and the beyond salad are all really great. Also you must try the sequoia sake because it is brewed in SF locally and they serve it perfectly in this restaurant.
author: Asa N.

description:
Seriously recommend this place! Every time I've come here I've gotten seated like right away (we came around the time that they open for dinner soooo) and the service is excellent. Everybody is really nice and they're fast. The restaurant itself is just aesthetically pleasing and you feel super hip sitting in here LOL. Even the bathroom area lol. But seriously, the ramen here is pretty good and best of all, they serve it with soft-boiled eggs! It's literally perfect, I don't know what magic they do to get a perfect soft-boiled egg every time, but they do. The broth is flavorful ( I think I've gotten the more expensive ramen both times); the one thing I definitely recommend doing is upgrading to a larger bowl. Like idk maybe it's because I just like to eat a lot but if you want your tummy satisfied AND full, get the larger bowl.

Both times, parking wasn't a b and we found a space really close like right away, under the overpass. But again, keep in mind I've only come here right when they open so it's still light outside and I've heard it gets packed later in the evening. Also, it might be hard to spot unless you look out for the sign and their windows. But it's like right on Valencia, I doubt you'll miss it and get super lost lol.
author: Pearl L.

description:
MMM, fell into that hype. And man did not regret it at all! Double dated with the roommates. We ordered the spicy fries, chicken wings, these octopus balls (can't remember name) Orenci ramen and the Beyond ramen. 

The wait was about 30 minutes on a Wednesday night. I absolutely loved the structure of this restaurant so modern so chic! So inviting! Definitely a little pick me up for this neighborhood. The food was amazing- everything we ordered was seriously so tasty! And I loved how they had minced garlic available at the table. The noodles were kinda thick which is probably why we were so full. Hey but there's that bang for your buck factor! 

Fall into the hype- check this place out!
author: Dara S.

description:
Yeah...I don't like giving meh reviews, but this experience definitely deserves it. The service was great, the decor a little glossier than I like for my ramen joints, but the food was fairly disappointing.

My husband and I had the hamachi appetizer, which was this weird state between cooked and raw. it was slightly warm, very bland and could have used a healthy dose of salt and some lime. The portion was large but it was the first time we haven't gobbled down hamachi sashimi.

We ordered the Beyond ramen in large and split it. Our server was very nice in bringing out an extra bowl and spoon for me. The tonkatsu broth was good, but a bit on the greasy side. I did like the texture of the noodles, which was bouncy and held up well in soup.

We're not likely to come back here, since we've had better bowls of ramen in SF and the appetizers left much to be desired.
author: Orchid B.

description: I dropped in for dinner one Sunday at 5pm.  The bar had a few empty slots, but most of the tables were empty/reserved.  They promote themselves as the best ramen in the Bay Area -- a hefty claim, so I had to check it out.  I had the Beyond Ramen, which was good.  I thought the broth, floating with little bits of fat, was tasty. The noodles were a bit more dense than normal ramen noodles, but worked with the broth.  I would go there again. The service was prompt.
author: Alexa S.

description:
I've tried Orench ramen, Beyond ramen and Chuka-soba. Orenchi ramen (tonkotsu) is by far the best ramen I've ever had since I came to US a 8 months ago. It's actually as good as famous ramen in Japan (I've lived in Japan for 24 years). This ramen alone deserves 5 stars. Price wan't bad too. It's about $11 for ramen.

I felt Beyond ramen was just weird. I'm not fan of its garlic scent. Chuka-soba wasn't bad, but not good. It feels like middle or low range ramen I can have in Japan. I wonder why they serve such ramens while they can create Orench ramen. You should definitely have Orenchi ramen if you have chance to visit here.
author: Kazuki N.

description: I don't know what I was smoking, this place deserves solid 4 stars. Great bowl of ramen!
author: Aubrey Z.

description:
This place isn't quite as good as the one in Santa Clara, but it definitely is one of the best ramen places in the world. Looking over the other reviews here, I'm utterly baffled as to how San Franciscans don't quite seem to understand what ramen is (one review here says something about the ramen being 'bullshit' because 'egg that was so so under-cooked it poured out'. That sounds like a perfectly cooked egg to me, dude; tsukimi as a topping in Japan is just actually a raw egg...).

The Orenchi Ramen is just as good as the one they make in Santa Clara. The Beyond Ramen is a riff on the old standby Orenchi Ramen, but I didn't like it as much as I feel like it's heavily oversalted. If you have some sort of salt addiction and don't quite understand the simplicity of the old broth, go for it. Maybe you'll understand one day.

Negatives: The karaage here is terrible though. Don't get it. Get it from the Santa Clara location. The fried garlic appetizer was burnt. There's no draft Kirin. It's still five stars because they serve Orenchi Ramen.
author: Patrick X.

description:
The building is awesome and I dig the vibes. Service was great and the noodles were delicious. One problem: the broth is oily and tastes fishy...nothing like orenchi in Santa Clara and not at all like tonkotsu. 

I really wanted to love this place but it's just not as good as other spots in sf.
author: Annie R.

description:
We came on a Sunday night around 8 and waited only a few minutes before getting seated at the small bar.  I definitely like the look and feel of this place, though bear in mind it's on the smaller side and it has become very popular.  The noodles are a bit on the thicker side and the brother is tasty and not spicy.  The pork belly is good but the portion is relatively small.  

This is the only ramen place I've been in SF and while my favorite is still a place in San Mateo, Orenchi does the job.  If it were a few dollars cheaper, I would consider it a good value, but I'm guessing their prices are up due to being in SF and it's popularity.  You can get a medium sized (on the smaller side of medium) bowl for about $13-14 plus another $1.50 if you want an egg (a must - I believe it should be included as standard).  We also got the tofu appetizer which was delicious and cooked in a way I've never tried before.
author: Victor C.

description:
Always long line, but I think here's the current best ramen place in San Francisco!!
It's real Japanese tonkotsu Ramen.
Recently i always chose Orench Ramen.
author: Asuka Y.

description:
I must admit to being disappointed, but that's maybe somewhat due to the months-long pre-opening hype, given the popularity of their Santa Clara location (which I've sadly nevr made it down to).  Ramen is bafflingly difficult to do right in SF (despite several great choices on the peninsula), and sadly Orenchi didn't really deliver on my hope that things were changing in that regard.   Noodles were good but not great, broth was somewhat bland and not all that special (not impressed when I have to "fake" flavor by adding tons of chili powder to it).  Toppings were good at least: cha shu was yummy, and the egg was perfectly cooked & runny when breaking it open.

The restaurant itself has terrible acoustics and it's almost impossible to carry on a conversation with tablemates at a reasonable volume.
author: Brian T.

description:
Got there on a cold Tuesday night  with the girlfriend (50 degrees!) around 5:30 thought it'd be a good pick me up for such cold weather. There was already a huge wait around 12-13 groups. We made it just in time to be the last 2 that got seated in the first wave.

Had their Beyond Ramen and Orenchi ramen with takoyaki on the side.

Takoyaki - A must have! I always get this at the original Orenchi in Santa Clara and this one is just as good, crispy but soft on the inside, best to eat fresh.

Orenchi Ramen - about as good as the original, nothing different, nice creamy, noodles were cooked well.

Beyond Ramen - not as good as the Orenchi, no soft boiled egg! Had a more beefy taste rather than creamy and had some arugula or some type of green. Decent alternative.
author: Allan N.

description:
Awesome place! Stopped by with friends after drinks nearby. Recommend it for a quick bite, with veeery tasty food  and nice ambience. 
Will be back.
author: Dalila F.

description:
Bullshit. Bullshit. Bullshit.
It doesnt help that I have eaten in a dozen of the countries best ramen places in the past month. But this was definitely the worst. Big bowls of dull broth, noodles that were broken, egg that was so so under-cooked it poured out, fucked up chicken wings for karage, disappearing octopus in dumplings and shisito peppers that were basically raw dressed in oil. 

I expect more from San Francisco. Cant believe this place was packed.
Bullshit
author: Wesley S.

description:
Cool venue with tall ceilings, kitschy decor, and music and acoustics so loud that I can't hear myself think. 
Solid service. 
Takoyaki, Hamachi Carpaccio and Karaage - Tasty and not greasy
Orenchi Ramen - The broth is a little bland and sterile, but overall pretty good. 
Haven't made it to Santa Clara mother ship, but I've heard this is not quite up to snuff, however not having to wait in line and having decent Ramen in SF more than makes up for that. 
Ramen for lazy people.
author: Snuffles B.

description: I don't understand how this place has way lower reviews than the santa clara location.  I have to say that the santa clara location is probably my favorite ramen place in the bay area.  I was putting off trying the orenchi here since I was concerned the wait would be ridiculous.  We lucked out and were seated right away.  I got the orenchi ramen, and the broth is just as amazing as the original location.  I think that this location has more side dishes but really ramen is what you come here for.  My favorite thing about Orenchi has always been the consistently runny egg, and I felt like my egg here was slightly more cooked than usual, but it was still pretty good.  Glad that there's an Orenchi that is so close to me now.
author: Tiffany C.

description:
Overrated. I ordered beyond. It was good but not "that" good . Def not worth the over an hour wait. The soup tasted like bacon and it didn't taste like I expected as tonkotsu. Maybe they put too many garlic. Iza ramen is so far my most fav. 

I liked ikura donburi better than ramen itself. Lol 
Ramen itself has too little topping as default. 
You don't get usual topping if you don't order as extra, which other ramen place give you as default. 

I feel like orenchi is too stuck up and
They are not thankful for customer who waits over an hour. 

I will not go back. I'm disappointed.
author: Mii L.

description: My favorite lunch spot...the menu is smaller than the original location in Santa Clara, but I don't mind.  The ramen is terrific, there are some lovely small appetizers, and the beer is very cold.  The service is flawless, and I especially like the mural by Chad Hasegawa.  We're lucky to have you all in the city!
author: Jennifer F.

description:
After a long week of work, my weekend started  better than expected tonight. With the chilly wind on a cold night, I was craving for a bowl of hot ramen before heading home.

Not sure of my options after 9:30pm, I looked up on Yelp to check my options and was glad to find Orenchi Beyond open for late dining. I was pleasantly surprised to find out that it is operated by my favorite ramen restaurant in Santa Clara.

Given that I went there by myself, I must say I had a great dining experience even at the bar. The staff was attentive and accommodating (to my request), while the manager was friendly and more welcoming than many ramen places I have been to. I know I should focus on the food, but the overall service was unexpected, which is why I am writing this review before sleeping.

I ordered my favorite tonkotsu shio ramen (Orenchi Ramen) and fried calamari legs (geso karaage). The calamari legs were fried just the way I like them, crispy yet not overcooked nor oily. The ramen tasted better than I remembered, likely due to the piping hot temperature of the broth when it arrived (considering how cold I was on my walk there). The broth was tasty as it was not too thick, yet still has a distinct pork flavor. The noodles were not overcooked, yet not undercooked so they were chewy in a good way (not soggy).

I must say, after tonight, I will more likely visit this City location than travel all the way to the Santa Clara, as long as this location keeps up the wonderful service and delicious taste of the food that I had tonight.
author: Gilbert M.

description:
**3.5** 
(4 for food, 2.5 for service)

I can't compare this to its original location in South Bay, since I've never been. 

However, even as a Japanese ramen newb, I have to say the original Orenchi Ramen is pretty freaking good. The soft boiled egg was just as it should be, and they didn't skimp on portion size. They could have used better quality pork though (or at least sliced them more evenly).

The service was pretty terrible and inefficient. They either need to better train their servers on how to seat customers during rush hour (especially in the restaurant biz where time = money) or hire a separate hostess to do it. We waited an unnecessary extra 15 minutes as waiters slowly cleared the table before seating the next batch of customers on their wait list. 

I'd come back, but probably when it's less busy.
author: Diana K.

description: I highly recommend the orenchi ramen with the seasoned egg. The soft boiled egg in the ramen. It's deceptive: you think the yolk is going to be hard-- no, instead it's runny goodness. Add the spicy miso for extra goodness. The broth isn't overpowering with gobbles of pork belly fat so you health conscious folks can devour this ramen without fear of losing your soul cycle figure. Cool atmosphere in the restaurant too.
author: Will C.

description: We came here for lunch in a Saturday: busy enough for a good vibe, but easy to get a table. Ramen was delicious: had the beyond ramen with a free egg topping (thanks yelp!). Definitely coming back for more...
author: Tom W.

description: Great ramen! I had the beyond ramen and the broth was super delicious. Egg was cooked perfectly as well. Lots of great sakes and beers to complement your meal. My favorite is the draft sake, very delicious!
author: Glen W.

description: Came here for lunch and had the chicken karaage cury and the gf had tonkatsu ramen extra spicy. Everything was delicious and service was prompt.
author: Kris A.

description:
Finally tried this place and now understanding why it's getting such terrible reviews on Yelp.

We wanted to try a bunch of stuff so we ordered 4 appetizers and 2 bowls of Ramen. The ramen was good, but not better than a lot of other places in SF. Of the appetizers, the Hamachi Carpaccio had an overwhelming fish taste, the Karaage was okay, and the chopped tuna was good. The kobe beef tataki wasn't even edible, and absurdly expensive.

The place was loud and the service was meh. There are so many other places to get ramen in this city. Avoid this one.
author: Brenden M.

description:
This place is pretty delicious. 

Apparently cooking soup for 18 hours will ensure that. 

Don't think you can go wrong with anything on the menu - I went with the Orenchi ramen which was great. 

They also serve Sapporo in metal pint glasses - which has nothing to do with the food but is unique.
author: Varun V.

description: I love this place.  Great appetizers and great ramen. I also love how they close later on some days compared to other ramen places.
author: Ricky W.

description: Yummy ramen hidden away at end of Valencia @ Duboce. #realjapanese. Great staff, cool bright space.  Ramen delish, but so are spicy chicken wings
author: bruce b.

description:
It was okay. Not bad at all, A quality Ramen for sure.
But I think Shalala in Japan town is superior to Orench, and not sure why Orenchi got hyped so much.

Again, not bad at all, it was actually all around good.

Edit : then I started to visit here obsessively. It is indeed a good ramen - I have to re-think the rating.
author: Takahiro K.

description:
Very hip restaurant in an awesome space

But, wait!! The Orenchi Ramen bowls are SUPER SALTY. I really wanted to eat a gallon of ice cream after eating the ramen to get rid of the salty taste. Did the chef dump a bucket of salt into the ramen? Also, The wait was pretty long. And, the waiter forgot to put in an order of Pork Belly. Our order was probably drowned out by the music. On the bright side, I went with some good friends and had a good time. 

+ Great music
+ Awesome space
+ Cool art

- Ramen was salty
- Hard to get the waiters' attention
- Long wait, the waiters forgot our order, whoops!
author: Jessica T.

description: Tried this place again - this time the tsukemen hoping it'd be better. Unfortunately I was wrong. This place just doesn't have it. SF doesn't have the best assortment of ramen shops, but this place ranks especially low.
author: Evan H.

description:
Good Food&Drinks + Good People:
The wait might be long but the experience is tremendous. Get yourself some sake from the bar if you're getting antsy from waiting outside. The spicy chicken kara-age is perfectly fried and seasoned, the noodles are just chewy enough, and the soup is bold but not too salty.  Both the Orenchi and the new Beyond ramen are excellent, but if you scared of fried garlic just stick with the original. The couple we got seated next to couldn't help but notice my coworker and I shamelessly drooling over their food so they kindly offered us some of their chicken wing appetizers- Tebasaki Owariage (sp?)- and they were AMAZING. Strange to be taking food from total strangers, I know, but their chicken wings really are that good. We had to share some of our spicy kara-age in return for their hospitality.

GREAT MUSIC:
Best part of it all was the music they had playing. Orenchi Beyond has a couple turntables set up in the corner, and on this particular rainy Friday they were puttin' on some good ol' old hip hop classics! Big & Pac, Blueprint Jay-Z, even had Snoop Dogg- Doggystyle and Dr. Dre- Chronic 2001 vinyls displayed on the shelf!

And at that point I died and went to ramen/hip hop heaven.
The end
author: Justin T.

description:
Alright, finally got to try this place.

I really love the outdoor waiting area because you can order drinks and have appetizers while you wait.. But because we're talking about SF here, outdoor space heaters would be amazing during dinner hours.

Already can't wait to come back!
author: Av A.

description:
Came here with high expectations based on feedback from my son who has gone to the Santa Clara location. The night started out great as I scored a prime parking spot on the corner across the street from the restaurant ( I guess it pays to drive a small car that can fit into tight spaces). At any rate, we arrived around 6:30 pm on a Friday and unlike other yelpsters who mentioned the long waits, we were able to score a 2 top right away.

My wife and I ordered the Beyond Ramen and the Orenchi Ramen that comes with the egg. The broths are different as the Beyond is hyped with garlic. We also ordered the 6 pieces of fried chicken and the squid dumplings as recommended appetizers by our server. Tea was served in a "tiny" teapot - think munchkin size which I had to request refills constantly to the point that if I was the manager I would think re-think this from a  productivity standpoint.

Overall, the food was average and  I probably would not comeback here. The party of two who were also dining here for the first time also thought the food was just average as well.

Probably the best ramen noodle house that I have been to is Hokkaido Ramen Santouka located in Toronto in which they simmer the pork for 20 hours and the slices are much thicker.
author: Richard H.

description:
Orenchi Beyond probably has one of the best broths I've tasted for ramen. I ordered the Orenchi Ramen, which has an amazing tonkatsu broth. Unfortunately, the broth was the only highlight. The noodles were too firm and the pork - albeit good - was almost nonexistent. There was one piece of pork in my bowl. With the pricing, it's not the best deal for ramen. 

San Francisco lacks quality ramen, but Orenchi Beyond does take a step in the right direction. Cook the noodles a bit more and include a few more slices of pork please! With a few tweaks, I think Orenchi Beyond deserves 4-5 stars.

I'm looking forward to trying the Santa Clara location next!
author: Jonathan C.

description:
Never been to the original/other Orenchi in Santa Clara

Delicious, satisfying ramen with a really tasty, rich broth- only negative would be the short/small noodles. I'm a fan of long noodles...it's all about the slurp factor when it comes to ramen

Apps are great too- I'd definitely recommend the takoyaki and karaage. Takoyaki has ground octopus so there's the textural balance of octopus meat/paste. Bonito flakes on top = perfect

Cool layout and great outdoor bar for waiting for tables. 

Overall solid choice for a big group, small group, or just yourself
author: Josh C.

description: Broth in Orenchi and Beyons ramen is delicious and high quality. Came back from Tokyo, ate here and felt like broth was as good as in Japan. Also like the spicy Karage. Haven't tried many of their other new offerings. Recommend a bowl of ramen, cold sake, spicy Karage and then hop across the street to finish it off with a cold beer at Zeitgeist.
author: Andrea G.

description:
I really enjoyed my dinner here. Arrived at Orenchi around 7:30 PM for dinner and was promptly sat at the bar (because I was a party of one. Or as I should truly say, friendless for the evening. Drowning my sorrows in ramen, obviously) 

I ordered the Orenchi Ramen and boy did I enjoy it. The broth was very savory, with a great pork meatiness and mushroom earthiness quality. The pork was thinly sliced and easy to tear apart for small servings with the chopsticks. The nori sheets were delicately placed - some in the soup soaking up the broth, some left dried and hanging out for your choice of eating. The noodles were al dente, maybe more chewy than I have had before, but with a great bite and texture.

My personal favorite part was the egg. I'm a huge sucker for the softboiled eggs found in ramen dishes and I gotta say this egg knocked it out of the park. Delightfully creamy, yet solid enough to soak in alot of the broth flavor.

Overall, really enjoyed my evening. The best description I have of this evening was the fact that I pushed my bowl away to have it taken away....and 2 minutes later pulled it back to me to soak up more of the broth. Give this place a try!
author: Kenny H.

description: Very nice Ramen place! They do a good job, the people are great to work there, and the food is pretty authentic, according to my Japanese wife.
author: Dan-o T.

description:
The decor was great. Remodeled warehouse decked out in graffiti art and modern wooden furnishings, coupled with an awesome playlist of the early 2000s hip hop hits, Orenchi Beyond was almost kind of a throw-back.

The classic orenchi ramen tastes pretty similar to the south bay original, though presentation and portion are a tad messier and less tightly controlled, I'd say. It's what happens when you leave the kitchen out to a bunch of part time youngsters. 

Broth: fatty, oily, full of umami, with a slight sourness from the bamboo shoots, but waaaay too damn salty (like I said about the original Orenchi too).

Noodles were very firm still, which I loved.
Takoyaki: a bit fusion-y and definitely not round like they are suppose to. Mayonnaise is not as sweet as the Japanese kind. Nice smooth and creamy texture but definitely didn't see much octopus in my octopus yaki.

One strange thing is that everything came lukewarm. In Japan and the southbay Orenchi, the ramen would come piping hot, ready to burn the roof of your mouth off. That's what makes slurping ramen noodles so much fun. Didn't happen with Orenchi Beyond.
author: Chia L.

description:
What I Liked: 
- Orenchi Ramen - Flavorful broth and noodles to my liking. My only complaint is that the portion for the pork was too thin and too little..
- Aged takoyaki - I like how its crispy on the outside and soft on the inside. Just the way I like it.
- Minced pork on rice - I loooove the poached egg and the pork is perfectly seasoned and very flavorful.

What I though was okay:
- Beyond Ramen - I didn't like the flavor of the broth as much.
- Pork belly - It's super soft and definitely super fatty. Too soft and too fatty for my taste. It was okay.

The wait wasn't that bad when I got there at 6pm on a saturday night. Only had to wait about 20 minutes. But the line grew longer after that.
author: Jannifer H.

description: Many times already @ Orenchi Santa Clara but first visit here. Same broth and noodle. Same very thin slice of charshu. Pretty good overall. Bit too noisy for me. Chair was very uncomfortable.
author: JK C.

description:
You know Lindsay Lohan and her role in mean girls?
Okay, call me crazy, but Orenchi beyond is reminiscent of Lindsay Lohan in Mean Girls!

That ramen is just soooo mouthwatering good. But the vibe/environment was just not the right fit. The ramen was the Regina George. 

I arrived with Monica W at 545pm sharp. What? I need free parking. Ain't a joke in the city. 25 cents for 7 mins? Okay brb, let me go pick some dollars off that money tree I've been growing in my backyard. 

We put our names down on the list, and already there are 5 groups of 2 head of us. They paid more for parking, suckas. We awaited in the cold with our puppy dog eyes through their glass exterior. They were eating, while I was starving, give me a break. They opened their windows/doors at exactly 6:03PM. We were sat in order. The host would call a name and seat them/get them set up. Why not seat a bunch of people and have someone else hand out menus? IDK man. The environment inside was dim/hipster. There was colorful abstract artwork on the walls accompanied with a mini bar and 2 beers on tap. There is a ramen bar as well. The dining tables are semi-communal, very close to your stranger neighbors. The chairs are barrels, very inconvenient for people with back problems and people with purses/bags. Bathroom? There is a room with a square toilet, and 3 co ed sinks outside. I literally LOL'ed at the square toilets.. cause, thats the coolest shizz ever. 

A server eventually takes our order(their ordering system just seems off, Lindsay took a few tries to get it right) There are 4 choices, but the two ramen choices are the beyond ramen and the orenchi ramen. The beyond ramen does not come with the runny hard boiled egg but the orenchi does. I tried a bit of both and I honestly could not tell the difference. I loaded mine up with that garlic puree and that spicy seasoning. I wish I ordered the large(1.50) more because their regular portions are TINY for 12 dollars each. It sucks that it costs so much more considering the portion/price ratio as compared to their original location. Don't get me wrong, the noodles were a perfect al dente, soup was hearty and flavorful. The pork belly was so thin that I had to dig through all my noodles to find the broken pieces. Btw, no corn add on's :'(

We also ordered the spicy karaage, which was SO DECEIVING because it was not the least bit spicy. 3 pieces(with bone) for 4.60. It tasted like san tung chicken but much sweeter and without that white pepper spice factor. Good, but will not be ordering again. 

Throughout dinner, service? Non-existent. What really irked me was when we paid. Our bill totaled 32, we gave 2 20's. Our change took a good 15 mins, so sitting around after eating really wasn't the best feeling, I was definitely feeling that coma. 


Verdict; I will not be back. Sunnyvale faithful, even through those damn lines/wait times.

ps; the beyond ramen comes with a crap load of bamboos, I personally hate bamboos, it smells like zebras. But this did not effect my 3 star rating.
author: Wendy X.

description:
saturday night dinner at 7:30pm. I was surprised that the line wasn't crazy. it wasn't although the waiting area is very nice. it's heated and properly alcoholized. 

we got their spicy karage and orenchi ramen. they were both extremely salty. man i thought i liked salty. i always added extra salt to my food, but i think my brain cells would explode if i added more salt to ramen here. 

the music was way too loud. at some point, their pandora station got to heavy metal, which made it so weird in a ramen place. sigh i didn't have much luck with food during this sf trip...
author: Te R.

description:
My sister's always raving about how good the ramen at the Santa Clara Orenchi is, so when they finally opened one in San Francisco she took me to try what the hype was all about.

We arrived 30mins before opening for dinner and found parking across the street. They already had their waiting list out and there was already a good number of people ahead of us. During our wait outside, the front of the restaurant transitioned into a bar where they let you order drinks and appetizers. I thought that was an ingenious idea because the restaurant is quite small and they were able to utilize the space they had. 

My sister recommended me getting the Orenchi Ramen. I was a bit disappointed because the bowl looked quite small, but ended up being pleasantly surprised at how deep it actually was. The Orenchi Ramen came with an egg, pork, green onions, bamboo shoots, mushrooms, toasted sesame, and nori seaweed. I thought the broth was very flavorful and not too salty. The pork was very tender and wasn't too fatty and the bamboo shoots also didn't taste like it came straight out of a can like most ramen places I've eaten at. I really liked the noodles because they were nice and chewy, but the best part was the seasoned soft boiled egg (drool)!

We were lucky enough to be the last ones to get in during the first wave of diners. Despite the long line outside, our server didn't rush us to make an order. The staff was friendly and attentive throughout our meal and we never had to wave or flag anyone down. We also didn't have to wait long for our food because it came out promptly. (Good thing though because I get hangry!)
author: Jenny L.

description:
Heard a lot of hype about this place so of course I'd give it a try. Only been here once and my overall impression is that it's good, but nothing that great.

Orenchi ramen - great broth, pork slices are pretty thin and flimsy so that could be improved, noodles on the firmer side if that's what you like, nice soft-boiled egg

Shishito age - pretty good if you like Shishito peppers, nothing too crazy here

Ankimo - thought this was poorly made, the ponzu sauce it's drowning in wipes out all the flavor of the ankimo. Liked the onions, but needs less ponzu.

I would come again if someone really wanted to try it, but I probably wouldn't make a strong effort to come back.
author: Gore S.

description: I've had the fortune of exploring many of the ramen places in San Francisco over the last couple of years, and this one sticks out as a favorite. I got the traditional orenchi ramen with pork shoulder, and the broth was creamy and delicous! I also dug the atmosphere, and the fish appetizer that we got. My boyfriend LOVED the fried chicken appetizer, too. I hope to be back!
author: Dana O.

description:
Orenchi Beyond should probably be renamed to Orenchi Xtreme since it's obvious that that's the vibe they are going for. From the shitty rap music that's constantly blaring to the $1200 bottle of sake listed on the menu for no discernible reason, Orenchi Beyond is the Mountain Dew of ramen joints -- relying way too much on salt, MSG and fake swagger instead of trusting in the (obviously talented) skills of its own cooks.

Orenchi Beyond is like the 12-year-old kid that moves to a new school and tries way too hard to be cool. If Orenchi would stop trying to be "Beyond" and strive instead to serve decent and enjoyable ramen, they would do a lot better.
author: Aaron V.

description:
Ramen is good, albeit a little on the salty side, but the broth is flavorful and the noodles are *crunchy* - just the way I like them.

The rice bowls are great staples, too, and make a great snack if you're not that hungry (and at $4-$6 a pop, you can't go wrong!)

BUT the last two times I've gone, the service has been both slow and disorganized. We watched as others who were seated after us get their food before us and we had to ask TWICE where our food was. And in the end, they charged us for more items than we ordered, sigh.

Luckily service can be improved upon and so I hope they do because the food is on point.
author: chanchan c.

description:
Cool ambiance. Pretty loud inside. Short wait for 4.
Liked the Orenchi Ramen. Not so much the chicken karaage.
author: An Y.

description:
Just as good as the Santa Clara Orenchi's-- with half the wait time.

The location is about 12 minute walk from the 16th Mission BART. Come 10-15 minutes before it opens to guarantee a seat. Big parties are harder so try to come with less than 6 people. The restaurant layout is half table, half bar seating. The decor is very hip, both inside and out. Love the glass triangular window panes. 

Beyond Ramen is saltier than Orenchi ramen and exclusive to this location, Definitely more on the flavorful side while Orenchi is the classic safer option. Beware though, Beyond ramen doesn't come with that perfect soft-boiled egg so you'll have to order an extra (or two). 

Service is excellent here-- everyone is quick on their feet and they are great at getting customers in and out.
author: Emily C.
Dav G.

description:
it used to be really gooD but i thibk they changed the chef. now its just ok rame.n
however i like their green apple Tea and the service is superb
author: Brigitte B.

description:
Good, but not that great...I've had better.

I got the Orenchi Ramen and my boyfriend had the Beyond Ramen (both $12). Comparing the two, the Beyond Ramen has a saltier broth and doesn't include the egg. The Orenchi Ramen includes egg, but mine was completely cold in the center, so they definitely take it out of the fridge and plop it in your noodles right before serving it, which kinda ruined the egg for me. 

For $12, I didn't feel like it was worth it. It's not a huge bowl of noodles either so you're just paying for the hipster vibe and location.
author: Venus L.

description: I love ramen so this is one of the best places for ramen in SF.  The food was authentic Japanese style ramen.  The service was also pretty good and I like the ambiance of the restaurant.  It's got a little bit of a hipster vibe to it.  If you happen to be in the neighborhood and have a craving for ramen, i highly recommend the place.  The key is to get there before it opens so you do not have to wait in long lines.
author: Bernadette A.

description:
We heard rave reviews about this latest SF ramen offering & were encouraged by tales of people willing to wait an hour or more for a seat, so on a rainy Tuesday evening (hoping the wait would be shorter) we decided to give Orenchi a try.

PROS:
- rainy, yucky weather resulted in a super short wait! I think we were seated within 10-15 minutes. (But it seems like that is not the norm.)
- bar window for those waiting outside. I was thirsty so this was a huge plus for me.
- cool beverage selection. Some interesting beers, and a delicious apple-green tea.
- cozy, intimate space (which I like)

CONS:
- the music. Oh my god the music. It felt like we were eating ramen in a (bad) dance club.
- the noise. It's just a loud space, partly because of the (way too loud) music, but also because (like nearly every other restaurant in this city) everyone wants clean, modern lines instead of investing in some sound baffling, so conversation bounces endlessly off every hard surface & then finally punches you in the ear. Repeatedly.
- the waitress got my order wrong. Twice. Hey, it happens, and it was fixed as quickly as it could have been, but she seemed remarkably unconcerned. 

MEH:
- the ramen. It was good, but not amazing. I definitely would not wait much longer than we did for it. So not really sure what all the hype is about.

In short: I would eat there again if it happened to be convenient or I was with friends who wanted to (as long as we didn't have to wait long), but it's unlikely that I would make a special trip.
author: Angela B.

description:
I've had the original Orenchi in Santa Clara 15+ times in my life. There was one point where I went every week, sometimes switching off with Santouka. Drugs are bad for you, but if ramen is your drug, things can't go too badly, right? Orenchi and Santouka compete for the Best Ramen Ever seat in my heart. Some problems can only be solved with a hearty bowl of ramen.

- Beyond Ramen ($12): Yes, the ramen is $3 more here than in Santa Clara, but can't blame them with the high rents of SF. This is a mix of the regular tonkatsu broth with shoyu (soy sauce) broth. I may actually like this better than the original, but the broths here tend to be a bit saltier and less smoky. The Beyond does not come with Orenchi's signature soft-boiled egg, so make sure you add it on!

I've always been pleasantly surprised by the very attentive and kind service at the Santa Clara location, and they did not skimp on that part of the experience in SF. Kudos to all the patient waiters who have to deal with the hoards of hangry diners.

The atmosphere at this location is MUCH more hip/design-oriented. Whereas the original feels like a young, authentically-Japanese space, this Mission location has an orange hexagonal door, an abstract painting on the wall, tastefully minimalistic furniture, and high ceilings. The bathrooms have rectangular toilet seats and individual music speakers, because the trendy-chic shouldn't end when you have to take a tinkle! Also, you don't wait in a parking lot shared with a Grocery Outlet - you get to wait in a cavernous outdoor alcove with a drinks window. TL;DR the ambience is my favorite of any ramen restaurant I've been to.
author: Jessica F.

description:
After falling in love with Orenchi in Santa Clara, I'd like to try Orenchi Beyond in SF and this place is not really beyond its origin. It's not that good as expected. 

I ordered Orenchi Beyond and spicy fired chicken. Fried chicken is a fail dish. It's way too salty and greasy. Move to the ramen, it's a little bit better. However, the broth is a tad salty and portion seems a bit small. Overall, it's not that bad. But if you would have tried Orenchi in Santa Clara, this place might not meet your expectation.
author: Saran M.

description: Maybe there are just too many ramen places in SF now, but I think this was just ok.  The restaurant is beautiful, but I can't remember much about the ramen except that they offered fish cakes as an addition but no sweet corn.
author: Kamael S.

description:
I'm not understanding the overall less than four star review. yes, the lines are long. yes, it's loud in there. but what makes that different from any other good ramen joint? the ramen is delicious!!! the broth is on point and the noodles are perfect! I also like the vibe of the place and the somewhat communal seating. 

I'm not sure if anybody else has mentioned this (I'm sure they have) but if you show up before opening, the list to sign up for seating is already out so make sure to place your name on the list even if you're there before opening time.
author: Regina C.

description:
Easily the best ramen place in SF like I could easily predict when I heard they were opening last year. 

Anti-pasti didn't appeal me at all so I just got 12 dollar orenchi to finish in 5 minutes. Eat, pay and leave ASAP for the suckers waiting in line. This is  the Japanese way. Please do realize that store staff don't expect you to enjoy 75 minute conversation at this place. Sit, order, eat, pay and fuckin' get lost. If you didn't know, ramen is a fast food. So do all your talking while waiting and eat like hell. 

I'm not gonna lie. This is the best ramen joint in the city where long wait seems reasonable. I'd recommend every geeky friend of mine regardless of ethnicity or age to hit this place to break up with substandard sham'en.
author: yota L.

description: Orenchi Beyond is definitely my top choice when it comes to Ramen in San Francisco. Everything from the noodles to the broth to the meat and most importantly the egg was excellent! Servers were crazy busy during my visit, however, they were still very attentive and remembered all my orders. Whenever I have a craving for ramen, Orenchi Beyond is definitely my go-to spot!
author: S T.

description:
You no longer need to be one of the masses standing outside in the dark for dinner. 

It is open for Lunch!  The good: Atmosphere. I personally liked the vibe, the outdoor window "seating", the music and furniture. 

The bad: Orennchi Ramen - Pork Belly small quantity and slices and not the traditional PB slices you imagine. Bland broth. Tori Soba - good broth, minimal meat, so-so noodles. Fried Chicken - flavorful but overdone.

This comes in third in my ramen travels. #1 Ramen Izakaya Goku  #2 Ken Ken
author: C K.

description:
Here's the thing: most of the poor reviews here are from the wait time. I did not experience the horrendous wait time because I came as a singleton on a Sunday evening. The guys sitting to the left of me (a party of 2) had a wait time of 1.5 hrs. The guys sitting to the right of me (a part of 3) had a wait time of 2 hours. I had a wait time of about of about 4 minutes. After finishing eating, I happened to run into some friends who had already been waiting for 1hour. Obviously, my expectations for this meal are calibrated for a less than 5 min wait time.

I ordered a bowl of the Beyond ramen. Well priced, great fresh noodles, some seaweed. I got no extra drinks or dessert and was super satisfied with the ramen. I've had bowls of ramen around town in the area at nearly every well-known restaurant offering it within a 0.5mi radius and this one's the best bang for the buck!

I also really liked the ambience. It's loud, it's busy and it's hip. This actually makes for a very good bar dining experience. One of the guys on my right commented that I looked very focused eating my ramen (the reason we started comparing wait times). I mean, of course! Ramen is what I came here for, dining with friends is for somewhere else where there's a nice quiet place to sit and chat for a long time :~)

Next time I go, I'll be trying likely just an appetizer. This time, it was ramen no frills. Beyond ramen with the pork belly delivered. Will definitely be stopping by again!
author: Grace W.

description:
The location and vibe was great. Good stuff to be able to order out of the bar off the street. Wait staff was awesome.

My husband and I have been trying for over an hour to reach the place because we left our card there. But there's no phone number. For any of their locations. 

Would appreciate anybody (esp. the restaurant) letting us know how we can contact them.
author: Diana L.

description: Soup is good, their #1 is different from original orenchi,  more garlicky.   Sides and everything is yummy.  Noodles great texture. Takowasa could be more Balance Meaning too much wasabi , losing the sweetness of the raw octopus.  Beside that, everything was good.  Service is quick and friendly.  Love that.
author: Tee K.

description:
There is really no reason why Beyond is any worse than the original. The ramen is just as good, and the decor, staff, and wait times are at least comparable if not better than the San Jose location. I've been here three times in one week, and it never disappoints.

The only ramen joint in the Bay Area that's comparable to SoCal ramen imo.
author: Jeff S.

description:
Update: I've been back and they are much improved. Probably more like 3 1/2 or even 4 stars on a good night. So now I can recommend them! 

Original review is below for reference: a few good tips are in it. 

We (my Japanese ramen expert dining partner and I) were so excited when Orenchi opened in the Mission. Finally, we would have really authentic delicious ramen close at hand. 

Well, not so fast (and I'm not referring to the 45 minute wait):  we ate at Orenchi and found it wanting. 

The first problem was the menma. What's menma? Let's go to Wikipedia for the definition:

"Menma (メンマ or 麺麻 or 麺碼?) is a Japanese condiment made from lactate-fermented bamboo shoots. "

What they fail to mention is that menma is super ultra funky tasting. It just tastes nasty to me (and to my Japanese ramen expert friend). Is it commonly found in ramen? Yes, but not always. And when it is found, it usually doesn't overpower the flavor of the ramen. 

At Orenchi, the menma we had was completely overpowering. It overpowered the soup. It was basically all I could taste. So Recommendation 1: If you don't love menma, ask for your ramen with no menma. Or get it on the side. 

We got both the Orenchi and the Beyond ramen. The Beyond had a much more interesting flavor, with some roasted garlic notes. The Orenchi ramen didn't have a particularly notable flavor, except for the menma. So Recommendation 2: get the Beyond ramen. 

The pork was good, but it was extremely thinly sliced and there wasn't much of it. Recommendation 3: get extra pork. 

The egg in the Orenchi ramen was cold. Not just room temperature: refrigerator cold. It was also quite runny. Runny and cold is not a great combination. But you won't be getting an egg because you won't be ordering the Orenchi ramen. You'll be getting the Beyond ramen, right? And it doesn't come with an egg. (See Recommendation 2, above). 

The noodles were thicker than we like, but they were also cooked more than we like. They'd gone beyond al-dente to just slightly rubbery. So Recommendation 4: ask for the noodles al-dente. 

We also ordered fried chicken karaage. When you order the karaage you're asked if you want it "regular or spicy". No matter how much you like spicy, do not order it spicy. What they don't tell you is that "regular" is real chicken karaage: small crispy boneless pieces of chicken, battered and deep fried. The "spicy" is bone-in chicken wings, not crispy at all, covered with a sweet, sticky, slightly spicy sauce. Ugh. So Recommendation 5: order the regular, NOT the spicy chicken karaage. 

Recommendation 6 would be to find a better ramen place, but now I'm just being cranky.
author: Jacob L.

description:
Short and sweet? A trendy (and beautiful?) little place down on Valencia. Good ambience, very loud, has the required community table with all too short stools with no backrest, and amazing music geared towards the 20somethings who will call the late 80s punk or early 90s stuff classic. Meh...

Regardless, the food was not bad but try overpriced. Basic noodles were $10-12, with add ons like egg or cha-Sui being $2-6 more a piece it can add up to quickly a $20 bowl of ramen. It's okay, the broth was subtle, seemed to not have that simmering all day taste to it :(, unfortunate...
author: Vittorio L.

description:
I was so excited to see that Orenchi had opened up a location in SF. I thought I would no longer have to make the hour-long pilgrimage to south bay to eat some of the best ramen in the country. I knew going in that it wouldn't match up to the original, but expected it to be quite good, especially given all the hype surrounding the opening.

My group of 4 all ordered the same thing: the Orenchi Beyond ramen with a soft-boiled egg. The noodles were not curly or chewy like typical ramen noodles: they were far too thin and brittle for the broth, which didn't taste as full-bodied as I had remembered it to. The portion was tiny; at normal ramen places, I am usually keeled over wanting to die from the humongous portions (for a small), but here, I felt like I had eaten 2 very large appetizers. Not starving anymore (had just had a slice of pizza before coming and was worried I wouldn't be hungry enough), but nowhere near full. Toppings and veggies were nowhere to be seen - a stray bamboo shoot or piece of piece of pork floating within the sea of broth...

Our bill came to about $30/person (split a pitcher and a double order of sake as well) for a group of 4, but I think we could have spent our money elsewhere and left happier. We found some pupusas and tacos to fill our not-so-full stomachs after our Orenchi experience.

Ambiance has loud music and everyone is shouting in the restaurant to make themselves heard to their friends sitting right next to them. It's like trying to eat a meal at a bar. Servers were wonderful and attentive, which is why I gave this place 3 stars (otherwise, I would have given it 2 for the food alone).

Meh. Make the drive to the original in Santa Clara. Or go to another joint in SF! Since they just opened, I think there might be some kinks they need to work outwits the food, but until they do, I'll have to get my ramen fix at another location.
author: Chrystal Z.

description: Very cool place to have ramen. Ramen is authentic. The soup is very flavorful. The chashu in ramen tastes really good. And Chashu Gohan is tasty, very yummy. Fried chicken is one thing that I order every time when I go.
author: Emma C.

description:
I've been wanting to try the Orenchi Santa Clara location for quite awhile and was excited for Orenchi Beyond to open in SF. 

BIG disappointment- 90% of the ramen was noodles, broth was okay- cannot modify level of spiciness, very skimpy on the default toppings especially the pork which was one thin slice (think ham size).

If you want to pay $12 for a bowl of ramen filled with mainly noodles- then give this place a try.
author: Minh P.

description:
A different experience to Orenchi in Santa Clara. Orenchi Beyond perhaps fits in better in the Mission than its Santa Clara counterpart would: the music is pumping, they offer a variety of drinks at their bar, and the decor has a trendy hipster minimist feel to it.

The menu features fewer varieties of ramen than the Santa Clara location. They serve Orenchi ramen and Beyond ramen, plus two soba varieties. They do have a decent selection of appetizers.

One nice touch is the way they have the front of the store set up. The bar faces into the waiting area, allowing you to grab a drink while waiting for your name to be called.

[Thanks to Leslie C. for pointing out that Orenchi is in Santa Clara not Sunnyvale.]
author: Glen G.

description:
Get ready for an absurdly long wait. We came right at opening on a weeknight and were told the wait time would be 45 minutes. We ended up waiting over an hour because the staff gave away our seats to a couple who wanted to sit at the bar. 

The ramen itself is also overrated and overpriced, in my opinion. I would probably not eat here again, considering the wait time and high prices.
author: Em A.

description:
First of all, the hours on this yelp page are ridiculous. 6am? Let's be real. They really open at 6pm. It's also strange they didn't have a phone number when I wanted to see if they actually had lunch hours or not on the weekend. I still don't know. 

Came by around 6pm and it was already packed with people. The wait is long, but the cool thing is the decor of the restaurant allows for an "outside bar" which is technically still on the restaurant's premises, so you can wait and drink. Smart. 

I got the Orenchi Beyond Ramen, which is only available at this location. I even checked the Orenchi menu to see if it was just listed as something else over there. It isn't. Tonkatsu Based Ramen with pork belly, green onion, bamboo shoot, sesame, dried seaweed, fried garlic, mizuna (japanese mustard). It was really good and garlicky. I've been to the other Orenchi and I thought their classic was OK, nothing worth the drive or wait. This was better to me. 

We also got some agedashi tofu, which was warm and yummy, along with some spicy chicken karaage, which was OK. I perfer the regular version, but I always get suckered by "Spicy". A bummer was that they didn't have the spicy bamboo shoots they have at Orenchi in Santa Clara. 

Overall, the vibe at the restaurant is interesting and different, but definitely hipster SF. If the wait wasn't so long, I'd be here more often.
author: Jeannie L.

description: There was a long wait and very limited seating, which confused us, because when we got our food the ramen was not very good. The noodles were thick and the broth was very salty. I could not finish my ramen because it was so heavy.
author: Risa P.

description: food is good and yummy. Service is kindna stuckup after we ask order ramen to go and why you don't have a phone number. lol
author: Leeto B.

description:
I'm proud to say San Francisco finally has a great Ramen joint! Don't get me wrong, there's a lot of ramen places but none of them really either stood out to me and I would rather drive out of the city just to get some decent ramen! Now, I don't have to anymore! I've never tried the Orenchi in the southbay (I know, blasphemy right?)... but my friends said this location was comparable to that location, so I guess I won't have to trek all the way down there just to try it anymore! Went on a Thursday around 6:20 and got seated at 7:20ish... so roughly an hour of waiting. There isn't a big sign that says ORENCHI or anything... but you'll see a large crowd standing outside... so you won't miss it unless you intentionally do it. Area has plenty of parking. Smart move on offering to sell alcohol to people as they are waiting, so there's something for you to do if you don't feel like walking around the area.

Onto the food! Shared the chicken wings and the takoyaki. The chicken wings were nicely flavored. Sweet, savory, and pepper on the top. Had a nice little crunch while it's hot and not over fried like other places. Moist in the center... awesome wings! The takoyaki was delicious! Not too doughy like other takoyakis I've had and it was seasoned well. Decent sized octopus in the center... unlike other places when you're wondering if there's even an octopus inside! Then I got the famed Orenchi Ramen (clouds part away while rays shine down)!!! It lived up to the hype and so much more. I got the large size (+1.25). Noodles were nice and chewy, egg was nice and runny, and broth was amazing. If this is what an orgasm in the mouth feels like... then damn, I've been missing out. Even though I knew the broth was bad for me... I couldn't stop drinking it, so flavorful! I paid for it in the end at the end of the night though cause I was super thirsty! But I would do it again if you gave me another bowl! When the meal was over... I felt like a little bit of me died inside. I will definitely be back and many more times!

Overall, service was good. Servers checked on us a few times. Place was clean. Can get pretty loud, but I feel like every place in the city is like this, so I'm used to it. Bonus points for their rectangle shaped toilet (I'm not sure why this really matters, I've just never seen a toilet that shape before)! Ramen is a bit pricey compared to other places, but I look at it that I'm saving gas money since I'm not driving out to San Mateo or the South Bay for ramen... so it balances out for me! Food was on point and I definitely recommend this place for people to try. KEEP EM' COMING ORENCHI!!!!!
author: Johnson S.

description: This place is awesome! Idk about you but I love the smell of fresh hot sake as soon as you walk in. Everyone is extremely friendly. And the food is amazing! A tip on what to order, my girl and I always get one each of the 3 ramen choices, and order a bunch of starter/appetizers. And of course the great hot sake!!
author: Derek S.

description: The wait is no longer long at this location, so that's a plus. However, the Orenchi Ramen does not tastes as good as the one in Santa Clara, but it's still good. Definitely good enough to satisfy my craving without having to make the drive down to the south bay.
author: Lina C.

description: The ramen here is not great.  I was really hoping to like it because I love Orenchi Ramen in Santa Clara, it is my favorite ramen shop in the Bay Area.  This place though was extremely salty however without much flavor, except being salty.  I had the Orenchi ramen and spicy Karaage.  Spicy Karaage was not spicy at all, just fried chicken drenched in this salty sauce that I did not like. The store vibe and hipster deco were the only thing I liked, along with the heater outside for people who are waiting.  I probably won't come back here again, will venture out to the original Orenchi instead for good kotteri tonkotsu ramen.
author: Ree'Ay I.

description: You can't take ramen to go. Never heard of such a policy. Been before and ramen is solid, but the no to go policy is truly a joke. Every other ramen place makes it work.
author: Alex B.

description: This is the best Ramen in town.  The secret of Ramen is the soup.  At Orenchi, they have an open kitchen where you can see them boiling bones in big vats of soup for hours.  The result is a a fantastic, incomparable broth that make you savor every drop of it.  I ordered the beyond Ramen which comes with a perfectly soft-boiled egg.  It was just heaven.  I have been to Mensho, which is also good but you have to wait for 1.5 hours, and to Nojo where the soup is way too salty.  Orenchi is the best place for Ramen in SF!
author: Will T.

description:
I would first like to address mr. Samson L.'s ridiculous review. Giving a place 1 star for a broken noodle machine is by far the dumbest thing ever. It's not like they intended to do that. That's an entire night's revenue down the drain for them. Saying Orenchi sucks for a broken noodle machine is like saying a Mercedes Benz sucks because it happened to blind you once with it's clean exterior. Also, then bitching about lack of parking is even more laughable because anyone who is familiar with SF knows parking sucks all over the city, especially in a high traffic area. Grow up dude.

Easily one of the best if not the best ramen in SF. Came here on a saturday at around 5:50 right before the place opened and there was a HUGE crowd already. There was at least 40-50 people in front of us so we stuck it out. The wait ended up being 1.5 hours which I would never do again. I happened to run into some friends who came at 5:30, put their name down and then went over to Zeigeist to drink before coming back over (probably the best idea to do). They were seated pretty much during the first wave. I think what took extra long was just certain parties taking forever to leave. At least 2-3 were there 2+ hrs. I have nothing against people enjoying their time but when there's a 20-30 person queue. Be more considerate.

There's only street parking but who in SF drives that much? Sorry, but if you're going to complain about parking, chances are you're either from out of town or just lazy as hell (this coming from a fat guy). Everyone knows parking in SF is bad. That's why you try to drive as little as possible. If you factor in parking into your review then everywhere in SF is bad at this point because there are very little plazas and very little parking garages. 

Anyways, on to the food. I ordered the oomori size Orenchi ramen and I would say overall, it's very good. The broth was seasoned perfectly and had a great tonkotsu flavor. I was able to enjoy the noodles and the condiments at the same time. I only wish it was a tad bit spicy to give it that kick but nonetheless was good ramen. I wish I ordered some Cha shu with it but i just totally blanked out. We also got some karaage chicken which was tasty but this is the first time I've been to a place where they ask how many pieces we wanted. Usually it just comes as it but I didn't mind. Just odd.

Overall, this place is solid. I would not wait 1.5 hours again but I would come here on a weeknight or something for a shorter wait time.
author: edward k.

description:
Overrated and underwhelming are two words that come to mind when I look back at Orenchi Beyond in SF. My friend and I both ordered the Orenchi Ramen, and both thought the broth was VERY watered down and not as rich-tasting as it should have been.

I'm not a ramen stickler in the least, but I will definitely not be coming back here or recommending to any of my friends.
author: Chris P.

description:
Orenchi ramen is in San Francisco now! Came in during a weekday for lunch, it was not crowded at all and we got seated instantly. Picked the orenchi original ramen (because of the egg, you need to definitely get the egg) and it is the best ramen I had in SF. The portion is not too big but will fill you up - don't skip the the broth as it is so delicious too (it is tonkatsu!). Will come back during lunch hours if possible, because it is not fun to wait in lines for other times.

Minus one star only because it is pretty expensive for the size - $12 per bowl.
author: Vivienne Z.

description:
Wasn't sure if I was in a ramen place or a club.... The lighting was so dark, the music was loud, and everyone waiting outside had a beer in their hands. Totally loved it.

The wait for a table of 6 was about 45 minutes, which wasn't that bad. The Orenchi Ramen was definitely worth the wait. The broth is a little on the thicker side and the noodles are a little harder compared to other places. 

Oh also, parking around this area sucked,
author: Kristine H.

description:
I was so happy when I found out Orenchi was opening a restaurant in San Francisco! No more having to drive out an hour to get Orenchi in Santa Clara.

The ramen itself is relatively the same as the one in Santa Clara. I have only ordered the Orenchi Beyond ramen, and it tasted pretty good. The noodles seem to be thicker, which I really like. I also order the salmon roe rice bowl with a poached egg, and I love it. If you like ikura, then you would love this rice bowl. The last time I went they ran out of eggs, so they gave us the bowl for free. Amazing! They also have a wide selection of foods that are different than the Santa Clara location.

The one dish I did not really like is the spicy karaage. When I came here the first time, it was sweet and tangy. The second time I ordered it, it was way too salty for my liking. I don't know if I would order this again.

The wait for Orenchi Beyond is about an hour. The food can take awhile to get to your table as well. Hopefully you won't be starving when you come here!

The decor is pretty amazing. Very modern and fits the feel of San Francisco. There is a bar in the "waiting area" so you can grab a beer or two while you wait. 

Santa Clara's location beats this one, but that won't stop me from coming back to this location.
author: Vivian L.

description:
Solid enough.  I had the Beyond with an egg and I also tried the classic Orenchi.  The noodles were great, as was the egg, but the broth was a bit lacking, and I was disappointed at the lack a spicy option (though they did offer chili oil to spice it up).  

Personally I thought the Beyond was too garlic-y, and that the original "orenchi" broth was the better choice.  Also, the Sake was tough to share.  It comes in a glass that doesn't pour well, so you'd be better off just getting 2, except that they cost as much as a bowl of ramen.

Overall it definitely hits the spot if you have a ramen craving, but it doesn't do anything too special.  Solid 3 star but I can't give it more because of how good the options are in San Mateo.
author: Alexander E.

description:
So after a night of rock climbing, some friends and I decided to head over to Orenchi Beyond. Luckily for us, it was Black Friday around 10pm so the place wasn't too packed. Got seated right away and gazed over the menu. With 4 different types of ramen on the menu, I decided to go for the Orenchi Ramen. 

Along with that, we kind of went ape sh*t with the appetizers too. We had damn near everything on that app menu. Between the 6 of us, we had the chashu, hamachi, takoyaki, spicy karaage, shishito peppers, and spring rolls. I'll just flat out say this, it was all good. Each dish had its own characteristic, but I'd have to say that the takoyaki was my favorite. Before I go on, let me just say that finding a place that makes good takoyaki in the Bay is a feat all on its own. Thankfully, OB makes a damn good one. 

Now let's talk about the ramen. I, personally, have never been to the Orenchi here in Santa Clara, even though it is close to me. After hearing stories of 90 minute waits and then some, I didn't want to make the effort. Now that I've had the ramen at OB, I'm almost intrigued to go try it from the original. Nonetheless, OB's ramen had me feeling some type of way.

The number one thing for when it comes to ramen is the broth. Hands down, some of the best broth I've had as far as ramen goes. Full flavored but with a light finish at the end so you don't feel heavy after drinking it. Noodles were on point, perfectly cooked. Chashu and soft-boiled egg, I don't need to say much because those two together is one combination I will never insult. Add in the nice pieces of bamboo and seaweed, and you've got yourself one legit bowl of ramen. 

On top of all that goodness, the vibe is just right at OB. Great selection of music, nice seating, and super cool staff to make your eating experience all the better. 

Needless to say, Orenchi Beyond is now a destination for me whenever I'm in the SFC. But don't take my word for it, go try it yourself!

Almost forgot to add but.. They got a super dope selection of Japanese beers and sake. Went great with all the food we ate. Cheers!
author: Richard L.

description:
I came here the day before thanksgiving and signed up for a table for six at 6:30. It still took almost 2 hours to get a table. I got the Beyond Ramen and the broth and pork was pretty good. The portions was pretty small though. I think there was only a couple thin slices of meat and the bowl was smaller than the smallest Pho restaurants. 

For the wait time, I would rather go to Ramen Underground or Kitanaya.
author: Christopher Y.

description: I hate to give only two stars to a place that had such nice staff, but most of the food was way too salty. We ordered the spicy kaarage and the hamachi carpaccio as appetizers and I had the Chu-Ka Soba while my friend ordered the Beyond Ramen. Everything apart from the hamachi was so salty it was not enjoyable. I know ramen broth is full of sodium but the flavor tasted a bit like burned shoyu. I was disappointed as another friend has been raving about Orenchi for months. I know I'm in the minority, but I've definitely had better ramen elsewhere. On the plus side, the decor is nice and the staff is very kind.
author: K H.

description:
Takoyaki was disappointing; kind of a croquette with a single piece of octopus inside each one. I didn't know this place was fusion, so don't present that if you are billing yourselves as an authentic Ramen-ya.

The chicken base ramen was also disappointing; make that bad. This place is set up for pork-base so take chicken base off of the menu.

I found it overpriced and disappointing. Second time and done.
author: Michael S.

description:
Cool environment.  I like the modern art feel, but the music was too loud.  The tables are not big so I was pretty close to my friend, but we could barely hear each other.  

The carpaccio hamachi appetizer dish was mediocre, the ramen noodles were nicely done, but the broth was a little on the salty side, but the wings were yummy! Go figure.
author: irene u.

description:
The Orenchi in South Bay is a lot better. First of all, most American ramen joints let the ramen bowls sit at the counter for a while before serving it to the customers which makes the noodle soggy. So I asked the waiter to make my noodles katamen(aldente). When the ramen came out, the broth was warm and the noodles were soggy. No bueno. The broth needs to be hot, especially for tonokotsu ramen because its super fatty so if you lit it sit for a minute, all the nasty fatty layer will rise to the top and form a wall. 

The ambiance of the restaurant is hip. They have good music playing with communal tables which can be a tight squeeze. They also have a standing bar where people can order drinks while they wait to get seated.
author: Ricky M.

description:
Pretty good ramen, but not enough to necessitate the 2 hour wait or the hype.

Get there before they open. Put your name on the list, mosey on over to Zeitgeist. Grab a beer, mosey on back over to Orenchi Beyond in a hour or so. See that there's still a list of tables ahead of your. Mosey on over to their bar window, and grab a aluminium cup of beer, or a can of sake.

Oh sweet, they called your name? Yes!

Order:
Ikura Ontama - Salmon roe and soft poached egg. Pretty good - the egg was delicious and had the texture of a sous vide egg.

Beyond and Orenchi Ramen. I preferred the Beyond, but felt that neither bowls were memorable.

I dig how this restaurant was designed, The see through glass kitchen wall, the large graffiti art piece encompassing the wall, the art on the tables, and the architecture of the entryway are all beautiful, but all of this gets kind of lost in the massive amounts of people and the wall of sound you encounter at this joint.
author: Jessica O.

description:
The wait is as long as everyone says. Party of two, arrived 30 minutes after opening. We waited just over an hour for a table. The food, however, was worth it. 

Started with the takoyaki. Not my favorite, but then I'm not really into octopus to begin with. It was much too fishy for my liking. 

We both got the beyond ramen, and I added extra chashu to mine. Thank god for that! The meat portions are definitely small. Broth is very flavorful, but not too heavy. I took my leftovers home and it reheated very well. Noodles didn't get soggy. 

The music is terrible. One minute I was in a 90s rap video and the next I was at an EDM festival. The atmosphere isn't conducive to talking, so I'd probably skip it for date night. 

Would definitely come back for the ramen, but I'd suggest coming just before opening to avoid a long wait.
author: Jasmin T.

description:
I'm not a ramen connoisseur, just a person who likes ramen that didn't come out of a styrofoam cup, so take what I say with a grain of MSG. 

Seemed like a long wait for a table but no wait at all for a spot for two at the bar ~7 on a Wednesday. Line seemed to build throughout the night though, so I would recommend coming early. We ordered the Age Takoyaki, which I can only describe as fancy croquettes with octopus (so stay away if you don't like either of those), and the Orenchi Ramen (which I believe is their "signature" dish).

My favorite thing was the texture of the ramen! Slightly chewy, almost al dente which is exactly how I like my ramen (not a fan of soggy noodles). Broth was creamy yet not greasy, and the soft boiled egg was on point. Thought the ramen was amazing, but only liked, not loved, the Takoyaki.

Overall, cute, hip place to get quality ramen in the Mission!
author: Erica D.

description:
Great food :)
But expect a wait :( 

I tried the Orenchi Beyond ramen! It's was a great rich ramen.  The food other than the ramen was a little lack luster for me.  But I have heard the soba is great so I will have to come back to try that.

Love the decor(*_*) very smart outdoor waiting area where you can have a beer while waiting to be seated.  Overall a great big thumbs up!
author: Emiko N.

description:
Very nice Japanese restaurant. I was there Saturday Night November 8 2014.with three of my friends.  

Parking was a challenging but, we manage to find a parking spot at the parking meter just a block from the 16 street BART station.  It was fine even though we had to walk a quarter of mile in order to get to the restaurant.  

It Saturday night and the entire restaurant was super busy, very crowded. We were told by the host that it was be about two hours wait but, we were able to get in just one hour and a half.  

The decor is it a bit of hipster. The tables were kinda of too close to each other so you have to be careful when get in and getting out of your seat.  

The waiter and waitress were very friendly and attentive.  

Now for the Ramen, I order Tori Soba Ramen Noodle and I must say they Ramen was so good I ate the whole bowl.  The price was not bad for $11.  There are water at the table waiting for you and spices such as garlic and one more but I cannot remember the name of the other spices.  

The type of chair they had at the table was just a stool.  

They lost a star only because I wish they would take reservation.
author: Mat Z.

description: I had to wait over an hour to get inside. They had terrible seating organization and took forever to seat my friends and i because we were a group of 7. It was rather annoying to wait all that time for this meal.
author: Yodha D.

description:
A friend and I came here on a Sunday afternoon at about 12:30pm and luckily the place was not packed like it usually is! We were seated right away. I really liked the bench in the middle of the restaurant and the bar that is open at the entrance. I'm sure that helps keep people occupied during long waits!

The food here was good! I ordered the regular Orenchi ramen and shared the salmon roe. The ramen was tasty - I get why the place is so popular - but I would say that the salmon roe is a must-try. For eating salmon roe for the first time, I was pretty pleased with it and would suggest it to those who like fish eggs and/or uni.

Nothing to complain about from this place. However, there wasn't anything spectacular about it either. My friend and I paid about $20 each for our meal. The tea alone was $9 which I thought was pricey, but we were happy with our meals and would come here again. Good food for normal SF prices, and it was nice to not have to wait long for a seat so definitely come here on a Sunday afternoon if you're dying to try the place and you don't want to wait in line!
author: Alexis R.

description:
Overall rating: 3 Stars

Ambience: pretty modern with wood decor. they take off the glass windows and serve drinks for those waiting outside. pretty neat!

Reservations: no resos, first come first serve basis. lines are pretty long on the weekends but if you go on a weekday, you'll be seated pretty easily. I went there at 6:30PM and there was no wait 

Parking: street parking available but hard to find. 

Service: has been hit or miss for me with this. depends on how busy they are

Food: don't expect the same quality food as orenchi in santa clara. the ramen was okay and the karaage disappointing. the highlight for me was the takoyaki!
- Orenchi Ramen: pretty disappointed because i was comparing it with the orenchi in santa clara. pretty much a standard tonkatsu based ramen
- Beyond Ramen: I thought this was better than the orenchi ramen. more flavor in the broth. I added the soft-boiled egg which they really nailed!
- Age Takoyaki: so delicious! must order. i'm normally not a takoyaki fan 
- Karaage: pretty dry pieces. it felt like they were fried a few times and wasn't as juicy as the ones in santa clara
author: Bee H.

description:
Loud! Super loud but at least they play cool hip hop and r&b. Expect a wait but the wait seems to go by quickly because service is quick and on top of things.
