I waited an hour but it didn't feel like an hour because the exterior of the restaurant has windows where you can order a beer or sake or even a small appetizer while you wait. Genius! I don't mind waiting but this is the perfect way and you won't keep looking at the clock.

The ramen is ok. Only thing is there's 4 options and two of them are similar. What's nice was they give you a whole egg but the only problem was the egg on the inside was cold. They have a huge list of appetizers tho. I ordered the spicy chicken karage. Sauce was good and the chicken was juicy but they were chicken wings. I saw the regular karage and those were chunks of fried chicken so I think they should call them chicken wings. Not karage. 

My overall experience was good. And I would definitely go back to try some other things. And I would definitely try to go down to Santa Clara and try the original restaurant for comparison too
author: Gina S.

description:
I love the atmosphere here, its one of those restaurants where (if you go early) you can just sit and talk forever and the vibe is very relaxing. Sort of like a bar, but instead of drinks, you get ramen. 

We started off with the Chicken Karaage which was steaming hot and fresh from the deep fryers. The chicken was moist and tender, the skin fried to the perfect amount of crispiness and chewiness. The only thing was that it wasn't spiced/salted enough, so we had to salt it ourselves. Other than that, no complaints!

I got the Orenchi Beyond bowl, which was oddly light for a pork soup base! I had read from their menu that they try to make the soup light and brothy without being too heavy; after the first sip of the soup, it was evidently clear that they had succeeded in making that light broth despite its heavy pork and fatty undertones. I'm personally not a huge fan of bamboo shoots or mushroom so I omitted those items from my bowl. The noodles were perfectly cooked, Al Dente, and the entire combination with the hot soup, soft boiled egg, pork (which was so well cooked it fell off my chopsticks whilst trying to pick it up) and seaweed made this bowl entirely enjoyable. Compared to my top ramen favourites (Nojo, Mensho) Orenchi goes nicely in the middle rankings--definitely a good bowl when one is craving more than satisfactory ramen, but not the best in my opinion, and $13 a bowl is pushing it a little. Could be worse though.
author: Jennifer S.

description:
TL;DR - Overhyped food with a ridiculous wait time. Try to come early to avoid the wait!

Holy moly - I was pretty excited to come and try this place since I've heard that the Orenchi in Santa Clara is amazing, but ended up being disappointed with the quality of food.

My friends and I (group of 4) got there around 5:20pm and asked the host how long the wait would approximately take. Looking at the list, he estimated 45-60 min. After waiting an hour, we went back to check the line and he told us it would be another 45-60 min. This was upsetting because one of his main jobs was to manage the waitlist, and he couldn't even set realistic expectations! If I had known the wait would be a total of 2 hours, I definitely would've gone somewhere else to eat and come back another time.   

When my group finally got seated, we order the fried chicken karaage (regular) as an appetizer. My friends got the Beyond Ramen, and I ordered the Orenchi. We were told that if you like salty things, you should get the Beyond. When our order came, I noticed that they missed an egg in my ramen (it's included). They were really good about it and brought an extra out. It sucked though because the egg was cold and even after soaking it in my soup for a considerable amount of time, I still couldn't manage to warm it up.

Flavor-wise, I'm not a huge fan of the Orenchi. Generally love Tonkatsu broth, but mine tasted like a mix between Tonkatsu and a bunch of sauce accidentally dumped in from the bamboo they include. If that's the intended flavor, it's probably just not my thing. Noodles did not particularly stand out. Chicken Karaage was pretty good though! Crunchy on the outside and very moist on the inside. Overall, I've definitely had better ramen in the city.
author: Rose Y.

description: Small intimate setting. Sat at the bar with the window view. The Orenchi noodle was great. I got the larger size but probably would have been fine with the regular.
author: Danielle G.

description: Great food, music and enviroment. We came in a group of 5 and we loved it! Was everything we were looking for!
author: Barbara O.

description: Great ambiance, came by at 11pm for late night noodles. I would not recommend any of the chicken ramen (broths weak and lack depth) but the pork is very satisfying.
author: T Y.

description:
I've been to the original Orenchi in santa clara and I think this new edition on Valencia is also very good!  

Decor: trendy, open restaurant where you can see the large vats of ramen cooking in the kitchen.

Food: I thought the ramen was great! To me the broth and chewyness of noodles are the most important aspects of good ramen, and I think Orenchi does well on both factors.  The pork slices were delicous too, although I wish they gave you more slices of pork.

Price: $12 a bowl, would be awesome if they had ramen happy hour where you could get a bowl for $8. You can add plenty of extras to your ramen if you want to pay for it such as extra meat, extra noodles, an egg, etc. 

Service: Better than I expected, although they only took 2 credit cards max if I remember correctly. 

I'm happy for this new edition to Valencia!
author: Mary X.

description:
It didn't blow me away like my first few bowls at the original Orenchi in Santa Clara, but it's a welcomed addition to the neighborhood.  

The broth is super rich with just the right level of salt and all of my favorite toppings.  My particular egg was just a tad over perfectly running and the pork was a thin slice that kept it tender, but it likely won't satisfy a big charshu fan.

The space itself is quite cool with the 'outdoor bar' in front (though I was imagining it'd be more like Bar Agricole when it's really a takeout window) and high ceilings with 'urban outfittery' decor.

We went 15 minutes before opening on a rainy evening to put our name down and made the first seating with some parties to spare.  Even as a ramen lover, I wouldn't wait more than 40 minutes for a bowl, but nommers can't be choosers.
author: Krystle S.

description:
I went for lunch yesterday and was hugely disappointed!  I ordered the Orenchi Ramen which was a pricey $12.  They do not offer a lunch menu and they do not do to-go orders.  There were very few pieces of pork and the meat was overdone.  Worse of all,  the broth/soup base was way too salty and had a strong bamboo flavor.  It was as if I was drinking a cup of salt.  For the rest of the afternoon, all I could taste in my mouth was salt.  This place is overhyped and I won't be back.  

2 stars for the atmosphere and decor and also the friendly service.
author: Bel L.

description:
First time going tonight and the wait was fine, just 30 minutes for a party of 2. 'Stuff' is right next door so we went over to window shop.

Once we sat, the blaring music was totally noticeable, with the servers' Japanese welcome greeting literally drowned out by Leonard Skynrd - Freebird (the long version). The cooks yelled hello/goodbye with everyone coming/going as well, but you honestly couldn't hear it. I don't design restaurants for a living, but I'm pretty sure the overall ambiance would go up considerably if the monster jams were turned off completely.

The ramen itself was ordinary. Ken Ken and Ramen Shop in Oakland have much more complex broths in comparison. The broth portions were fine, but like others have said, the pork slice you get is fairly paltry.

Unless I'm being taken there on someone else's dime, doubtful I'd go back. But hey, we can say we went, right?
author: Justin H.

description:
Ramen was very good. I like it better than underground.

Service was little off...
- brought my ramen before appetizer 
- brought my check before appetizer
- after three requests brought me my karage spicy chicken
author: Michael V.

description:
When I lived in the South Bay I'd line up at 5:30pm for a bowl of Orenchi ramen down there, so now that I'm in the city I had to try Beyond. Was not disappointed at all! 

The line's much shorter here, and heat lamps outside made waiting comfy. Once inside, the atmosphere is at once intimate and expansive, and made me feel much more hip than I really am. I ordered the Orenchi Ramen and it's still great. Also had delish Takoyaki and Tori Soba, and fantastically friendly and attentive service.

Edit: I raised it to 5 stars because every time I go in I feel like the service gets better and better. Makes me feel like I'm in Japan again :)
author: Tria C.

description: Tasted like something out of Japantown, and not in the good way.  Pretty bland tasting and flavorless.  The effort put in seemed weak sauce.  Not even close to Iza Ramen or Izakaya Goku (both in the Mission).  They are open til midnight on weekends, so if you're in the mood for some snacks later at night then why not.  The vibe is fun, huge open warehouse space and a communal table vibe.
author: A A.

description: It's a good place, except I don't eat meat but usually okay with meat broths.  I thought I'd go ahead and order the ramen but for me, the broth was very very pork tasting, which I think most people love, but it was too overwhelming for me. Otherwise, it's a great place with yummy toppings and I love the windows to the kitchen with the huge big vats of broth, hot water they're cooking the noodles in.  The waiters are all hip and friendly, and we did have to wait about 10 minutes.
author: Elizabeth R.

description:
Low quality toppings with soup that pairs well with noodles. Just like their Santa Clara location. But that's okay. It's a fine bowl of ramen and it's still affordable. You're not paying $25 a bowl (but maybe we should) so it's fine. 

The soba is better than you would expect. Noodles pair really well with the soup & are perfectly cooked. 

They offer Sapporo in ~10 ounce glasses for $3 though! Perfect amount of beer for a bowl of ramen. 

Ramen becomes fine and decadent with a light beer :)
author: Margaret S.

description:
My first impression was that the dance party music is a bit oddball. I kept having deja vu from when I was out at the club a few weeks ago. And it's on the loud side, so don't expect to be having an in-depth conversation with your fellow diners.
I did like that you can order a beer (or sake, or tea) while you wait outside, which if the line were any longer would be really nice. Lucky for us, on a rainy Tuesday night, it only took about 10 minutes until we were seated.

As for the ramen, I can only really say "Meh". It was ok. I got the Orenchi Beyond, and my g/f got the regular Orenchi. The Beyond was definitely a bit richer, but neither one of them really wowed us - the flavor in both varieties was just not that complex. The chashu was possibly the most thinly sliced I've ever experienced in ramen. Their noodles I also found to be of slightly odd consistency; they were a bit thicker and chewier than I tend to like them. That's obviously personal preference, though, and not a knock on them.

We also got the takoyaki, which was almost liquid inside and pretty darn tasty, though the octopus was a bit tough.

They do have some nice fancy tea selections, and the beer list is functional. When we were there, they only had Sapporo on tap.

In all, I'd put it pretty firmly middle of the pack in terms of quality. It's got nothing on the San Mateo Trio (Santa / Dojo / Parlor).
author: Don H.

description:
Pretty darn good actually. I got the Orenchi Ramen and it had a very good deep flavor like a tonkotsu that's been slow cooking for 18 hours as they state on their menu. What stood out for me was the depth of flavor while still being light and not overly fatty. The flavor was well balanced, not too salty and not too oily. 

Noodle texture is extremely important to me and I really liked theirs. It was thick, crinkly and perfectly al dente.

I would have given it 5 stars if the chashu was thicker as it was sliced pretty darn thin and it wasn't melt in your mouth tender. In addition, the egg was flavorless and cold.
author: Ted V.

description: The orenchi ramen is less salty than the beyond ramen. That's all we tried this time and we'll be back for sure. Save yourself an hour of wait time by showing up 30 minutes before they open and getting seated in 35 minutes.
author: Jeff B.

description: Very hip ramen place. We tried orenchi ramen with seasoned egg. Ramen was great so far with thick and good tasting broth. But it has small portion and toppings like bamboo shoots and chashu were too small. About the vibes of this place, I'd say, its pretty impressive. Chill music and interior design was modern and chic.
author: Sofie L.

description:
Finally came to try this place after all of the hype about the Santa Clara location. The first thing you notice is the cool ambiance. They did a great job with the space. I liked that you can see into the kitchen with the huge pots for the ramen noodles and broth. We came in with a large group that arrived at different times. Luckily it was slow on a Monday night and our waitress was really accommodating. 
We started with the chicken wings, edamame, and a lot of beer. I love that their menu is so simple! For ramen, I decided on the orenchi ramen. It is tonkotsu based and has pork belly, an egg, green onion, bamboo, mushroom, and seaweed. It surprisingly wasn't that good. I didn't get a lot of noodles and the broth was pretty bland. Luckily garlic and siracha can make the broth better. The pork piece I got was also very fatty. I also thought it was really pricey for what it is ($13 for a bowl).
author: Alisha K.

description: It is way under what I have expected for this restaurand. As for food all of them are very salty. I have order the ramen it only have a piece of pork in top of it. I have been to a lot of Japanese Restaurant this is my first time not feeling good after the dinner with my friends. I would say this but high end Japanese restaurant PRICE but low on the Quality and quantity food. Sad....
author: Ronald T.

description:
Small portion, probably should've gotten an appetizer. My Ramen had like one slice of pork....
Salty
Expensive
LOUD

Needless to say, I was pretty disappointed. I hope the one in sunnyvale taste better because I dont see why people go crazy for them.
author: Erica L.

description:
I love the orenchi in sunnyvale but this place is very mediocre.

Ordered:
- takoyaki: did not disappoint! Soft, gooey, and chewy
- negitoro (spicy tuna rice bowl): skip, it was bland 
- calamari legs: lacked the crunchy texture but still delicious 
- beyond ramen: I thought it was super salty
- spicy karaage: they need to mention that they're not the regular karaage with spice, they're chicken WINGS with spicy sauce. 

Service:
Service was on point. They were super attentive and nice. While you're waiting, they offered drinks and appetizers.

I was glad they made an orenchi in sf but I think I'll just be going to the sunnyvale one. Unless I want pocky at the end of my meal and I'm in the area.. Just maybe..
author: Lia L.

description:
Good but not great, I think ramen dojo is better.

I would go back again because it's closer than Santa Clara
author: Sean S.

description: I absolutely love everything about this place. The food, the music, and the art is as good as it gets. It's different because i believe the broth is garlic based but so tastyyyy and the karaage is absolutely amazing !! its a plus that they open late nights for all you drunk people
author: Isa T.

description: Food is great. We ordered the takoyaki for appetizers. It was really. Very flavorful. I had the orenchi ramen for dinner. The broth was so good, noodles was not soggy. The toppings was adequate for its serving. Not too little. Service was excellent. The place is busy but the staff was efficient. They really mean business. No movement or action was wasted. It was run like a well oiled machine. The place itself is a little small but the lighting, high ceilings, and decor mesh well together. Great experience for my first time here. Definitely highly recommended. And I'll be back. For sure!
author: Gladys P.

description: Tried the Orenchi ramen today.  Broth was very flavorful, noodles thick and chewy.  While they do charge for extra toppings, the Orenchi ramen already comes with a plethora of delicious toppings, which is nice.  Delicious!
author: Jeff T.

description: Get the pork lovers meal!  It says it's for 2 and it's probably enough for 4 average people!  Or, just get your grub on and defeat it yourself!!  So good.
author: Mark H.

description: One of my favorite Ramen joints in SF. Very solid ramen, with quality (homemade?) noodles and broth. It's a fancier dining experience than your standard ramen bar (like Ramen Underground). First Ramen place I'd pick if dining with a group.
author: John D.

description:
Trendy ramen spot but the food simply wasn't great. The ramen and soba flavors weren't especially exciting. The appetizers were harder to go wrong with but similarly lacking. The one bright spot was the perfect pork shoulder in the ramen. 

Definitely not worth the wait.
author: Andrew M.

description: I only had the time and money to try the ramen today. The broth was rich and delicious, but not too salty. The noodles were thick and chewy and delicious. The egg was whole! I'll be back for more. $15 including tax and tip for a bowl of ramen.
author: Julie G.

description:
Orenchi is where it's at. It's hyped, and I think it's deserved.

The WAIT can be next-level, but it seems to be getting better these days. If the waitlist is long, Zeitgeist is across the street, but don't get ham sauced to the point where you're eating pizza by the slice next door.
author: Marcus C.

description:
Good but not great. I definitely wouldn't wait over an hour to eat here...it's just ramen, people, and there are plenty of good restaurants down Valencia.

The broth is tasty. The pork is tender and tasty but there was not enough of it. The noodles were good but nothing special. We didn't have to wait long to be seated but it was the Christmas weekend so that might not be typical.

The decor was very modern and industrial, the noise level a tad loud but not outrageously so. They needed to crank up the heat because it was pretty chilly inside for the first 10 minutes or so after opening.

So, overall we enjoyed our meal but three stars about covers it. If you're craving ramen this is definitely a place to consider.
author: Bob B.

description: This is one of my favorite places for ramen in SF. Simple, pared down menu in a fantastic space. A giant rolling door opens the building to the street where waiting guests can have a drink at the double-sided bar opening right onto the sidewalk. Stainless steel vats of broth bubble behind glass at the back of the restaurant. Dim lighting and hip hop add to the night life feel. It can get a bit crowded on the weekends, but I love popping in on a weeknight for a quick bite. Service is friendly and quick.
author: Matthew B.

description: Nice spot, friendly staff, food was just okay. Didn't have much flavor, good thing they have a bowl of garlic on each table as that helped.  Was expecting more from their ramen.
author: Dilly M.

description: Really good, enthusiastic service. Good vibe. REALLY tempted to give 'em 3 starts for the food. The Ramen was tasty but not the best I've had at that price point in SF. Mine was missing a couple things but the servers rectified the situation right way. Overall, worth a visit.
author: Rob G.

description: The food was great/affordable, the staff was amazing, and the sake was plentiful.  The staff explained the artwork on tables and wall, then hooked us up with some extra sake.  Overall great experience!
author: Matt M.

description: After hearing all the hype about the Santa Clara branch, I was looking forward to trying this one.  No wait whatsoever during lunch on a weekday. The noodles are good, not soggy.  Be careful asking for "extra spicy" as it is much spicier than other Bay Area ramen places.  Service is good. I would recommend if in the area, but wouldn't make a special trip.  Much better options in the Peninsula or South Bay.
author: somel y.

description: Yummmyyyyyy! Great ramen ! The broth was very flavorful and delicious. Service is fast and the ambiance is really cute. Some interesting and delicious appetizer choices too! Highly recommend . Also the beer comes in a cool metal glass and is extra refreshing!
author: Theresa C.

description: Great food, great service, and I love the decor! The staff is excellent! Its a great vibe. It seems like they have some new items not at the Santa Clara location. Its become my go-to ramen place.
author: Gary L.

description: Hip joint, cool music, cool employees and really good ramen.
author: Will D.

description: Like Orenchi in Santa Clara, Orenchi Beyond serves the best ramen in the Bay Area, but the wait times are much better at Beyond. Great food, and great service. I enjoyed the Beyond Ramen, which was a menu item unique to the location here.
author: Michael B.

description:
To the amusement of my coworkers, when I found out that Santa Clara's ever-so-popular Orenchi Ramen was expanding to the Mission, I squealed like a little girl. My passion for ramen runs deep, and possibly obsessive.  With no car, you have no idea how long I've been waiting for a satisfying bowl of ramen. (Sozai or Underground doesn't cut it imho). It's long overdue for me to pay my visits to see my beloved girlfriend: the tonkotsu ramen.

I've been here twice now, and ordered three bowls. I can tell you with confidence that Orenchi makes the best damn ramen in the city. Owner Ozawasan has done an excellent job maintaining the classic Orenchi flavor to this new location. 


Here are details on their classic Orenchi Ramen:
- SOUP: The tonkotsu soup is on point -- a very traditional tokotsu style which is a little lighter in surface taste. It goes against the trend these days of making the broth thicker and thicker. It's very refreshing to have a bowl of ramen that isn't a sodium bomb or a BP oil-spill. The umami, however, is anything but light; it's deep to the bone, and it's fucking fantastic. I would say, Ippudo's Akamaru is the only ramen broth that beats this in North America (that I've tried).
- NOODLES: Thicker and chewier than the average ramen. It's definitely made with more 'kansui' alkaline water, which is very apparent with the springy-ness and the earthy aroma it gives off. The thickness really helps here because it clings to the broth more so than the conventional ramen noodles. Unfortunately, I don't think they serve kaedama (noodle refills), which would have been awesome.
- CHASHU. It's very thin, but very delicious. I was very impressed when I saw the workers blow torch the surface of the ramen before serving. Making chashu is a very tedious process that involves refrigeration and is usually served room temperature on top of the broth. And yes of course, the chashu is rolled, not slabbed, which allows for a the "melt-in-your-mouth" feeling due to the higher moisture content. Kudos to that.
- EGG: It tastes like sex. Should I even say more? Not only is it a soft-boiled egg, but it's not over-marinated. Basically, it doesn't have an overpowering soy-sauce taste like many other ramen shops, and you can actually taste the sugar and ginger. This definitely goes well with the lighter Orenchi broth, and this may be one reason why the more heavier, garlicy Beyond Ramen doesn't come with an egg.
- OTHER TOPPINGS: Aside from the egg and chashu, the toppings are standard and nothing fancy. I'd like to point out that the menma (fermented bambooshoots) was NOT overpowering for me, like another review pointed out.


Some things that bothered me:
- This place is too trendy! From a business standpoint, Ozawasan did a fantastic job maintaining the same great ramen but adding to it a "Valencia"-vibe. Ramen is $12 instead of $9.80. The space is sleek with aluminum and a red tinted entrance. It's perfect for SF, it's perfect for Valencia street, and therefore there is probably lots of money to be made. Call me traditional, but I am a big fan of the cozy, "hole-in-the-wall" aura ramen shops give off. Others may disagree, but the space in the Santa Clara Orenchi still has this vibe despite its popularity.
- In Orenchi Beyond, there are no individual tables, but more long benches for the customers to sit in a line -- it's harder to have a meaningful interaction with the staff here. (Staff are really nice though! I think they are doing a great job).
- Their bowl of ramen is on the smaller side, and the chashu is pretty thin.
- The wait. However, you can order drinks and snacks while you do!

Overall, this is a fantastic ramen, and I believe it's worth the wait. If it means anything to the reader, I like the Orenchi ramen better than Daikokuya's (LA), or Shinsengumi's Hakata ramen (LA), but Ippudo's Akamaru ramen (NY) slightly beats it. I also think Orenchi ramen would do quite well as an lower-top tier ramen in Japan.
author: Jamie T.

description: Pretty good ramen and appetizers, good ambiance, decent prices, good beer. My only complaint is it seems a bit crowded and busy.
author: Anthony P.

description: I loved this place! Ramen was sooo good! Menu offers a variety of great appetizers, fun environment and prices reasonable for ramen. Most importantly the broth and noodles are made in house!
author: Leslie S.

description: Nice decor and ramen was good.  I'd go again if I was nearby.  But not so amazing that the quality of the ramen makes me crave that particular restaurant.
author: Colette H.

description:
If you are coming for a good Ramem experience, you will be very disappointed. 

And other reviews that warned you about the food been too salty, they are absolutely right.

We started with the chilled egg plant, the flavor is ok, but so salty. 

Then the squid legs. It was overcooked. The legs are very tough. 

Then the Ramen. I had the Beyond Ramem, my wife had the Orenchi Ramen. Both looked great when put on the table. The noodle is the thick kind, cooked al dente. I think is a bit hard but acceptable. But the soup, OMG, it is so salty! Never had any like this. This soup lacks any other flavor. I think it was just soy sauce + salt water. 

I think the place is trying to be a hip izakaya where you can also order ramen. But, man, the food is just such big disappointment. 

The ambiance is also not good, the speaker was playing some loud south american pop, kind of a weird choice for a Japanese restaurant. I am not really sure what the deco is trying to be. 

No going back again. And I won't recommend this place to anyone.
author: Kevin L.

description: I'm a fan of Orenchi in Santa Clara so I had to try Orenchi Beyond. Had a great time here too! Good vibe. Great service. And I also like that they have old favorites from Orenchi (i.e. Orenchi Ramen), but also new ramen and appetizers to try. I'll definitely come back!
author: Oliver C.

description: Excellent ramen! First time having sake on tap and really enjoyed it. Lots of space and service was friendly. I regular the South Bay location and look forward to more trips to the SF location.
author: Patrick C.

description: I had gone into San Francisco with friends and as we were looking for places to eat, we happened to pass by Orenchi as they were setting up for the dinner run. When it comes to ramen, I'm not a picky person, but the two friends I was with that night were both seasoned travelers to Japan and they both enjoyed it very much. Since we were on a time crunch, we didn't opt for too much other than the flagship ramen they sell. It came pretty quickly, some of the noodles were a little bit firm, but otherwise, the broth, meat and the noodles that sat in the soup a little longer were all absolutely tasty. Couldn't complain, when the bill arrived for the three of us it was about 36 dollars.
author: Zach W.

description:
food: 5 STARS
overall: 4.5 stars

Pros:
- the thick NOODLES are so so chewy and stay firm even after soaking in the broth
- soft-boiled egg was so soft with flow-y yolk in the center and omg it was perfect
- broth is creamy with the right amount of fattiness
- chashu is soft and juicy with a little bit of fat
- service is decently quick (during soft-opening)
- ambience + decor are trendy and youthful

Cons:
- the wait (duh.) We arrived at 5:45 and were seated at 6:25
- last order is taken at 9:30 pm
- not good for large groups (there were a bunch of 4 person groups who were seated after me although they were way ahead of me on the wait list)

Bottom line: I would 100% revisit. The noodles were probably one of the best ramen noodles I have ever had. While I've had better tonkotsu broth in my life, Orenchi's was still very good. A bowl of ramen is reasonably priced at $12 (it's basically an entire meal) and trumps most bowls over $15 (cough cough Ippudo NY). Definitely worth the wait.
author: Jiann M.

description: Yay ! Orenchi in the city. Ramen taste as good as santa clara. Hipster vibe, a cool outdoor bar to get a beer while you wait, and a long wait. But so so good!
author: Coco T.

description: I got there 5:45 pm on Tuesday 11/18. Wait until 6:15 pm. I ordered Orenchi  Ramen, and my friend order Beyond Ramen Oomori (Large Bowl). We also add Age Takoyaki as appetizer. Takoyaki is oooooooooishiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiii. The broth is very rich yet not too salty, smelled and taste so good with mashed garlic. I personally love the bamboo shoot in the ramen. They are juicy and brittle at the same time. Also, the Nori taste different than other ramenya, has more flavor on it.  I really like this place, and I will visit again.
author: Kay K.

description: Beautiful, open, hip space. I've never been to Orenchi in South Bay so I went in with no expectations. I'm a fan of Himawari in San Mateo, Santouka in San Jose and Shinsegumi and Daikokuya in Los Angeles and Orenchi definitely measured up. I ordered the Beyond Ramen which had a tonkotsu broth base and the noodles were topped with mizuna and garlic chips. I also added an egg which was cooked with a perfectly runny center. Spot on. The noodles were what made it stand apart from the rest of the pack. They were a lot thicker than I've experienced...probably more similar to the noodles I tried in Japan. Thoroughly enjoyed the chicken karaage as well - spicy (wings) and non-spicy (dark meat pieces). Bowls are around $12 a pop, but worth it. Oh, and parking was pretty easy on a Sunday evening. We got there right when it opened at 5pm. I'll be back!
author: Lisa H.

description: It's my fave Ramen joint near my work and I love it.  Yummy ramen, dope hip hop, excellent service...oh and it's near my work.
author: Deborah V.

description: Food poisoning from eating there last night. The only thing I ate before dinner at 8pm there was pizza at 1pm, so it wasn't the pizza. Woke up in the middle of the night last night with all the symptoms. Sigh.
author: Jessica C.

description: I always thought this place was okay coming from the Santa Clara location.  The line was always crazy. With this location, there wasn't a wait at all during lunch time. I  had the beyond ramen with an egg and for me I don't really like the broth, it wasn't flavorful. However, the side order of chicken was awesome!!!
author: Nhung T.

description: Not a fan. Was looking good coming in...stylish decor, inked up staff, , kinda trendy and in my hood!! But damn, couldn't be more disappointed.  Had the Orenchi Ramen as is.  The presentation was meh...but who cares, it's how it tastes.  First sip of broth I got a fishy taste and smell.  It's pork stock for the broth but that smell and fishiness was pretty distinct and permeating everything in the bowl.  I tried to eat it because I was starving but that ish was nasty.  Sorry but that's the truth.
author: Ramon L.

description: I ordered the Orenchi Beyond Ramen. 1 star for good texture of noodles, and another for good broth. No stars for extremely small portions.  I frantically tried to search for pork and found two small scraps of thinly sliced (yet admittedly delicious) pork.  Not much veggies either.  After eating a bowl of ramen, I left feeling still hungry and had to have another full meal.
author: Eric C.

description: Really great ramen, if you can stand the wait.  This ramen isn't as thick as Iza Ramen, but is still really tasty.
author: Corey C.

description:
I really like this place, and have been six or seven times. I live around the corner, and can go at random times when there's no wait (usually when the open for lunch on weekends), so that probably biases my opinion.  However, when I do have to wait, it's not so bad since they have a bar, and can have a beer while waiting. 

I always get the Orenchci ramen, which is very consistent and very tasty in my opinion, but I'm not a ramen snob. The Beyond ramen was okay, but not as good. The only thing better than the ramen is the service. These guys are great.

For the price, it's a great bowl of ramen - especially compared to some of the other trendy ramen restaurants.
author: Courtney S.

description:
I live right by this place and was excited a noodle place was opening nearby. I went there the other day to ask for a to-go menu.  They were closed but the door was open and I figured I'd stop in, grab a menu so I could look over it and perhaps order something to pick up later that night (there is no menu in the window).

There was some guy sitting by a laptop and because I had my dog I didn't want to walk in so I called in to ask him if he could help me.

The guy could not have been LESS helpful, he acted like I had asked him to donate a kidney or something.  First thing he acted all pissed off and told me that they were closed and I said I could see that but all I wanted was a menu to order food later but it still seemed like I was bothering the crap out of him.  They didn't have a menu I could take and their web site doesn't (at the time of writing this) have a menu posted.

Here's a tip for ya... you just spend thousands of dollars to open a new restaurant, a potential customer walks in who lives nearby and eats out at least two meals a day, don't act like they are a pain in the butt.  Be polite and at the very least you could have said "sorry we are closed right now and don't have any menus you can take but here is a menu you can take a look at and we'd love for you to come back when we are open to try the food".

Unbelievable how someone can spend so much money to open a restaurant and not give a crap about customer service.  About one in every four restaurants close every year, my guess is this place will fall into the group that fail unless they learn how to treat customers.
author: Deke R.

description:
Surprised to see that there is no line at this restaurant. The one in Santa Clara is packed all the time. Really good ramen. I had the Orenchi Ramen, good flavor and low fat. Be careful of the hours as they only open Tue to Thur for lunch.

Been here multiple times now and have never been disappointed. This is my all time favorite ramen place now!
author: John L.

description: Ambiance and wait staff were great.  Food was okay.  Didn't seem like much of a variety there.
author: Jer M.

description: I am a vegetarian and I really find it annoying that they don't substitute anything for vegetarians. They are not even open to the idea. Be warned of this when you get their ramen soy based. It was what I got. The soy ramen was bad, too salty and tastes like I'm drinking soy sauce. It's not miso soy but soy. Will not return.
author: Johnny H.

description: Ehh...I think the santa clara one taste better. Their apps are much better. We had the fried octopus...so mushy. But still this place is better than Ramen Dojo!
author: Alyce l.

description: This is the 2nd spot of the infamous Orenchi in San Jose. Love the modern layout, especially the open bar window that serves beer, sake and cocktails while you wait. If you want a spot when they open at 6pm be sure to come at least 20 min earlier. Great vibes and friendly staff. A welcome addition to mission!
author: Kristen C.

description: Man, I really wanted to like this place more, especially since everyone who works here seems pretty cool. I had the orenchi ramen, oomori (larger portion), and it was just okay. Disappointed that only one thin slice of pork was in there, and the "oomori" size didn't seem that much larger, but it was overall not bad, especially when you add a teaspoon of garlic puree. Also had the takoyaki, which was pretty good, and a (metal) glass of Stone Warrior beer.
author: Maximillian M.

description: I've been to four ramen places. Two of them were fantastic, one was quite good, then there was Orenchi - perfectly mediocre, and therefore quite disappointing. Cool space, neat ambiance, good service, and sub-par food.  I got Beyond Ramen, my friend got Orenchi Ramen. I think Orenchi Ramen is slightly better than Beyond Ramen, but neither is good ramen.
author: Joseph B.

description:
I was already a fan of the Santa Clara location like many so I was very excited to have them branch off into the city which is much closer to me.  The differences are significant but most are good though I do miss the charm of the original. 

We came here last night expecting the hype but arrived with no line to see.  We entered the restaurant waiting to be greeted but it took a couple minutes.  We later realized there was a sign up list in the window that we walked by and didn't notice.  Not that it was necessary but if that was a requirement it probably should be displayed a little better.  

This location is far more stylish than it's forefather. The kitchen is wide open behind glass so you can look up close at the chefs manning the noodle station and the cauldrons of soup.  The seating is all communal so be prepared for that along with no backs to seats as they are all stylish looking tree stumps.  The bar seats do have back though if you need that. All the little details from the art, decor, windows, to the bathrooms all work together well and compliment the dining experience.  We did not experience the DJ being there so we weren't blown away by the loud music others have mentioned. 

We sat at the bar and were greeted warmly by the gentleman working that area.  I did notice a bit of a stench from some dish washing buckets sitting on the other side of the bar.  It would have been nice if these were placed out of sight. It didn't bother my friend so maybe it was just me.  He took the time to go over the plethora of appetizers available and we settled on Tako-Wasabi.  I'm a big fan of octopus but my friend hadn't experienced much of it before though she was not against trying something new.  When it arrived it wasn't what I expected visually.  It looked like what I'd imagine to be what grizzly bear snot would look like. The taste however was amazing. Some of the best octopus I've ever had. My hesitant friend loved it as well.  If you can get past the look and texture (which I loved) it's a great little app.  I did suggest serving it on a piece of nori or seaweed cracker. 

Lets get to the reason why we we came, the ramen. There were two options for ramen as well as two options for soba. We both ordered each of the ramens. Orenchi and Beyond.  We shared each others ramens and agreed that the noodles were perfectly made firm and slurpable. The broth on each one was very good the beyond tasted and felt a little lighter than the Orenchi.  Neither of them reminded me of my experience in Santa Clara but both were solid bowls of ramen.  Egg was tasty and we both agreed the pork slices were a little small. I added nori and fish cakes in mine. Only the Nori made a difference for me. What we both did try was the chopped garlic at the bar which made the broth a little more flavorful if you like garlic.  We had to talk later so we went easy on the garlic.  

Overall we both liked Orenchi a lot and plan to go back. The Tako Wasabi alone was worth the trip.  A fun dish if you can power through the uniqueness of it.
author: Joco F.

description: To be honest the first time I went, the ramen sucks! Too oily, only one piece of meat and a tiny bowl. The price doesn't worth tht little portion of food. Especially it doesn't taste gd. Today I decided to give this place a second chance, is better and their bowl is bigger than last time! But still they only give out one slice of pork for every single bowl! Plus is still too oily!!! Customer service was only ok:( with tht kind of price, portion and taste I would rather pay more for some where else! Oh one more thing spoon was hella dirty!!!!
author: Sally C.

description: Not impressed.  Not at all sure what the hype is about - the ramen was mediocre and the noodles themselves nothing special (in fact, less than special).  Very expensive for what it is but the many sheep of San Francisco seem to be lining up to get sheared.
author: Stan B.

description: love the tankatsu ramen here. And the fried chicken is pretty good too. Waits are long and the seating cozy but the trade off is worth it.
author: SFA M.

description: Broth had a feral funk aroma to it. Fortunately flavor was there. Typical mission-sized chasu portion was as thin as a slice of bologna. Ways to bust out the meat slicer, boys. Appreciate it.
author: Anthony R.

description: Looking for hipster ramen? Well Orenchi Beyond is your place. I had the Orenchi Ramen and it was pretty basic. The consistency of the noodle was good. The wings we had for appetizer was pretty good. Overall I would give this place 3.5 stars. I will say that the venue was nice. The design is great with a nice open space with a bar in the front where you can order appetizers. One thing that I will note that was annoying is that it seems like the servers friends seem to get seated first than us and they were huge parties of like 7 and 8. I hate nepotism.
author: Gary I.

description: The perfect thing to keep me in the land of the living after I had just touched down following a 15 hour journey. The first ever establishment I ate at in SF! Really energetic atmosphere, fast and friendly service, amazing ramen broth and the noodles themselves are really a cut apart.
author: T M.

description:
My girlfriend ordered the Orenchi bowl which came with bamboo shoots seaweed and mushrooms.. The broth was really good. It was rich and full of flavor. Noodles were great, very firm. The egg was cooked perfectly, but was not season. 

When my bowl came I realized they forgot my pork. I asked about it and they brought  one very thin slice on a plate. I was more sad than upset. The broth was also very good. It was rich in tonkatsu flavor but there wasn't much in the soup. My Orenchi experience in the South Bay was much more positive than this.

 The space is really loud it's very busy. The artwork is cool, but the wait and the rushed service won't have me back very soon.

Oolong high drink
author: Mark R.

description: I cannot believe the hype and excitement for this restaurant as I feel the ramen here is mediocre at best. The broth didn't have the complexity and deep nuances that befits a great bowl of ramen. Also, the two  paper thin slices of pork chasu didn't exactly help either. I gave this place an extra star due to the ambiance and the employee's enthusiasm.   I wouldn't go back......
author: GORDON M.

description: The homemade ramen noodles formed a juicy nest in a rich broth. The atmosphere was fun and very loud thanks to the dj spinning hip hop. Three stars for not having a vegetarian option. I hadn't eaten meat in over a year and was very surprised that an SF establishment didn't have an option for me. The pork was good but not worth my first meat in a year. I'd recommend the fun and yummy place to friends but I'll be headed back to Ken Ken next time I crave ramen.
author: Bradley H.

description: Creamy bowls of yummy ramen! There is a wait but while you wait you can order drinks / appetizers to entertain yourself. I've never been to the original Orenchi but I'm sure I would love it!
author: Tara S.

description: Beyond disappointment. Orenchi at Santa Clara is much better.  The noodles had a chewy texture and was not yummy.  The Cha shu slices were only okay. The only thing decent was their soft boiled egg. Not worth $12.  When we wanted the bill, the waitress was incompetent, she did not know to read/charge our credit cards.  Thanks for messing up our bill. Not cool.
author: Ann L.

description: Admittedly, I'm new to the Ramen craze - but this place is really good.  Friendly staff and really really good ramen.  My wife got the "Beyond Ramen" which was smokey and great, I got the "Orenchi Ramen" which was lighter but still had the smoke and earthy mushroom flavors. We'll be back
author: Scott L.

description:
Vegetarian Review: 

It's hard to review this place because I'm vegetarian and I had very limited options. I know I came to a ramen place expecting a vegetarian option, but even some places in Japan have vegetarian broth, so I just expected a SF restaurant to do the same. That being said, they had great service, and my friend seemed to enjoy his ramen. I got the spicy fries which came with a delicious spicy wasabi dipping sauce and the eggplant which were not very good, you can pass on that. Hopefully they add a vegetarian broth in the future.
author: San D.

description:
The wait is the worst thing about this place : (

The building, waiters, and service is awesome!!

The chicken wings were delicious, they had great flavor and were perfectly cooked. The fries were so simple but I could eat bucketfuls of them. The chicken karage had nice crispiness and tasted exactly how it should.

The ramen....Orenchi ramen was a large serving which is nice because usually after ramen I am still hungry. Pork flavor was intense and wanted to order more to go but they do not do that here.

I would go again and again, just beware of the wait.
author: Nicole G.

description: Not as good as the one in San Jose. I hope that's just because you're new and need some time to get it together. Please bring up the noteworthy ramen from down south.
author: Kelly C.

description:
The food decent, the wait not too long on a weeknight if you get your name on the list early. The price... Waayy too much. They charged me extra to take out the pork!! Not only did I have less ingredients, I'm paying more for it!! They purposely gave me a large beer when I asked for a small just so they can squeeze every dollar. Overall super trendy, super fulfilling, super pricey. Luckily I have a job that can support this lifestyle once in a while but if you're looking for a good deal as a local, this is not the place. 
I agree with the previous reviewer, you're not allowed time to digest... Get Out was the message after paying. We want more money from the people waiting outside, suckers. If it's supposed to be fast food, not when you're paying high end prices..
author: Yodlee Y.

description: Went for lunch.  No wait at the door, but we waited a long time for the ramen after sitting down.  The pork sausage was just a hot dog (even served with ketchup!).  The ramen was ok, a bit too salty.  Oh and the music was ridiculously loud.  It felt like sitting at a club at noon.
author: Regina T.

description: Ramen is very authentic but the service leaves something to be desired. They waiters were so aggressive that they we're rushing us out mid meal. 30-minutes in, the bill had already shown up (not at our request). The food is good, but the awful service left a literal bad taste in my mouth.
author: Laura V.

description: 4.5, expect 45 min waits during peak times.  90s hit music mashups.  this location has the "beyond ramen" as well as the standard orenchi ramen.  the beyond is a heavier broth with more bonito flavor and strong garlic.  the black garlic slick really pumps the flavor and nice alkaline noodle but a little softer.  excellent egg (have to add for the beyond but not for the orenchi which is creamier and lighter, still fatty) and light on the cha siu given only 1 piece.  pricey.
author: Rob C.

description:
I am a ramen snob, having previously lived in the ramen capital of Japan for two years.  This makes me super picky about tonkotsu ramen, and I tend to brace for disappointment whenever I try a new ramen place in the area, since it's never just right, since the tastes tend to not be very popular with Westerners, or so my native Japanese colleagues in Japan tell me.

So no, this isn't "just right," but I have to admit, the ramen here is really good.  The broth (I had the shoyu/Orenchi) was really rich, which is where most tonkotsu here gets it wrong (thanks, health freaks of San Francisco).  But at Orenchi Beyond, you can see the congealed pork fat in the broth, little white droplets just swimming on the surface of the broth.  If you think about it for more than a couple seconds, it's gross, but taking a sip of the broth and the noodles (makes sure you slurp!) makes you forget all that stuff about cholesterol and saturated fats.  What is surprising to me is that unlike most other ramen that I've had around here, I didn't feel unnaturally thirsty for the rest of the day, so that says something about the quality too, I think.  

I went on a Saturday afternoon, and there was no line, so it seems like I lucked out in that regard, judging by the other reviewers.  Service was friendly and fine.

The one complaint I do have is that it's a bit expensive.  For the bowl I had, I expected to pay around $8 or so, instead of the nearly $15.  It's the price of living in San Francisco, I guess, but it never fails to irk me.
author: Norman S.

description: Fun atmosphere. Great service. Good food.  If you are put on a wait list, check back soon, because the wait might not take as long as they say. I noticed this happened to us and others. I had the "beyond ramen," and it was very satisfying. For $12, you get a big bowl of tasty broth and noodles along with other additions. I liked the mizuna. The servers were super busy running around but still were able to make us feel welcomed, comfortable, and appreciated. The atmosphere was very casual, crowded, and loud.
author: Patsy O.

description: Chicken karaage was seriously delicious.  The ramen was good, not the best I've had. The broth could be more flavorful.  For a no line Wednesday, it was worth the visit.
author: Eric C.

description: Ramen is salty. No vegetarian ramen options. Super loud so not good for conversation. Spicy tuna was loaded with mayonnaise. Best thing was the octopus balls.
author: helen c.

description: Tried to come here opening weekend, and decided to leave after finding out it was about a 1 and 1/2 hour wait. Waited for the hype to die down a bit, so I came back a month later. Stopped by on a monday night and waited only 20 minutes. Got the Beyond Ramen and added a egg. The broth was very flavorful, and the egg was runny (i love it that way). I also had the chicken wings for an appetizer. It was decent, not a big fan of it though. I'd come back for the ramen, but prefer the South Bay location. But then again, i live in SF and this location right right by home
author: Steve T.

description: First thing you learn is that you always got to wait but luckily, you can order appetizers at the front window. So that's cool. And once you finally get your seat after waiting for 3 hours, you know your ramen is going to be effing amazing.
author: Joshua G.

description: Ramen stacks up with the best. Love music kills it for me though. Can't bring the baby; will bring earplugs for myself next time.
author: Alton Y.

description:
Stick to the ramen, avoid all appetizers

RAMEN
I tried both ramens, the Beyond and Orenchi. The soup base was nice for both. Garlicy for the Beyond. Lighter and sweeter for the Orenchi. This was a decent bowl of ramen. The best in the city for sure and above average for the Bay Area but mediocre by NY/LA/Int'l standards.

The most bizarre adaptation was the use of v thinly sliced cha siu, almost prosciutto thin. It melted instantly in the bowl, disappearing to the bottom. No cha siu/meat texture could be experienced obviously which is a shame. I ordered 2 extra slices which were barely noticeable and melted away. Cha siu is probably the second or third most important element to bowl of ramen and v unsuccessfully executed here. Actually makes me wonder if the chef who developed this version has a proper understanding of ramen at all...

APPS
I ordered 6 appetizers on the menu and they were terrible. Airport dining mediocrity. Prob worse in some cases. 

The fried chicken was fried to a crisp - Dark brown Coke color, dried meat, completely dehydrated, friend in oil that was either overused or stale (lending to the color).

Fermented squid - Acquired taste which I happen to like so won't comment. This comes out of a container so hard to mess up.

Monkfish liver - Surprisingly decent (prob also comes packaged) but overwhelming use of red onion which was the only garnish for soaking up the ponzu. Garnish is key for this dish. Normally daikon or cucumber.

Eggplant - This was completely inedible. Tasted like it had gone bad (rotten) in the fridge. We barely touched it and also commented to the waiter and they didn't take it off the bill.

Takoyaki - Oddly fried. This is meant to be cooked in a steel or iron griddle. Leaving a subtle crisp shell and moist contents inside. This one was fried (again to a crisp and deep dark brown using stale oil) and very mushy inside.

Chicken salad - The chicken was some sort of dehydrated, completely devoid of flavor and nutrient impoverished chicken breast mash. Dry and tasteless like paper. Like they collected spent pieces of chicken after making stock and put it through a processor (v likely how they got it). It's like the vegetable waste leftover from juicing.
author: Sebastian C.

description:
this review is strictly on the ramen.

it's definitely not the greatest ramen if you have tried ramen ippudo (in Japan and NY), BUT I can still say it's probably one of the decent ramen in SF. I ordered the orenchi beyond ramen and it was not that bad. the soup base is tonkotsu, (according to the server it's a salt flavored tonkotsu), not too rich and not salty, (i've tasted a lot of salty soup base, men-oh is one of those places), the pork shoulder was flavorful and portion was about right. the noodle was good, but again, nothing special about it though.  

will i come back here again for the ramen, NO. but will come back for the appetizer.
author: Toni Rose M.

description:
My new favorite ramen spot! I rarely crave ramen but damn orenchi beyond was gooood. I eat at orenchi in Santa Clara once in awhile but orenchi beyond was really beyond the original orenchi! Orenchi beyond also has a more modern and hipster vibe compared to the orenchi in Santa Clara. 

I had the orenchi beyond ramen which is a special at this location. It has a similar tonkatsu broth as the orenchi ramen but has a stronger garlic taste with fresh vegetables that all go very well together. I also had the takoyaki which I was not disappointed by. It had an extra crispy texture to the outside and although the inside didn't taste like the authentic takoyaki with pickled ginger in it, it was certainly delicious. You can upgrade your ramen to a large portion for just a dollar more but I did feel that the regular portion was fairly small because I can never finish a whole bowl by myself but I killed it in minutes. Or it could have been that I was just realllyyy hungry after the long wait...
The wait kind of sucked sitting on a cold rock that I had to share with 10 other people but you can get a beer or an appetizer while waiting. Overall I still thought the beyond ramen was worth the wait and I will definitely be back for more!
author: J K.

description: Cool spot with a good bar and atmosphere. I thought the food was really good, but not 5-star status. To be fair I don't eat pork so I had the vegetarian broth. Definitely worth a visit though! I'll be going back.
author: Jason B.

description:
Loved the design and vibe here... But the ramen is just ok.
The noodle quality was great, the broth is where it was so-so.
I'll come back and give it another try.
author: shirin r.

description:
Gosh with all the lines every time I walked by I thought- this must be GREAT ramen. Finally a place to get some soup with out busting out a second mortgage- well Mission prices. I arrived, sat down, super noisy- Not exactly conducive to telling the waitress what you'd like to have or ask questions about the menu. Why do people think it has to be that loud, it's just not fun yelling over food. 
 I ordered basics- my first time get the ramen and some edamame- yeah sounds right.  I think this will also be my last time. 
The edamame arrived- it was a bowl of grey soy. I didn't think anyone could really kill that bean, but they did. Inside they were mushy, grainy and the texture was ruined not too mention over salted. Yuck- I ate about 6 and stopped. Ok, so it's only a couple of bucks...
Then, the Orenchi ramen shows up. I'm surprised there aren't deer trying to slam down the door because of the salt lick quality of this dish. The texture of the broth was like dishwater- I'm not exaggerating here- just gross. The noodles- I ate them because they tasted less salty than the broth. The meat and the greens just had a dirt quality to them. 
Not once did anyone ask me how was my food. Beginning, middle and end. Nope. Not once. I mean when someone takes an 60% full bowl of ramen away, doesn't ask if you want to take it home and doesn't ask "how was everything"? they are probably afraid to hear the truth. 
I did however, leave a small note on my check letting them know they shouldn't serve the overcooked edamame. There wasn't enough room on the receipt to tell them how bad the ramen was, so I decided to just write it here. 
There's simply no subtlety in their food from what I experienced.. No essence of what a dish that is that complex and what it means to create it perfectly every time. 
I hope they will take the feedback here and create a better dish.
author: Little W.

description: Delicious and fun, although I am reserving a star due to sitting in the freezing cold.  The storefront is not closed to the outside and on a cold, damp night like tonight is freezing. I'm sitting here at the bar in a jacket and scarf!
author: Adam G.

description: Had been waiting to try Orenchi Beyond on Valencia Street since I work nearby and was hoping to find a new favorite ramen place - but was very disappointed.  The ramen itself wasn't that good and had a bit of an iron taste, the seating was really tight and the sound level was SO LOUD that people couldn't talk.  However, the wait staff was really sweet and when I asked if they could turn the music down, I think they did.  It's hip and trendy, if that's what you want.  My favorite ramen places continue to be Ramen Yamadaya in Japantown and Ramen Underground on Kearny Street.
author: karen K.

description: I LOVE this place. I don't usually review restaurants, but there were so many cute details to like about Orenchi. The service was great. There were little hooks under the tables for bags. The tea was expensive but the container it came in was super cute. There's a bar where people can stand outside and there are heaters right above so you'll never be cold. There was a large table of Japanese people (always a good sign). My grandpa loves Japanese food. He said it's the best broth he's ever had (Beyond Ramen). Four stars because the noodles were okay, no kimchi (they apologized for being out of stock), flavorless radish salad, and though the seats were cool they weren't very practical for my grandma who has a bad back.
author: Melissa K.

description: Awesome sauce!  The ramen and the soba are delicious.
author: Conor M.

description: Orenchi ramen has a bit too much pork flavor to my taste, which overpowers the rest of the flavor pack. Beyond ramen on the other had is awesome. Less pork flavored but well balanced with fish stock. We ordered several side dishes. They were all good and had unique flavors. The only downside is the long wait time. Definitely recommended especially for those who love ramen.
author: K N.

description:
Orenchi Beyond Ramen: meh, too much garlic, texture of noodles was not chewy enough, not much toppings, broth was just okay, ~$15 incl tax and tip

Ambiance: A lot of thought and care went in to designing this restaurant. It was interesting to look around. However, the very loud music was overbearing.

I would not go back. There are better ramen places in the Bay Area.
author: Jolie S.

description: By far the best ramen joint in California. Pretty close to ramen made in Japan.
author: Dana T.

description: So close, but so far! I've eaten here probably 5 times as its in my hood. I love the decor and the vibe. I'm no ramen expert, but I know my way around and have traveled in Japan on several occasions. Two meals were fabulous, with near perfect ramen. Two meals were meh, with very poor ramen that suffered for a variety of reasons. One meal was just pretty bad. They have the potential for greatness, but they just miss the mark. I hope they get it together, I would love to be able to continue to frequent this place.
author: Mary M.

description: Yum. The orenchi ramen is a no brainer - super filling umami flavor with perfectly cooked ramen. The scallion, egg and nori all add to the slurpy goodness. Not to mention it's reasonable. I'd come much more often if there wasn't always a wait. They do a nice job of keeping the waiting area comfortable - heat lamps, tv, limited seats, drinks and food available.
author: Haley Y.

description: The best ramen in San Francisco, although it's not quite as good as the South Bay location. The regular ramen broth is rich without being too fatty, the noodles have good texture, and the toppings are all on point. I like the thinner chicken soba with lemon too, for a slightly lighter meal. I wish they would start serving the tsukemen they have at the other location.
author: Hal T.

description: Totally refreshing to find a place with delicious ramen and absolutely zero snooty attitude!  The prices are reasonable to boot.  The ramen is divine.  Thanks, Orenchi Beyond!!
author: Em P.

description: if you love tonkotsu, this is your place. awesome space, too, with an outdoor waiting area complete with bar for drinks while you wait!
author: Rachel T.

description: We've been looking forward to this place opening up for awhile now, and we weren't disappointed.  The ramen dishes were great, and the service quick (once you managed to grab a table). Excited to try the rest of the dishes!
author: Matt L.

description: Well, honestly can't tell you. It's been 30 minutes and still they haven't brought the ramen.  Really want to love it.
author: Joe B.

description:
Being a huge fan of Orenchi in Santa Clara, I was excited to see they finally made the move to expand and that the new location just happened to be in SF.

Summary: 5 Stars for food. 3 Stars for everything else.

The Good:
 - Food.
 - 'Orenchi Ramen' and 'Beyond Ramen' were delicious - Still among the top.
 - Apps were good as usual - Karage, Spicy Karage, Wings, Agadashi
 - Nice restaurant that is more finished than the Santa Clara location. (No unpainted 2x4's, open ceiling tiles, etc. Beautiful facade.

The Bad:
 - Arrived at 5:20 on a Saturday for a 6pm open. We were 17th on the list with a total of 55 people in front of us (16 parties ranging 1-8 people, avg. of 4). Sat down to eat at 7:30pm - Over a two hour wait. If you're familiar with Orenchi in Santa Clara, it's usually 45m-1hr wait.
 - Chairs are basically tree stumps with no backrests which would have been nice after waiting 2+ hours. Tables are close together, as per norm.
 - Approx 1/3 of the restaurant floor plan looks like wasted space. There's a bar with space behind the counter but it screams under-utilized which is unfortunate considering the popularity of Orenchi.
 - Ramen is +30% $$ than Santa Clara.
 - Hostess let two parties cut the line. One instance was because 'someone didn't know to put their name down' and the other instance looked like a friend who decided to stop by.
 - The menu is incredibly inconvenient. It's a 3 panel menu with horizontal pages that opens lengthwise like a scroll. 

The more modern 'Orenchi Beyond' is nice and it screams San Francisco. However, a large part of me wishes they kept the original persona which solely focuses on churning out predictably delicious food.

Best ramen in SF area? Probably. Would I go back? No...Can't deal with a 2 hour wait. If you decide to invest an evening - Put your name down and come back in an hour. Good luck.
author: Con L.

description: I work down the block and this is always a special treat for going out to lunch. I've only had the tonkatsu (pork) ramen. I prefer the Orenchi Ramen since it comes with the soft-boiled egg.
author: zach b.

description: It was preeeety gud. When I heard that there was a ramen shop in the Mission, I didn't think it would be this good! I recommend this place.
author: Gary L.

description: They missed our order; was waiting for a bowl of noodles for more than 30 mins. They didn't even take it off the final bill. But the food quality is good. Chicken wings are great.
author: Cheyenne G.

description: Came here last night with a friend for the 2nd time. I think I prefer the Beyond Ramen more than the original Orenchi Ramen. The portions are definitely a lot smaller than the Santa Clara location. The ramen is still better than most places in the bay area in my opinion. Their fried octopus balls was the bomb! ...Or maybe I was just really hungry. The noise level inside was kind of loud, hard to talk.
author: Matthew F.

description: Happy to have a ramen place added to the neighborhood. Good ramen. Great appetizer!
author: Sans S.

description: I had a great lunch here  The people working were very nice and the ramen was top notch.
author: Aaron F.

description: The appetizer are all very good. Ramen noodle was very good, soup was super salty, I could not finish mine at all, gave it all to my friend. It is totally not worth the one and half hours wait. It is over rated.
author: Diana C.

description: Finally tried this place and luckily didn't have to wait for the table. Ramen is pretty good but not great. Noodles are cooked well (chewy not  soggy), ingredients appear to be high quality (soft egg, mushrooms, bamboo shoots, pork). I think the broth is on the salty side and one-dimensional which is why I think it's just ok. Basically, one of the better places in San Francisco, but any hole in a wall place in Tokyo would be much better. What really kills it for me though is the crazily loud music and noisy hipsters talking about their hipster issues. Really hard to enjoy food surrounded by the cacophony.
author: Mikhail K.

description: Quick summary: Loud music, Beyond Ramen is ok - kind of salty. It's good to try it once but definitely not worth waiting an hour for. Over rated.
author: Jackson N.

description: Second visit in a month...   I like to try places more than once before I make an opinion. Cute trendy spot. Artwork is cool and the music they played the second night we were there was old school R&B...we love that. This place was suggested by a friend who is in the Ramen business.  The noodles were al dente (both days) personally for Ramen I prefer the noodles a little softer, not mushy but a tad softer.  The broth was consistent on both visits.  Flavorful and a rich pork taste.  I really liked they offer different sides (approx $1-$3 per). It would be nice to see more veggies though on the selection of sides. We ordered 3-4 different sakes.  The lady who services us what actually quite helpful as the menu wasn't too descriptive of the Sakes.  I would try this place again if it was for a fun night with friends.  But seriously, I still have a hard time paying over $6-$8 for ramen, let alone $12-$18 w/sides.  Ouch!
author: Leilani I.
